additionalFields.Description: People who have spent time in jail or prison often face barriers to accessing stable jobs, housing and financial services. These types of barriers are a key driver of recidivism for the more than 600,000 people who are released from prison each year. Between 2005 and 2014, an estimated 68% of people released in 2005 were arrested again within three years. Within nine years, 83% of those released in 2005 were rearrested, according to the U.S. Department of Justice’s Bureau of Justice Statistics.
additionalFields.headline: Justice Through Code is a free coding program for those impacted by the criminal justice system

additionalFields.Description:
Amazon has announced its largest single renewable energy project so far, with the purchase of 380MW of energy from the planned Crosswind Consortium project.

item.name: Well-Architected? Architecture reviews for modern cloud applications

additionalFields.Description: During application development as well as during subsequent operation, the question: "Am I actually doing this right?” arises from time to time. An architecture review is a good way to determine whether Best Practices are being followed and whether there are any risks in the architecture. The AWS Well-Architected Framework helps cloud architects develop secure, high-performance, resilient, and efficient infrastructures for their applications. This article shows how the concepts from the Well-Architected Framework can be put into practice. In doing so, the authors will also address the concerns of IT managers from German SMEs using anecdotes and Best Practices from the industry.
additionalFields.headline: Well-Architected? Architecture reviews for modern cloud applications

additionalFields.Description:
Nashlie Sephus found success in the tech industry in a place that doesn’t typically offer many options for Black tech workers like her: the Deep South. Now she wants to help others do the same.

The applied scientist, who focuses on ensuring accuracy and fairness in artificial intelligence for Amazon Web Services, bought a 12-acre property with seven buildings in her hometown of Jackson, Miss., last fall. Her vision: to create a tech hub that includes housing, retail and entertainment to try to help lift up the predominantly Black city in the poorest state in the nation.

additionalFields.Description:
Tomasz Stachlewski, CEE Senior Solutions Architecture Manager at Amazon Web Services (AWS) in an expert commentary for ISBtech on cloud computing trends in the face of 5G.

item.name: Broadcasters Weigh 5G’s Potential

additionalFields.Description:
For broadcasters, 5G represents both a potentially helpful new tool and a competitive threat. The reality of either prospect hinges on how quickly and deeply the technology gets rolled out.

Wireless carriers have hailed the new 5G communications standard as a transformational technology with a broad range of potential consumer and B-to-B applications, including streaming Ultra HD (UHD) content to smartphones and TV sets, supporting ultra-low-latency cloud gaming, delivering real-time navigation information to autonomous cars and enabling augmented reality (AR) and (VR) experiences for industrial or medical use.
additionalFields.headline: Broadcasters Weigh 5G’s Potential

item.name: How Charity: water is Using IoT and Cloud Analytics to Bring Clean Water to Citizens

additionalFields.Description: Every summer, just before the monsoon season begins in India, pictures like these appear in Indian newspapers or TV. But these could well be images shot in Ethiopia or another impoverished or drought-affected nation. Most of us do not see women and children walking several kilometers each day to fetch water from a distant well or lake. With pots stacked on their heads and cans strapped to cattle, they spend much time collecting water every day, and that’s one reason children do not attend school. The water at that resource is usually not potable and causes water-borne diseases. Around the world, 785 million people do not have access to clean water. It’s quite common to see cattle and humans consuming water from the same resource in India. While there is groundwater or water in wells, it takes a considerable effort to draw it out from the ground, as pumps are few in number or broken. A successful project undertaken by non-profit Charity: water in Ethiopia could be the solution to this problem. The project uses smart pumps with IoT enabled devices and cloud analytics. The IoT devices are designed by AWS partner Twisthink, an innovation design firm. And the cloud services are provided by AWS (Amazon Web Services). There is a partner ecosystem that handles other aspects of the project, like distribution, installation, and maintenance of the water pumps.
additionalFields.headline: How Charity: water is Using IoT and Cloud Analytics to Bring Clean Water to Citizens

While many industries have struggled, and some sank, due to COVID-19 constraints — just look at retail bankruptcies — others, like government agencies, have eeked out an advantage from them.

Bringing a new robot to market is exciting: new capability, new hardware, new services. The problem is when you get to software, where everything feels harder and takes longer than you think it should. Like Tesla’s full self-driving, which has all the hardware and intelligence it needs — with the possible exception of LIDAR — but is perpetually just ... about ... to ... arrive ... and even so, was recently savaged by Consumer Reports as buggy and ineffective.

Hardware is necessary, but software provides the animating intelligence that allows it to do useful, efficient, and safe work.

additionalFields.headline: Amazon is trying to build the future of gaming in AWS

item.name: Securing space: The military, academia and business find common goal in the stars

additionalFields.Description: From Apollo to Artemis, humanity has traveled outside the borders of our planet. Now, as satellites litter the night skies, we are embarking on a new generation of space exploration — one powered by the cloud.
additionalFields.headline: Securing space: The military, academia and business find common goal in the stars

item.name: Carrier Global partners with Amazon to enhance delivery of refrigerated goods

additionalFields.Description: Palm Beach Gardens-based Carrier Global Corp. entered into a multi-year deal with Amazon Web Services, part of e-commerce giant Amazon.com, that will use technology to enhance the delivery of frozen goods around the world.
additionalFields.headline: Carrier Global partners with Amazon to enhance delivery of refrigerated goods

item.name: Amazon announces price cuts on GPU instances in AWS Sagemaker

additionalFields.Description:
Amazon Web Services is cutting the price of GPU instances on Sagemaker, its fully managed machine learning service. AWS said customers will see up to 18% in price reductions on all ml.p2 and ml.p3 GPU instances.

The price cuts will apply from October 1 for all SageMaker components across the following regions: US East (N. Virginia), US East (Ohio), US West (Oregon), EU (Ireland), EU (Frankfurt), EU (London), Canada (Central), Asia Pacific (Singapore), Asia Pacific (Sydney), Asia Pacific (Seoul), Asia Pacific (Tokyo), Asia Pacific (Mumbai), and AWS GovCloud (US-Gov-West).
additionalFields.headline: Amazon announces price cuts on GPU instances in AWS Sagemaker

item.name: AWS moves forward on commitment to use 100% renewable energy

additionalFields.Description:
The company is committed to use only renewable energy in its entire global infrastructure.

Sustainability is already a crucial and decisive part of the strategy and mindset of many companies. Amazon Web Services has adopted a clear position on sustainability, hoping to generate a positive impact on the environment. AWS is committed to running the business in the most environmentally sustainable way possible and in addition to the environmental benefits inherently associated with the use of cloud applications, AWS is committed to only using renewable energy in all of its infrastructure globally.
additionalFields.headline: AWS moves forward on commitment to use 100% renewable energy

item.name: Federal cloud spending increased only slightly in 2020, but AWS’s Carlson says there's no going back

additionalFields.Description:
The holdup of big-ticket cloud computing awards in fiscal year 2020 may have dampened expected federal spending in that area, but Amazon Web Services executive Teresa Carlson said Wednesday that the speed and agility of cloud deployment during the pandemic means there’s likely no going back for agency leaders.

The pandemic compelled AWS's government clients across the globe to adopt and ramp up cloud services quickly to meet the fast-moving demands of the crisis, Carlson, AWS's vice president for worldwide public sector business, said Wednesday at the Fortune Most Powerful Women Summit.
additionalFields.headline: Federal cloud spending increased only slightly in 2020, but AWS’s Carlson says there's no going back

item.name: Amazon S3 On Outposts Hit GA

additionalFields.Description: This week AWS made yet another announcement surrounding their AWS Outposts, this time granting the ability to use Amazon Simple Storage Service (S3) APIs. Now users of Outposts will be able to store and retrieve their object data the same way they would in a normal AWS Region. All the tools, apps, scripts, or utilities leveraged through the cloud can now be configured the same way locally.
additionalFields.headline: Amazon S3 On Outposts Hit GA

item.name: Amazon Timestream database is now generally available

additionalFields.Description:
The latest addition to the AWS database portfolio focuses on time series data – a segment where fit-for-purpose databases are emerging because use cases ranging from IoT to e-commerce are driving data volumes overwhelming general-purpose platforms.

Following an almost 2-year preview, AWS's time series database, Amazon Timestream, is now generally available. Timestream is a serverless, purpose-built database that exposes time series data through SQL.
additionalFields.headline: Amazon Timestream database is now generally available

item.name: Amazon launches a virtual tours and experience platform, Amazon Explore

additionalFields.Description: Amazon today is launching a new service called Amazon Explore that allows customers to book live, virtual experiences led by local experts. The experiences may be focused on creativity, learning DIY skills, taking virtual tours of far-off places or cultural landmarks, or, in some cases, shopping local boutiques from around the world.
additionalFields.headline: Amazon launches a virtual tours and experience platform, Amazon Explore

item.name: Migrating an entire university to the cloud, during a pandemic: lessons learned

additionalFields.Description: It’s said that change is the only constant in life, and that holds true in the world of IT. This year has brought about lots of change for society—the way we socialize, the way we work, the way we learn, the way we teach. The way we stockpile unnecessary amounts of toilet paper. I could keep going.
additionalFields.headline: Migrating an entire university to the cloud, during a pandemic: lessons learned

item.name: Amazon Web Services named one of Atlanta's Best Places To Work for 2020

additionalFields.Description: Consumers may not be aware, but they cross paths with Amazon Web Services (AWS) all the time. NetFlix, LinkedIn, Facebook, and much of Zoom’s video-conferencing traffic are all powered by AWS. The cloud-computing arm of retailer Amazon, AWS offers dozens of services, including storage and computing power, that allow customers to run their internet operations through AWS data centers. Last year, AWS revenues topped $35 billion. Paul Soligon, director of the MidAtlantic and Southeast areas for AWS, predicts AWS revenue will increase 30 percent in 2020 — to well over $40 billion.
additionalFields.headline: Amazon Web Services named one of Atlanta's Best Places To Work for 2020

item.name: Ekwateur capitalizes on AWS services to reduce its digital pollution

additionalFields.Description:
Combined with financial optimization, the FinOps concept can also be an excellent springboard for improving a GreenIT strategy. Illustration by example with Ekwateur, a renewable energy supplier.

Founded four years ago, Ekwateur is a supplier of renewable gas and electricity, mainly to private individuals. But the company also counts a few companies and institutions among its customers, including most French ministries, Météo France and IRSN (Institut de Radioprotection et de Sureté Nucléaire). Very dynamic, the company has 240,000 customers today and expects a turnover of more than €160 million in 2020.

In just three years, the company has become the 5th largest energy supplier in France.

The Cloud for better resource management and faster performance
additionalFields.headline: Ekwateur capitalizes on AWS services to reduce its digital pollution

item.name: Verizon and AWS bring mobile edge compute to 3 more cities

additionalFields.Description: Verizon and Amazon Web Services (AWS) are on track to deploy 5G edge compute in 10 cities in 2020. Today, they said they’ve deployed Verizon’s 5G Edge in three new locations: Atlanta, New York and Washington, DC. They had already launched the mobile edge computing (MEC) platform last month in Boston and the San Francisco Bay Area. They still plan to add five more cities by year end.
additionalFields.headline: Verizon and AWS bring mobile edge compute to 3 more cities

item.name: AWS Launches Low-Cost Burstable T4g Instances Powered by AWS Graviton2

additionalFields.Description: AWS provides various Amazon Elastic Compute Cloud (EC2) instances, including a broad choice of Graviton2 processor-based, which allow customers to optimize their workloads on performance and costs. The latest addition to the Graviton2-based instances is the low cost burstable general-purpose T4g instances.
additionalFields.headline: AWS Launches Low-Cost Burstable T4g Instances Powered by AWS Graviton2

item.name: Arçelik chooses AWS for digital transformation push

additionalFields.Description:
Arçelik has selected Amazon Web Services (AWS) as its preferred cloud provider for machine learning and analytics across its operations.

The Turkish company, which owns 12 appliance brands including Beko and Grundig, says that it is looking to “transform itself into a data-driven organisation and provide enhanced customer experiences, innovate new services, and lower costs across its operations in nearly 150 countries.”
additionalFields.headline: Arçelik chooses AWS for digital transformation push

item.name: AWS details how tech firms use its cloud to aid COVID-19 response

additionalFields.Description: Companies in multiple markets are using Amazon Web Services Inc.’s platform to build products that can aid the global response to COVID-19, and the cloud giant today shared details about some of its customers’ efforts.
additionalFields.headline: AWS details how tech firms use its cloud to aid COVID-19 response

item.name: AWS Outposts Ready Launches With 32 Validated Partners

additionalFields.Description:
Solutions from 32 Amazon Web Services partners – from Alcide and Citrix to Trend Micro and Zadara -- are available now for AWS customers to use with their deployments of AWS Outposts, the on-premises version of the industry’s leading public cloud.

The new AWS Outposts Ready Program, unveiled today as part of the AWS Service Ready Program, is designed to make it easier for customers to find integrated storage, networking, security and industry-specific solutions that AWS has technically validated and tested on Outposts to help deploy, monitor, secure and integrate Outposts-based workloads.
additionalFields.headline: AWS Outposts Ready Launches With 32 Validated Partners

item.name: Amazon cloud offers silver lining for Thai start-ups

additionalFields.Description:
Amazon Web Services (AWS) is committed to supporting start-ups from birth through to maturity, said Gaurav Arora, AWS head of Startup Ecosystem for Asia Pacific-Japan.

“The AWS Activate programme enables early-stage start-ups to build quickly and supports them through their entire lifecycle," he added.
additionalFields.headline: Amazon cloud offers silver lining for Thai start-ups

item.name: Here are the six new stats Amazon will help the NFL track during the upcoming football season

additionalFields.Description:
Fans might not be able to engage in football by attending NFL games in person at the start of the upcoming season, but they can dive deeper into the sport thanks to new Next Gen Stats powered by Amazon Web Services.

AWS and the NFL are debuting six new insights into player and team performance in time for the season kickoff on Thursday between the Houston Texans and Kansas City Chiefs. The league previously announced the stat Expected Rush Yards, which was born out of the Big Data Bowl analytics competition, and is intended to reveal how many yards a rusher is likely to gain after a handoff.
additionalFields.headline: Here are the six new stats Amazon will help the NFL track during the upcoming football season

item.name: AWS keeps ‘commanding’ lead in latest Gartner cloud report

additionalFields.Description:
Despite a tightening market for cloud computing, Amazon Web Services Inc. remains the “commanding” leader over No. 2 Microsoft Corp. and No. 3 Google LLC, with No. 4 Alibaba Group Ltd. still relegated to “niche” status.

That’s according to a new report from Gartner Inc. made available on its site this week, laying out its trademark Magic Quadrant for cloud computing. Rounding out the niche category are Oracle Corp., IBM Corp. and Tencent Holdings, with no new entrants in any of the categories and empty quadrants for “challengers” and “visionaries.”
additionalFields.headline: AWS keeps ‘commanding’ lead in latest Gartner cloud report

item.name: Amazon Web Services: education is the key to the economic development of a country

additionalFields.Description:
The Manager of Programs of the Public Sector of Amazon Web Services (AWS) for Latin America and the Caribbean, Abby Daniell, spoke with La Hora about the reasons of promoting a program of 30 thousand scholarships that will benefit young graduates to facilitate learning about cloud technologies, which was recently made official with the Ministry of Education. At the same time, she pointed out that education is the key to the economic development of a country.

The program, which will be available from September 7th, 2020, is part of the technological innovation framework that the Ministry of Education recently launched: “the Mineduc Digital”.
additionalFields.headline: Amazon Web Services: education is the key to the economic development of a country

item.name: NFL reveals new ‘Expected Rush Yards’ stat, with help from Amazon Web Services

additionalFields.Description:
Football fans wondering whether the next handoff to a running back could be another Beast Quake have another stat to track thanks to Next Gen Stats, the platform powered by Amazon Web Services.

The new stat, called Expected Rush Yards, was born out of the National Football League’s Big Data Bowl, a data analytics competition which focused on the run game this year and sought to answer the question, “When an NFL ball carrier takes a handoff, how many yards should we expect him to gain on the play?”
additionalFields.headline: NFL reveals new ‘Expected Rush Yards’ stat, with help from Amazon Web Services

item.name: Weta Inks Deal With Amazon To Expand VFX and Animation in the Cloud

additionalFields.Description:
The studio is currently working on VFX for titles including the 'Avatar' sequels and 'Black Widow.'

Peter Jackson's Wellington, NZ-based visual effects and animation studio — whose Oscar-winning work has included the VFX in Jackson's The Lord of the Rings trilogy and James Cameron's Avatar — has inked a multi-year deal with Amazon Web Services to use the Amazon cloud to forward its VFX and animation production.
additionalFields.headline: Weta Inks Deal With Amazon To Expand VFX and Animation in the Cloud

item.name: AWS launches its Bottlerocket container operating system into general availability

additionalFields.Description:
Amazon Web Services Inc. today announced the general availability of Bottlerocket, an open-source Linux distribution it has developed specifically for running software containers.

Popular Linux distributions are designed to run not only containers, which enable applications to be run in multiple computing environments, but also a range of other workloads. Because they support a large number of use cases, they have a large number of components that can be difficult to manage.
additionalFields.headline: AWS launches its Bottlerocket container operating system into general availability

item.name: Algorithms Help Spot Possible Suicidal Intent Among Veterans’ Social Posts

additionalFields.Description:
A social media platform designed for America’s military community is now equipped with a custom machine learning model that insiders say can rapidly review public posts and pinpoint those that show signs and risks of potential self-harm. 

With support from the Veterans Affairs Department and Harvard University’s Nock Lab, Amazon Web Services linked up with the existing RallyPoint military social media platform to target the production of a technological solution that can speedily surface sensitive public posts and boost online suicide intervention.
additionalFields.headline: Algorithms Help Spot Possible Suicidal Intent Among Veterans’ Social Posts

item.name: Amazon to build wind farm in Galway to help power its data centres: The company has pledged to build on its Irish sustainability programme, with water conservation among its priorities

additionalFields.Description:
Amazon is set to double its renewable energy capability in Ireland with a new wind farm project.

The 115-megawatt (MW) project in Ardderroo, Co Galway, will support Amazon Web Services (AWS) data centres in Ireland, and is set to begin operations in 2022, with up to 27 turbines on the site.
additionalFields.headline: Amazon to build wind farm in Galway to help power its data centres: The company has pledged to build on its Irish sustainability programme, with water conservation among its priorities

item.name: AWS’s unique way of accelerating equality in technology

additionalFields.Description:
AWS DeepRacer Women’s League showcases racing with fully autonomous miniature cars powered by machine learning.

Who says that today’s foremost technologies such as cloud computing, big data analytics, artificial intelligence, and machine learning remain the exclusive domain of men? Certainly, this question no longer becomes relevant as women’s needs place an increasing demand on this precise set of technologies.
additionalFields.headline: AWS’s unique way of accelerating equality in technology

item.name: Official F1 study names Senna as fastest driver of all time

additionalFields.Description:
An official Formula One study that used "machine learning" and "cloud technology" has ranked Ayrton Senna as the fastest driver of all time ahead of Michael Schumacher and Lewis Hamilton.

The study aims to compare drivers across four decades to name the fastest based on pure qualifying speed alone. F1 used technology from sponsor Amazon Web Services (AWS) to reach the conclusion and claims to rank all drivers since 1983 while removing the relative performance of the car from the equation.
additionalFields.headline: Official F1 study names Senna as fastest driver of all time

item.name: Amazon now offers third-party solutions for contact center AI

additionalFields.Description:
Amazon today announced the launch of AWS Contact Center Intelligence (CCI) solutions, a combination of services that enables customers to integrate contact centers with AI through partners in the AWS Partner Network. Amazon says that CCI, which has solutions for things like self-service, live call analytics, and agent assist, is designed to make it easier for companies to apply AI to existing and new systems.

As customer representatives are increasingly ordered to work from home in India, the U.S., and elsewhere, some companies are turning to AI to bridge the resulting gaps in service. The solutions aren’t perfect — there’s always going to be a need for human teams, even where chatbots are deployed — but COVID-19 has accelerated the need for AI-powered contact center messaging.
additionalFields.headline: Amazon now offers third-party solutions for contact center AI

item.name: Amazon to help Toyota build cloud-based data services

additionalFields.Description:
Amazon.com Inc’s cloud computing unit will help Japan’s Toyota Motor Corp build a platform to help manage and monetize data gathered from the automaker’s global vehicle fleet, the companies said on Monday.

Toyota said its Mobility Services Platform will enable it to process and analyze data that can be used to develop vehicle services from ride and car sharing to behavior-based insurance and maintenance notifications.

The deal is an expansion of Amazon Web Services’ existing collaboration with Toyota, and marks the e-commerce giant’s expanding foray into the transportation business.
additionalFields.headline: Amazon to help Toyota build cloud-based data services

item.name: AWS quantum computing service Braket now generally available

additionalFields.Description:
• Braket is a fully managed AWS service that lets users experiment with computers from quantum hardware providers.

Amazon Web Services on Thursday announced the general availability of Amazon Braket, a fully managed AWS service that the company has touted will enable scientists, researchers, and developers to experiment with computers from quantum hardware providers.
additionalFields.headline: AWS quantum computing service Braket now generally available

item.name: RallyPoint teams with Amazon and Harvard to enable faster suicide intervention for veterans

additionalFields.Description: RallyPoint, a professional social media network serving the U.S. military and its veterans, today announced a pilot program in collaboration with Amazon.com Inc. and researchers at Harvard University’s Nock Lab to help veterans with issues of self-harm and suicide.
additionalFields.headline: RallyPoint teams with Amazon and Harvard to enable faster suicide intervention for veterans

item.name: IHS Markit makes bold bet on public cloud during the pandemic

additionalFields.Description:
Despite uncertainty brought on by the coronavirus pandemic, IHS Markit stuck with its strategy to move compute resources to AWS. IHS CIO Chad Moss offers tips for IT leaders making similar migrations.

As the coronavirus forced businesses to close in March, IHS Markit faced a difficult decision. The company, which provides data analytics services, had hoped to offload the bulk of its compute functions to the public cloud beginning in 2020, but the pandemic raised key questions.
additionalFields.headline: IHS Markit makes bold bet on public cloud during the pandemic

item.name: Jack in the Box leverages Amazon Web Services to improve efficiency

additionalFields.Description:
• Jack in the Box chooses Amazon Web Services (AWS) for its cloud services and scalable infrastructure that would enable operational efficiency throughout business.
  • The company migrated from its on-premises data centers to AWS to drive flexibility and resiliency across its organization.
additionalFields.headline: Jack in the Box leverages Amazon Web Services to improve efficiency

item.name: Amazon offers to train Utah teachers, for free, in how to prepare students for cloud-based jobs

additionalFields.Description:
Amazon is partnering with Utah to train the state’s educators to teach a curriculum developed by the tech giant to prepare students for jobs in the cloud.

The effort aims to provide cloud-computing courses and related resources to some 5,000 Utah students by June 2022, Gov. Gary Herbert said in a media teleconference Thursday from the Utah Capitol.

The state’s Talent Ready Utah training program will coordinate the effort with Amazon Web Services’ AWS Academy, which works with colleges and universities to help students learn skills and earn credentials offered by the company.
additionalFields.headline: Amazon offers to train Utah teachers, for free, in how to prepare students for cloud-based jobs

item.name: Octopus Energy selects AWS as cloud provider to power its global expansion plans

additionalFields.Description:
• UK-based energy market challenger Octopus Energy has named Amazon Web Services as its preferred cloud provider, as it gears up for further global expansion

Octopus Energy has named Amazon Web Services (AWS) as its preferred cloud provider, as the UK-based green power supplier press ahead with its plans to to scale its operations across the globe.
additionalFields.headline: Octopus Energy selects AWS as cloud provider to power its global expansion plans

item.name: Amazon and Verizon Pitch 5G to Businesses With New Server Sites

additionalFields.Description:
• Boston, Silicon Valley facilities could work for health care
  • So-called 5G-edge computing may enable instantaneous diagnoses

Amazon.com Inc.’s AWS and Verizon Communications Inc. are opening new 5G server sites in Boston and Silicon Valley Thursday, pitching businesses to use the next-generation network for everything from health care to tracking sports data.
additionalFields.headline: Amazon and Verizon Pitch 5G to Businesses With New Server Sites

item.name: Amid vaccine race, Moderna taps AWS as preferred cloud vendor

additionalFields.Description:
Dive Brief:

  • On Wednesday, biotechnology company Moderna disclosed that it has selected AWS as its preferred cloud provider. The Cambridge, Massachusetts company is currently developing one of the most advanced vaccine candidates for the new coronavrus, according to CIO Dive sister publication BioPharma Dive. Moderna will leverage AWS to run analytics and machine learning workloads.
  • Using AWS-powered infrastructure, Moderna was able to deliver the first clinical batch of its vaccine candidate to the National Institutes of Health for a Phase 1 trial, 42 days after initial sequencing of the virus.
  • Moderna is using Amazon Redshift — AWS's data warehousing service — to aggregate results "from dozens of experiments running in parallel," using insights to refine design and production cycles.
additionalFields.headline: Amid vaccine race, Moderna taps AWS as preferred cloud vendor

item.name: Global Payments stock gains after company says new partnership with Amazon’s AWS could triple market opportunity

additionalFields.Description: Global Payments Inc. topped earnings expectations Monday and announced a new partnership with Amazon.com Inc.’s Amazon Web Services that it said would provide more cloud-focused offerings for bank clients and allow the company to expand its geographic reach.
additionalFields.headline: Global Payments stock gains after company says new partnership with Amazon’s AWS could triple market opportunity

item.name: Amazon Announces New Command Line Interface Tool AWS Copilot

additionalFields.Description: Recently, Amazon announced a new command-line interface tool called AWS Copilot, which allows customers to develop, release, and operate containerized applications on AWS. With a single command, customers can create all the infrastructure and artifacts necessary to run a service on Amazon Elastic Container Service (ECS) and AWS Fargate.
additionalFields.headline: Amazon Announces New Command Line Interface Tool AWS Copilot

item.name: Amazon launches Fraud Detector in general availability

additionalFields.Description: Amazon today announced the public launch of Fraud Detector, a fully managed service powered by machine learning that identifies potentially fraudulent activities like online payment and identity theft. First unveiled during Amazon’s re:Invent 2019 conference last December, it’s now generally available for Amazon Web Services (AWS) customers in select regions.
additionalFields.headline: Amazon launches Fraud Detector in general availability

item.name: The 12 Coolest AWS Tools Of 2020 (So Far)

additionalFields.Description:
• Here’s a look at 12 new product/service releases and updates announced so far this year, including Amazon AppFlow, Amazon CodeGuru, AWS Fargate Platform Version 1.4.0, Amazon Kendra and new features for Amazon Macie.

Amazon Web Services has been known for its rapid pace of innovation in cloud computing, and this year is no different.
additionalFields.headline: The 12 Coolest AWS Tools Of 2020 (So Far)

item.name: KidsOnline: To take Vietnamese preschool education to a new peak

additionalFields.Description: KidsOnline, a "Make in Vietnam" application supported by "giant" Amazon Web Services, has overcome the monotony of pure technology products, becoming an application imbued with humanity. It towards building a community of education, nurturing, and developing preschool children in a comprehensive way, which is widely trusted by schools and parents across the country.
additionalFields.headline: KidsOnline: To take Vietnamese preschool education to a new peak

item.name: Amazon brings Contact Lens, a set of AI-powered contact center tools, into GA

additionalFields.Description:
• The machine learning-powered set of capabilities allow companies to automatically transcribe and analyze customer calls.

Amazon Web Services on Thursday announced the general availability of Contact Lens, a set of machine learning-powered capabilities that transcribe and analyze customer calls to contact centers. Contact Lens is part of Amazon Connect, a fully-managed cloud contact center service.
additionalFields.headline: Amazon brings Contact Lens, a set of AI-powered contact center tools, into GA

item.name: Volkswagen sees Amazon-built ‘industrial cloud’ as future B2B marketplace

additionalFields.Description:
Volkswagen AG, Europe’s largest automaker, is expanding its cloud-based software and data portal, aiming to develop it into an industry-wide marketplace where business customers can buy and sell industrial applications, the company said on Thursday.

VW’s “industrial cloud” was designed in partnership with Amazon Web Services and eventually will link more than 120 VW factories around the world to the automaker’s 1,500 suppliers and their 30,000 plants.
additionalFields.headline: Volkswagen sees Amazon-built ‘industrial cloud’ as future B2B marketplace

item.name: If Amazon were to stop innovating it would 'be out of business in 10-15 years': Amazon CTO

additionalFields.Description: Not only has Amazon seen great e-commerce strength since the start of the COVID-19 pandemic, but the tech giant also continues to thrive on the innovation front, including its Amazon Web Services (AWS) arm, which helps power other businesses. Werner Vogels, chief technology officer at Amazon joins BNN Bloomberg to discuss.
additionalFields.headline: If Amazon were to stop innovating it would 'be out of business in 10-15 years': Amazon CTO

item.name: AWS Adds Fourth Availability Zone in Seoul as Cloud Demand Soars

additionalFields.Description:
Seoul has become the fourth region to house over four AWS availability zones, joining US East, US West and Tokyo.

This latest launch will bring AWS to 77 availability zones in 24 geographic regions worldwide. Amazon is meanwhile planning nine more zones and three more AWS regions, to be located in Indonesia, Japan and Spain.

The opening comes as a growing number of Korean businesses — the country is the world’s most wired — go deep on the cloud, including flagship carrier Korean Air, major telco SK Telecom, as well as cloud-native startups.
additionalFields.headline: AWS Adds Fourth Availability Zone in Seoul as Cloud Demand Soars

item.name: AWS Launches A Livestreaming Tool Based On The Same Tech As Twitch

additionalFields.Description:
Amazon has launched a tool that will allow anyone to host custom livestreams without turning to the likes of YouTube or its all-conquering streaming platform, Twitch. Amazon Interactive Video Service (IVS) is even built on the same tech as Twitch.

Businesses (or anyone else with the drive to do so) can embed the livestreams in mobile and web apps, and they could limit the audience for their streams. They’ll have a deeper native level of interactivity than they might find on Twitch or YouTube.
additionalFields.headline: AWS Launches A Livestreaming Tool Based On The Same Tech As Twitch

item.name: HSBC signs multi-year deal with Amazon Web Services

additionalFields.Description: HSBC has signed a long-term strategic cloud deal with Amazon Web Services to create a more personalised banking experience for its millions of customers worldwide.
additionalFields.headline: HSBC signs multi-year deal with Amazon Web Services

item.name: Logitech for Zoom Rooms adds Alexa for Business integration

additionalFields.Description:
• Amid the COVID-19 pandemic, there's a need to reduce the need to touch conference room surfaces as employees head back to the office.

Logitech Solutions for Zoom Rooms will integrate with Alexa for Business as a move to make meeting rooms contactless.

Alexa for Business is a service that enables businesses to schedule meetings, reserve rooms and start video calls easily.
additionalFields.headline: Logitech for Zoom Rooms adds Alexa for Business integration

item.name: Amazon launches monitoring service AWS IoT SiteWise in general availability

additionalFields.Description:
Amazon today announced AWS IoT SiteWise, its managed monitoring service for industrial customers, is now generally available two years after its unveiling at AWS re:Invent 2018. SiteWise is live for Amazon Web Services (AWS) customers as of this week in the US East (N. Virginia), US West (Oregon), Europe (Frankfurt), and Europe (Ireland) regions, with additional server regions to follow in the coming months.

Manufacturers, energy utilities, and food processors often struggle to collect, process, and analyze data from their hundreds to thousands of internet of things (IoT) sensors. Extracting data across different locations is time-consuming and expensive, because this data is typically stored in local, specialized servers that lack a common data format. Even with a data-collection pipeline in place, information like equipment type, facility location, and relationships with other equipment must be annotated manually; customers have to write custom apps to calculate and compare performance metrics across facilities to derive insights.
additionalFields.headline: Amazon launches monitoring service AWS IoT SiteWise in general availability

item.name: The Online World Artificial Intelligence Conference (WAIC) 2020 Opens. AWS Drives the Innovation and Application of Machine Learning

additionalFields.Description:
Swami Sivasubramanian, vice president of AWS artificial intelligence, delivered a keynote speech, titled "Breaking the Convention: Machine Learning Everywhere", at the World AI Conference (WAIC) 2020 on July 9, 2020.

AWS’s Drug Repurposing Knowledge Graph (DKRG) was listed among the WAIC 2020 Super AI Leader (SAIL) award, reflecting AWS's leading technology in machine learning innovation and applications in healthcare sector.
additionalFields.headline: The Online World Artificial Intelligence Conference (WAIC) 2020 Opens. AWS Drives the Innovation and Application of Machine Learning

item.name: AWS Outposts now also supports AWS Relational Database Service

additionalFields.Description:
AWS Outposts, the hybrid cloud platform of the tech giant, now also supports AWS Relational Database Service. This allows customers to create RDS database instances in their own on-premise data centers.

By supporting the database instances in the on-premise environment, the hybrid cloud platform gets a significant increase in functionality. AWS Outposts enables companies to run native AWS or VMware Cloud on AWS in their own datacenters. This gives them an on-premise version of the AWS Cloud.
additionalFields.headline: AWS Outposts now also supports AWS Relational Database Service

item.name: AWS helps respond to natural disaster crisis

additionalFields.Description:
• AWS Disaster Response Program contributes to solving the effects caused by natural disasters, as well as giving access to technology in times of crisis

Latin America, a region that is often severely affected by natural disasters each year, requires programs and actions that help to quickly and efficiently resolve the consequences of these events.
additionalFields.headline: AWS helps respond to natural disaster crisis

item.name: The time for modernizing government IT is now, says AWS public-policy VP

additionalFields.Description:
There has been way too much lost in recent months: jobs, routine human interaction and, most importantly, lives. That has led one executive of Amazon Web Services Inc. to frame consequences of the global pandemic in terms of reassessing how governments handle technology as a critical solution for the recovery to come.

In an opinion piece published today on Morning Consult, Shannon Kellogg, vice president of AWS public policy, Americas, called for federal funding to modernize state information technology systems.
additionalFields.headline: The time for modernizing government IT is now, says AWS public-policy VP

item.name: Amazon’s AWS establishes new aerospace cloud unit as Jeff Bezos increases bets on outer space

additionalFields.Description:
• Amazon Web Services announced on Tuesday it was establishing a new space unit called Aerospace and Satellite Solutions.
  • Job listings for the AWS unit identify it’s looking to provide services for nearly every space sub-sector, including rocket launches, human spaceflight support, robotic systems, mission control operations, space stations, satellite networks and more.
  • Amazon has steadily grown its influence in the space industry in recent years, with a satellite connection service called AWS Ground Station and a satellite internet venture called Project Kuiper.

Amazon Web Services, the cloud-computing branch of the e-commerce giant, is further expanding its services in the growing space industry.
additionalFields.headline: Amazon’s AWS establishes new aerospace cloud unit as Jeff Bezos increases bets on outer space

item.name: IHS Markit commits to three-year data and infrastructure migration to AWS cloud

additionalFields.Description:
IHS Markit will migrate most of its data-processing infrastructure and hundreds of applications out of its datacentres and into the Amazon Web Services (AWS) public cloud over the next three years.

The global market research firm said the move, which will also include the migration of various corporate platforms and end-user applications, is for resiliency and innovation purposes, and will see AWS become its preferred cloud infrastructure provider partner.
additionalFields.headline: IHS Markit commits to three-year data and infrastructure migration to AWS cloud

item.name: Amazon launches AI-powered code review service CodeGuru in general availability

additionalFields.Description: Amazon today announced the general availability of CodeGuru, an AI-powered developer tool that provides recommendations for improving code quality. It was first revealed during the company’s Amazon Web Services (AWS) re:Invent 2019 conference in Las Vegas, and starting today, it’s available with usage-based pricing.
additionalFields.headline: Amazon launches AI-powered code review service CodeGuru in general availability

item.name: Cepsa will migrate all its servers to Amazon's cloud

additionalFields.Description: Cepsa and Amazon Web Services (AWS) have signed a technological transformation alliance that breaks the mold in the Spanish energy sector. The record size of the digital agreement involves the migration of all the oil company's IT operations to the leading global platform for cloud computing. In other words, Cepsa will no longer use its own data centres but those of the US multinational. For the time being, this decision alone will bring about an immediate 25% reduction in the costs of the oil and chemical company in servers, energy and maintenance, as well as a reduction in emissions, waste, agility in operations and efficiency through increased automation.
additionalFields.headline: Cepsa will migrate all its servers to Amazon's cloud

item.name: Amazon launches cloud service to help non-coders build apps

additionalFields.Description:
• Amazon already leads the cloud infrastructure market, and now it’s expanding its cloud product lineup with a tool for people who don’t code.
  • The Honeycode service will compete with offerings from cloud challengers Google and Microsoft.

Amazon’s cloud unit on Wednesday announced the introduction of Honeycode, a service that non-coders can use to write applications.
additionalFields.headline: Amazon launches cloud service to help non-coders build apps

item.name: F1 and AWS: data at the service of teams and spectators

additionalFields.Description:
The two groups will collect data in real time over the competition weekends to generate six new statistics for Formula One teams and fans alike.

The Formula 1 group and Amazon Web Services, the cloud division of the e-commerce giant, announced and made official the arrival of six new Formula 1 statistics on Tuesday 23 June. Based on the data, they will be gradually introduced until the end of the season, as soon as the season starts again, starting at the Austrian Grand Prix in early July. These statistics, which will evolve through the learning machine, will assist decision making and in-depth analysis and will be accessible to F1 spectators. To discuss and unveil the juicy details of these statistics, we interviewed Rob Smedley, a former chief engineer with Williams and Ferrari, who is now a technical advisor for Formula One.
additionalFields.headline: F1 and AWS: data at the service of teams and spectators

item.name: Genesys Selects AWS as Preferred Cloud Provider

additionalFields.Description: Amazon Web Services, Inc., an Amazon.com, Inc. company reported that Genesys has chosen AWS as its preferred cloud provider for Genesys Cloud.  Genesys Cloud is an all-in-one solution and leading public cloud contact center platform.  Consumers utilize the platform to manage and improve customer relationships that include voice, text, web chat, and social.
additionalFields.headline: Genesys Selects AWS as Preferred Cloud Provider

item.name: Amazon launches AWS Snowcone for data processing at the edge

additionalFields.Description:
Amazon Web Services Inc. today added a new product to its family of data migration devices, introducing a secure edge computing and data transfer device it calls AWS Snowcone.

The small, ultraportable and rugged 4.5-pound device offers up to 8 terabytes of usable storage and is targeted at the rising number of edge computing workloads, where space, power and cooling features are limited. The device measures just nine by six by three inches, and can easily fit into a backpack or a standard mailbox. It’s also light enough that it can be carried by most drones.
additionalFields.headline: Amazon launches AWS Snowcone for data processing at the edge

item.name: AWS flexes more cloudy Arm CPUs – and suggests they'll outpace competition over time

additionalFields.Description:
• Adds memory-optimised and compute-optimised instance types powered by homegrown silicon

Amazon Web Services has fired up two new EC2 instance types running its homegrown Arm-based Graviton2 processors, repeated the claims that they significantly out-perform the x86 silicon on which it built its business, and reckoned Arm will outpace other architectures.
additionalFields.headline: AWS flexes more cloudy Arm CPUs – and suggests they'll outpace competition over time

item.name: Top 10 AWS Cloud Migration Tools And Services In 2020

additionalFields.Description:
One of the ways of becoming a profitable business is by modernising the applications. With the ever-evolving technology, organisations have started shifting their businesses on public clouds as part of a larger digital transformation program.

There are several key benefits of migrating to the cloud, which includes operational resilience, business agility, cost-efficiency as well as staff productivity. Migrating to cloud platforms such as AWS is an iterative process that evolves as organisations develop new skills, processes, tools, as well as capabilities. It includes moving any workload from on-premise environments or any other hosting facilities to public clouds.

Here, we have listed down the top 10 AWS cloud migration tools and services one must know.
additionalFields.headline: Top 10 AWS Cloud Migration Tools And Services In 2020

item.name: Slack moves video and voice calls to AWS

additionalFields.Description:
Slack will run its native voice and video calling capabilities on Amazon Web Services’ Chime platform, part of a multi-year partnership for collaboration product development.

AWS is already Slack’s preferred cloud infrastructure provider, and the two companies have a common rival in Microsoft, competing with its Azure and Teams products, respectively.
additionalFields.headline: Slack moves video and voice calls to AWS

item.name: AWS launches AMD-based C5a instances for compute-heavy workloads

additionalFields.Description:
Amazon Web Services Inc. has launched a new family of cloud instances that run on Advanced Micro Devices Inc. processors and target computationally intensive workloads such as analytics applications.

The instances, which became available under the C5a name Thursday, are the first from AWS to use AMD’s second-generation Epyc Rome processors. The chips are based on a seven-nanometer architecture that provides 23% more instructions per clock than the first generation.
additionalFields.headline: AWS launches AMD-based C5a instances for compute-heavy workloads

item.name: Amazon Helps World Health Organization Launch Covid-19 App 12 Months Early

additionalFields.Description:
The World Health Organization (WHO) and Amazon Web Services (AWS) have exclusively told me how they have teamed up to create an app that helps health workers respond to the Covid-19 pandemic.

The app was designed around the needs expressed by 20,000 global health workers in a WHO Academy survey conducted in March this year.
additionalFields.headline: Amazon Helps World Health Organization Launch Covid-19 App 12 Months Early

item.name: AWS Ground Station Connects the Amazon Cloud to Space Satellites

additionalFields.Description: Amazon Web Services has a thriving relationship with the commercial space industry, making it the go-to cloud provider for nearly all new space startups. Its most recent service, AWS Ground Station (GS), provides a unique communications channel between satellites and AWS data centers.
additionalFields.headline: AWS Ground Station Connects the Amazon Cloud to Space Satellites

item.name: 5 Ways AWS Is Helping Its Partners During The Coronavirus Pandemic

additionalFields.Description: Amazon Web Services has stepped up with new online training and certification offerings, fee waivers and other concessions for its AWS Partner Network members dealing with remote work environments.
additionalFields.headline: 5 Ways AWS Is Helping Its Partners During The Coronavirus Pandemic

item.name: How AI and machine learning are helping to fight COVID-19

additionalFields.Description:
• Organizations have been quick to apply their AI and machine learning know-how in the fight to curb this pandemic.
  • These technologies are being deployed in areas from research to healthcare and even agriculture.

As the world grapples with COVID-19, every ounce of technological innovation and ingenuity harnessed to fight this pandemic brings us one step closer to overcoming it. Artificial intelligence (AI) and machine learning are playing a key role in better understanding and addressing the COVID-19 crisis. Machine learning technology enables computers to mimic human intelligence and ingest large volumes of data to quickly identify patterns and insights.
additionalFields.headline: How AI and machine learning are helping to fight COVID-19

item.name: Tricks for Trimming Cloud Costs in Downturn

additionalFields.Description:
The business turmoil caused by Covid-19 is prompting companies to cut costs any way they can, from furloughing staff to begging landlords for breaks on their rent. Another tactic is finding ways to save on cloud computing expenses, which are increasingly significant for many companies.

Although cloud computing is often touted as a way to keep technology budgets down, it’s easy for companies to rack up unexpectedly hefty cloud bills. Common mistakes include running online applications on older servers from providers like Amazon Web Services when newer, more efficient ones are available, and unnecessarily moving data to data centers in different regions. While cloud customers have sought to police these expenses for some time, many are doing so with a new sense of urgency because of the economic downturn.
additionalFields.headline: Tricks for Trimming Cloud Costs in Downturn

item.name: Amazon's five new solar projects to power operations in Australia, China, US

additionalFields.Description:
• Amazon hopes to supply approximately 1.2 million MWh of additional renewable energy to the company's fulfilment network and its data centres.

Amazon has provided detail on five new renewable energy projects it hopes will supply approximately 1.2 million MWh of additional renewable energy to its fulfilment network and Amazon Web Services (AWS) data centres.
additionalFields.headline: Amazon's five new solar projects to power operations in Australia, China, US

item.name: AWS, COVID-19, And The Need For Speed In Time Of Crisis

additionalFields.Description: As a tech analyst, I’ve been closely following the tech industry’s efforts across the board to rise to the occasion and support the radical changes to the way we live, work, and socialize brought on by the COVID-19 pandemic. One of the companies on the frontline of all this is Amazon—of course, part of this is the huge influx of people turning to the e-commerce giant for all of their shopping needs.
additionalFields.headline: AWS, COVID-19, And The Need For Speed In Time Of Crisis

item.name: Cloud use spikes amid COVID-19 but IaaS costs remain stable

additionalFields.Description: AWS, Microsoft and Google have benefited greatly from the COVID-19 pandemic as companies worldwide scrambled to adopt technologies that enable remote work at scale, and enterprises are more likely to enjoy flat costs or price cuts -- not hikes -- for the foreseeable future.
additionalFields.headline: Cloud use spikes amid COVID-19 but IaaS costs remain stable

item.name: AWS announces major enhancements to Amazon Macie

additionalFields.Description: AWS has announced a series of major enhancements to Amazon Macie, delivering important new features, greater availability worldwide, and substantially reduced pricing. The new features include updated machine learning models for more accurate detection of Personally Identifiable Information (PII), support for customer-defined data types, and native multi-account management with AWS Organizations.
additionalFields.headline: AWS announces major enhancements to Amazon Macie

item.name: Pandemic Accelerates Amazon’s Vision for the Future

additionalFields.Description:
The last couple months have been difficult for many people, but some of the global pandemic’s impacts on technology have reinforced and accelerated Amazon’s vision for the future, said Amazon CTO Werner Vogels.

“If nothing else, these past few months have truly ushered in an era in technology where we are seeing fundamental shifts in how everyone is feeling, not only in technology itself but how to access that technology, as well as how we build that technology,” he said today during a keynote at the AWS Summit Online.
additionalFields.headline: Pandemic Accelerates Amazon’s Vision for the Future

item.name: AWS makes Graviton 2 instances widely available

additionalFields.Description:
The ARM Graviton 2 instances of AWS are leaving the preview phase and will be generally available from now on. With the instances, AWS offers more computing power for less money, and the ARM architecture gets a big boost.

In December, AWS unveiled Graviton 2. This is an in-house built server cpu based on the Arm Neoverse design. The 7nm chip provides 64 computing cores with 32MB of L3 cache per core. AWS introduced the processor as a preview in its m6, c6 and r6 instances and promised up to seven times the performance of Graviton's first generation. Today, the M6g instances are launched to an audience.
additionalFields.headline: AWS makes Graviton 2 instances widely available

item.name: Amazon releases Kendra to solve enterprise search with AI and machine learning

additionalFields.Description:
Enterprise search has always been a tough nut to crack. The holy grail has always been to operate like Google, but in-house. You enter a few keywords and you get back that nearly perfect response at the top of the list of the results. The irony of trying to do search locally has been a lack of content.

While Google has the universe of the World Wide Web to work with, enterprises have a much narrower set of responses. It would be easy to think that should make it easier to find the ideal response, but the fact is that it’s the opposite. The more data you have, the more likely you’ll find the correct document.

Amazon is trying to change the enterprise search game by putting it into a more modern machine-learning driven context to use today’s technology to help you find that perfect response just as you typically do on the web.
additionalFields.headline: Amazon releases Kendra to solve enterprise search with AI and machine learning

item.name: An AWS exec explains how the company avoided outages during the pandemic, even as its rivals faltered: 'The cloud is all about creating the illusion of infinite capacity'

additionalFields.Description:
• Amazon Web Services has avoided cloud capacity issues despite surges in usage related to the pandemic.
  • David Brown, vice president of AWS Elastic Compute Cloud, told Business Insider that the company managed to avoid issues because it started adapting its supply chain in response to the coronavirus crisis in early January.
  • For example, AWS shifted manufacturing to countries with less of an impact from the virus to avoid temporary disruptions. 
  • "The cloud is all about creating the illusion of infinite capacity," Brown said.
additionalFields.headline: An AWS exec explains how the company avoided outages during the pandemic, even as its rivals faltered: 'The cloud is all about creating the illusion of infinite capacity'

item.name: AWS adds UltraWarm storage tier for Elasticsearch customers

additionalFields.Description:
AWS has announced that its UltraWarm storage tier for Amazon Elasticsearch Service that provides customers with fast interactive analytics of log data at one-tenth of the cost of existing storage options is now generally available.

Amazon Elasticsearch Service makes it easy for users to collect, analyze and visualize machine-generated log data from websites, mobile devices and sensors.
additionalFields.headline: AWS adds UltraWarm storage tier for Elasticsearch customers

item.name: AWS Launches SaaS Competency Program for Partners

additionalFields.Description:
• Public cloud leader aims to more easily connect customers with service providers

Amazon Web Services (AWS) has created a new Software-as-a-Service Competency for partners, making it easier for end users to find those with the expertise in building SaaS solutions on AWS’ public cloud infrastructure.

The Lowdown: The largest public cloud service provider said this week it’s making the new SaaS Competency available to Advanced and Premiere Consulting Partners that are part of the AWS Partner Network (APN). A number of channel companies have already reached AWS SaaS Competency, including AllCloud, Cambridge Technology, ClearScale, Storm Reply, and Mission.

The Details: Partners that achieve SaaS Competency use AWS best practices for designing and building such solutions through their professional service practices. Partners need to undergo technical validation by AWS Partner Solutions architects and show customer success to reach the designation
additionalFields.headline: AWS Launches SaaS Competency Program for Partners

item.name: Formula One and AWS collaborate for virtual machine learning event

additionalFields.Description:
Formula One has teamed up with Amazon Web Services (AWS), its official cloud and machine learning partner, to create a virtual event that will see professional racers compete against amateur developers from around the world.

The F1 ProAm DeepRacer event, which will run throughout the month of May, will be a one-off contest as part of the AWS DeepRacer League, a competition that sees developers build and train machine learning models that compete in monthly virtual races.
additionalFields.headline: Formula One and AWS collaborate for virtual machine learning event

item.name: AWS tops $10 billion in quarterly revenue for the first time

additionalFields.Description:
• Some Amazon Web Services customers, like Slack and Zoom, saw major usage gains in the quarter as companies and schools sent people home to avoid coronavirus.
  • AWS announced a deal with 3M in the quarter.

Amazon’s market-leading cloud business crossed $10 billion in revenue for the first time in the first quarter. At $10.22 billion, Amazon Web Services revenue grew 33% on an annualized basis, the company said in a statement on Thursday.
additionalFields.headline: AWS tops $10 billion in quarterly revenue for the first time

item.name: In face of COVID-19, AWS launches new cloud region in Milan, Italy

additionalFields.Description:
Amazon Web Services (AWS) launched a new cloud region in Milan, Italy, which marked its sixth European region overall. Italy, along with Spain, has been one of the European countries that has suffered the most due to the coronavirus pandemic, which has included a nationwide lockdown.

Amazon Web Services didn't directly say how the COVID-19 crisis impacted its new cloud region in Milan, but it did note that it will help Italian startups, enterprises, governments, education and non-profit organizations run their applications and serve end-users from data centers located in Italy.

"The opening of the AWS (Milan) Region demonstrates our ongoing commitment to the people of Italy and the long-term potential we believe there is in the country," said Amazon CTO Werner Vogels in a blog post. "Now, more than ever, we are seeing customers use efficient and secure cloud computing infrastructure to make a meaningful impact on lives around the world.
additionalFields.headline: In face of COVID-19, AWS launches new cloud region in Milan, Italy

item.name: AWS’ Teresa Carlson: NASA, Tech Companies Leverage Cloud to Explore Space

additionalFields.Description:
Teresa Carlson, vice president of the worldwide public sector at Amazon Web Services and a 2020 Wash100 awardee, wrote in a blog entry posted Monday how cloud platforms help NASA and space technology companies explore space, protect life on Earth and support other missions.

Carlson discussed how NASA has studied the conditions associated with superstorms through its collaboration with the Amazon Machine Learning Solutions Lab and AWS Professional Services.

“With the power and speed of AWS, analyses to predict superstorms can be carried out by sifting through as many as 1,000 datasets at a time,” she wrote. “To date, the initiative has aggregated observational data from 50+ satellite missions containing images, time-series, and miscellaneous telemetry data.”
additionalFields.headline: AWS’ Teresa Carlson: NASA, Tech Companies Leverage Cloud to Explore Space

item.name: AWS Gives AI Workloads a Human Touch

additionalFields.Description:
Amazon Web Services (AWS) announced the general availability of its Augmented Artificial Intelligence (A2I) service, which is designed to streamline human review of low-confidence artificial intelligence (AI) workloads.

The managed service is designed to make it easier for users of Amazon’s various AI capabilities to implement human review and improve the overall accuracy of machine learning (ML)-based image analysis, optical character recognition, transcription, and spoken language. “This interplay between machine learning and human reviewers is critical to the success of machine learning systems,” Amazon claims.
additionalFields.headline: AWS Gives AI Workloads a Human Touch

item.name: The chief evangelist of Amazon Web Services says the coronavirus crisis has 'pushed' the company 'into the future'

additionalFields.Description:
• Jeff Barr is the chief evangelist of Amazon Web Services and runs the company's news blog, which is often the first place customers learn about features and developments.
  • The coronavirus crisis hasn't changed his duties, but it has changed how he and his team complete them.
  • Barr said he expects the pandemic to have a lasting impact on the way the business operates.

As the chief evangelist for Amazon Web Services, Jeff Barr is usually the first person to reveal new developments about Amazon's multibillion-dollar cloud computing business — and respond to customer frustrations.

While the coronavirus crisis hasn't changed his duties, it has changed how he completes them.
additionalFields.headline: The chief evangelist of Amazon Web Services says the coronavirus crisis has 'pushed' the company 'into the future'

item.name: Amazon Keyspaces for Apache Cassandra now generally available

additionalFields.Description:
Amazon Web Services (AWS) has announced the general availability of Amazon Keyspaces for Apache Cassandra.

The cloud giant touts the offering as a scalable, highly available, and fully managed database service for Cassandra workloads.

Launched in preview at AWS re:Invent 2019 as Amazon Managed Cassandra Service, Amazon Keyspaces supports the same application code, Apache 2.0 licensed drivers, and developer tools that are currently used by customers running Cassandra workloads.
additionalFields.headline: Amazon Keyspaces for Apache Cassandra now generally available

item.name: AWS Chatbot launches, sending important alerts directly to Slack

additionalFields.Description:
Amazon Web Services Inc. said today that its AWS Chatbot service for sending notifications to DevOps teams is now generally available.

Launched in beta in June 2019, AWS Chatbot enables security, billing and system stability alerts to be sent to DevOps teams via the popular collaboration tool Slack. The service delivers alerts from several important AWS services, including Amazon Cloud Watch, AWS Health, AWS Budgets, AWS Security Hub, Amazon GuardDuty and AWS CloudFormation.
additionalFields.headline: AWS Chatbot launches, sending important alerts directly to Slack

item.name: Amazon launches its first African AWS datacenters as demand for cloud services surges

additionalFields.Description:
Amazon has officially opened its first datacenters in Africa, with its Amazon Web Services (AWS) cloud division launching three new availability zones in Cape Town, South Africa.

While Amazon first announced this new cloud region back in 2018, the timing of the launch is notable. Demand for cloud services has surged due to the COVID-19 crisis, with businesses embracing bandwidth-intensive remote working options like video-conferencing and individuals on lockdown consuming more internet-based services.
additionalFields.headline: Amazon launches its first African AWS datacenters as demand for cloud services surges

item.name: Amazon launches AWS AppFlow, a new service for managing SaaS data flows

additionalFields.Description:
• Amazon also announced that its EC2 Inf1 instances are available on AWS SageMaker.

Amazon Web Services on Wednesday announced the launch of AppFlow, a fully managed service that lets customers manage the flow of data between AWS and third party SaaS applications. With AppFlow, Amazon said customers can create and automate bidirectional data flows without writing custom integration code. AppFlow also works with PrivateLink to route data flows through the Amazon's network instead of over the public Internet.

"Amazon AppFlow provides an intuitive and easy way for customers to combine data from AWS and SaaS applications without moving it across the public Internet," said AWS VP Kurt Kufeld.  "With Amazon AppFlow, our customers bring together and manage petabytes, even exabytes, of data spread across all of their applications – all without having to develop custom connectors or manage underlying API and network connectivity."
additionalFields.headline: Amazon launches AWS AppFlow, a new service for managing SaaS data flows

item.name: AWS and Facebook launch an open-source model server for PyTorch

additionalFields.Description: AWS and Facebook today announced two new open-source projects around PyTorch, the popular open-source machine learning framework. The first of these is TorchServe, a model-serving framework for PyTorch that will make it easier for developers to put their models into production. The other is TorchElastic, a library that makes it easier for developers to build fault-tolerant training jobs on Kubernetes clusters, including AWS’s EC2 spot instances and Elastic Kubernetes Service.
additionalFields.headline: AWS and Facebook launch an open-source model server for PyTorch

item.name: Amazon tells cloud customers it’s ‘here to help’ as businesses face financial hardship

additionalFields.Description:
• Amazon Web Services sent some customers an email, offering a way to ask for financial assistance.
  • The correspondence comes after reports suggested that Amazon has not been very willing to give some customers relief as they deal with coronavirus.

Amazon Web Services wants to help. At least that’s what the company is telling customers who are struggling amid the coronavirus pandemic.

“In this unprecedented time, you may need to change the way your business is operating,” AWS told users on Monday in an email that was obtained by CNBC. “Whether you need to address financial pressures, support remote work, ensure business continuity or scale to meet unusual demands, we are here to support you and help however we can.”
additionalFields.headline: Amazon tells cloud customers it’s ‘here to help’ as businesses face financial hardship

item.name: From Delhi to London, Amazon Web Services helping all to tackle COVID-19 challenges

additionalFields.Description:
From Delhi to London, Amazon Web Cloud helping all to tackle COVID-19 challenges.

As public health organisations, universities, governments and companies globally scramble to predict and monitor the effects of the COVID-19 pandemic across the spectrum, Amazon Web Services (AWS) which is ecommerce giant Amazon's Cloud arm is helping them leverage the true potential of Cloud.
additionalFields.headline: From Delhi to London, Amazon Web Services helping all to tackle COVID-19 challenges

item.name: The Unsung Application Heroes Of AWS Come Through During COVID-19 Crisis

additionalFields.Description:
Amazon’s AWS is the most popular enterprise cloud infrastructure-as-a-Service (IaaS) offering in the world, boasting millions of cloud customers. While it’s known all over for its IaaS and PaaS (Platform-as-a-Service) solutions, less of a spotlight is dedicated to its applications which it has been adding over the past few years. 

Three of its popular apps, which I consider the unsung heroes of AWS, are helping businesses and schools navigate the current COVID-19 crisis that has swept the nation over the last two months, resulting in widespread closures. Today I wanted to attempt to give these three apps their proper due. Let’s take a closer look.
additionalFields.headline: The Unsung Application Heroes Of AWS Come Through During COVID-19 Crisis

item.name: AWS Boosts Snowball Edge Device Performance

additionalFields.Description:
Amazon Web Services (AWS) today revealed some updates to its Snowball family of edge devices, including a new interface for managing clusters and a boost in performance and virtual CPUs (vCPU).

Snowball Edge Storage devices now feature 40 vCPUs compared to 24 in the previous version and 80 gigabytes of memory. Data transfer speeds have improved by up to 25%, and that increased speed rides on a new 100 gigabit networking adapter and a 3.2 GHz processor, according to AWS.
additionalFields.headline: AWS Boosts Snowball Edge Device Performance

item.name: Exclusive: Amazon Is Powering The Coronavirus Diagnostics Of The Future

additionalFields.Description:
The lung scans of coronavirus patients coming out of Wuhan, China had the tell-tale signs of infection. While healthy lungs would usually show up as dark, these were showing the white haziness doctors describe as “ground glass” on chest x-rays and CT scans, resembling the splintering of a car windshield, and in some cases, a near total whiteout.

These patterns in the lungs were familiar to Dr. Savvas Nicolaou, a professor of radiology at the University of British Columbia and the director of emergency and trauma radiology at Vancouver General Hospital in Canada. In the 2000s, he was part of a team that analyzed chest x-rays of SARS patients. When COVID-19 started spreading in January, he teamed up with Dr. William Parker, a radiology resident at the University of British Columbia. Parker is a cofounder of SapienML, a company that has developed software to anonymize medical imaging data, along with Nicolaou and engineer Brian Lee.

The three of them had previously worked together on an artificial intelligence model trained on chest x-rays. “We thought, well, can we see the findings of COVID-19 in that model?” says Parker. They put out a call to collect as many chest x-rays and CT scans as possible to start building an open source AI model analyzing how the disease displays in the lungs, with the goal of developing an alternative way to diagnose patients besides existing tests.

Among those who answered the call to help Parker, Nicolaou and Lee build these CT scan diagnostics? Amazon.
additionalFields.headline: Exclusive: Amazon Is Powering The Coronavirus Diagnostics Of The Future

item.name: Amazon makes massive dataset available to coronavirus researchers

additionalFields.Description:
Amazon Web Services Inc. is throwing more resources at the fight against the COVID-19 pandemic, hosting and curating a massive public dataset relating to the coronavirus.

The company announced today that it’s making available an AWS COVID-19 dataset, which it says is a centralized repository of data and other information regarding the spread of the novel coronavirus that’s wreaking havoc across the world.
additionalFields.headline: Amazon makes massive dataset available to coronavirus researchers

item.name: Serverless is Key in Reducing Cloud Costs; How to Utilize it in Batch Processing

additionalFields.Description: “Serverless is the way to go when it comes to reducing the cost of using the cloud.” Yosuke Toyama, GM (Group Manager) of the Multi-Cloud Integration Division at Nomura Research Institute, Ltd. said: “Not only do we expect to see a reduction in AWS usage fees, but we're also seeing a significant reduction in the cost of maintaining the servers.”
additionalFields.headline: Serverless is Key in Reducing Cloud Costs; How to Utilize it in Batch Processing

item.name: AWS Migration Acceleration Program for Windows now generally available

additionalFields.Description: Amazon Web Services on Monday announced the general availability of its Migration Acceleration Program (MAP) for Windows. First previewed at AWS re:Invent 2019, the program aims to help organizations execute large-scale migrations and modernizations of Windows workloads on AWS.
additionalFields.headline: AWS Migration Acceleration Program for Windows now generally available

item.name: Swimming Australia Partners With AWS To Uncover Olympic Talent

additionalFields.Description:
Swimming Australia is partnering with Amazon Web Services to enhance the performance of swimmers and improve audience experiences. Data and insights from the Amazon cloud services provider will help uncover talent for 2024 Olympics in Paris, according to Swimming Australia.

The country’s peak body for swimming announced the deal today. AWS has similar deals with other sporting codes, including the Wallabies, Formula One and the NFL in America.

The public cloud provider offers several cloud computing and data services, which swimming Australia says will now be used to “optimise athlete performance at critical junctures of the race, create new swimming meet formats, connect the national tribe of swimmers to better identify talent, and provide more meaningful fan experiences”.
additionalFields.headline: Swimming Australia Partners With AWS To Uncover Olympic Talent

item.name: Interview with Dirk Didascalou, AWS: “I consider the cloud to be very liberating.”

additionalFields.Description:
Together with Amazon Web Services (AWS), the Volkswagen Group is building the “Volkswagen Industrial Cloud”. This will bring together real-time data from all 122 production facilities of the VW Group. “Industry of Things” spoke with Dirk Didascalou, Vice President IoT at AWS, about the Volkswagen IoT platform, other AWS projects and the benefits of the cloud.

"The real problem is no longer technology, but the cultural and process-related changes that result from technological change. In the past, a distinction has been made between OT, Operational Technology, or IT, Information Technology, and the product, the financing. They were all in their silos and had their tasks. Nowadays you can work in Operational Technology and have your own IT. Every project manager today can also deal with financing issues. These things are closely related. In the past, people budgeted that they could spend X million euros. If you go into the modern, cloud-based infrastructure, on demand, then you only pay for what you use."
additionalFields.headline: Interview with Dirk Didascalou, AWS: “I consider the cloud to be very liberating.”

item.name: Maryland Human Services Dept Deploys AWS-Based Social Service Delivery Platform

additionalFields.Description:
The Maryland Department of Human Services has used Amazon Web Services’ cloud computing technology to build a technology platform for state agencies to process social service applications.

Maryland DHS, together with Deloitte’s consulting arm, created the AWS-based Maryland Total Human Information Network within a six-month period, AWS said Tuesday.

The system is designed to comply with Federal Risk and Authorization Management Program requirements and help case workers access data on citizens who receive support through government assistance programs.
additionalFields.headline: Maryland Human Services Dept Deploys AWS-Based Social Service Delivery Platform

item.name: Tandem Bank goes all-in with AWS and infrastructure-as-code in bid to improve agility

additionalFields.Description:
