Tandem Bank is a UK challenger bank which offers credit cards, fixed-savings products and current accounts, all managed by its mobile app, which gives users various additional features, such as auto-saving, and aggregating non-Tandem bank account data from other accounts or credit cards.

When Paul Clark was made CTO back in April 2017, he made the decision with senior management that on-premise systems were not exactly what was needed in the business. “What we had wasn’t scalable, we couldn’t change it very quickly, and we couldn’t adapt to changing marketplaces or the changing needs of customers,” says Difa Niculescu, IT director at Tandem Bank.

“AWS was selected because it was the most successful cloud vendor, which was having good traction with onboarding financial services clients. It also has the most mature platform-as-a-service (PaaS) services, which allow us to integrate quickly and adopt services in the early maturity stages of cloud,” Niculescu says.
additionalFields.headline: Tandem Bank goes all-in with AWS and infrastructure-as-code in bid to improve agility

item.name: AWS opens second CloudFront edge location in Toronto

additionalFields.Description:
With an increase in the demand for CloudFront services, as well as the expansion of the services Amazon Web Services, Inc. provides in Canada, AWS has announced the opening of a second CloudFront edge location in Toronto.

This brings CloudFront’s global network points of presence to 187 locations; which includes 176 edge locations and 11 edge caches.
additionalFields.headline: AWS opens second CloudFront edge location in Toronto

item.name: The Top Things To Know About Becoming An AWS Partner

additionalFields.Description:
Solutions providers and other companies looking to become Amazon Web Services partners can tap the AWS Partner Network (APN) for programmatic, technical, business and go-to-market assistance to tailor growth plans and build their business around the largest public cloud provider.

AWS doesn’t disclose partner numbers for its global ecosystem of software and professional service firms beyond “tens of thousands,” but does say it added more than 35,000 new partners between 2016 and 2018.

“It’s a large and rapidly growing ecosystem,” said Kelly Hartman, the APN’s global head. “Our pace of innovation and what we offer to partners really is more significant than any of our competitors,” she said. “We spend a lot of time actually working with partners to look at things that matter to them and their customers. We really take a personalized approach to helping companies get there. A lot of companies look at building partner programs, and it’s kind of like ‘you figure out the program, and we’ll engage with you once you figure it out.’ We really help partners build to the specific things that customers are looking for.
additionalFields.headline: The Top Things To Know About Becoming An AWS Partner

item.name: AWS Cloud Tools Help University Scientists Conduct Climate Studies

additionalFields.Description:
Amazon Web Services has partnered with North Carolina State University’s Institute for Climate Studies to develop cloud-based datasets for two studies on the Earth’s natural phenomena using tools such as the Amazon Elastic Compute Cloud.

The first project was part of an international effort to assess the Earth’s ability to reflect solar radiation or albedo, while the second involved the use of recorded temperature data to create a historical climate dataset for the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, AWS said Sunday.

As part of the first study, the scientists tested EC2’s capacity for developing an albedo dataset from over 270 terabytes of NOAA geostationary satellite data and found that AWS can complete the task 50 times faster compared to an on-premises system.
additionalFields.headline: AWS Cloud Tools Help University Scientists Conduct Climate Studies

item.name: Amazon introduces computer vision into warehouses

additionalFields.Description:
Inside Amazon’s warehouses, the myriads of products stocked by the online retailer sit jumbled together in yellow bins, toothbrushes next to electric fans next to school textbooks. Until now, Amazon’s workers have scanned the barcodes on each product and on each bin so that the goods can be tracked inside the warehouse and easily retrieved by the squat orange robots that traverse the floor, moving tall racks of bins.

But in dozens of US warehouses the process is being automated. Instead of clunky handheld scanners, that often get in the way as workers grapple with bigger items, AI cameras and scanners watch the process and automatically track which products go into which bins.

It might seem like a small change, but it has had a significant impact on efficiency, said Brad Porter, Amazon’s vice-president of robotics, at the company’s re:MARS artificial intelligence and robotics conference in June. He added that the cameras would not replace human workers, but would change how they do their jobs.
additionalFields.headline: Amazon introduces computer vision into warehouses

item.name: Amazon Hong Kong opens AWS region; Recommend traditional banks to go cloud

additionalFields.Description:
AWS set up a data center in Hong Kong this year, marking the company’s 8th active region in the Asia Pacific. Alex Yung, Corporate Vice President and Managing Director for Greater China, believes this move helps promote start-ups and innovation from science companies, accelerating the transformation of traditional industry, he expects Hong Kong to become a data exchange center.

The biggest benefit with the AWS Hong Kong Region is that local users can store their data in Hong Kong, execute their applications on local platforms with lower latency. Besides, it can shorten the products development time for start-ups and technology companies. With three availability zones in Hong Kong, AWS’ services would be more stable and reliable than its competitors.  “AWS Hong Kong Region has a cluster of 3 data centers and each data center is 20-30km from each other with independent electric supply. Even one of them is down, the others will not be affected and disaster recovery is more reliable and stable.” Alex added.
additionalFields.headline: Amazon Hong Kong opens AWS region; Recommend traditional banks to go cloud

item.name: King of the cloud: Andy Jassy - the rock fan behind Amazon’s most profitable business

additionalFields.Description:
These days, the founder and chief executive of Amazon’s most profitable business, Amazon Web Services (AWS), is a pivotal player in the world’s second biggest company.

Jassy, Amazon’s second biggest individual shareholder with a stake worth $173m (£136m), may not be a household name like Bezos, who he shadowed for years as his right-hand man, but as the brains behind AWS - which now generates over half of all Amazon’s profits - he has played an instrumental role in building the Seattle-based company into the ubiquitous global colossus it is today.

This year, AWS - the world’s biggest technology infrastructure and cloud computing provider whose customers including everyone from Goldman Sachs to the CIA and Apple to Britain’s Home Office - is on track to generate $31bn (£24bn) in revenue and is growing 41pc year on year.
additionalFields.headline: King of the cloud: Andy Jassy - the rock fan behind Amazon’s most profitable business

item.name: The Latin expansion and why Brazil is strategic for Amazon’s cloud

additionalFields.Description:
The most used cloud platform in the world, Amazon Web Services (more commonly known for its abbreviation, AWS) began 2019 earning billions. With 41% global growth in the period, information technology services offered in the cloud were the main responsible ones for leveraging results: representing 13% of the entire Amazon revenue, over US$ 7.5 billion of the US$ 60 billion registered by the company between January and March.

The amount is global and represents millions of clients of AWS from all over the world. Among them, tens of thousands are Latin American and beyond that very little is detailed by the company. AWS doesn’t open local numbers, but a national event hosted in São Paulo allows us to have a feel of the width of the businesses in the country. 22,000 registered and 8,500 simultaneous participants followed talks about success cases and the applicability of the solutions offered by the cloud branch at Amazon.

The eighth Brazilian edition of the AWS Summit was opened with statements of the local importance for the company’s business. On stage, the vice president for sales in Latin America, Greg Pearsons, stated that the region “has a pivotal role in this moment of cloud, more specifically Brazil, with many large companies and brands moving their operations to the cloud”. Besides the focus on digital transformation, Pearsons also highlighted cloud natives, like Nubank, a Brazilian fintech which figured among the ten largest digital banks in the world, the largest outside of Asia.
additionalFields.headline: The Latin expansion and why Brazil is strategic for Amazon’s cloud

item.name: AWS rolls out new secure access features, cloud instances for enterprises

additionalFields.Description:
Amazon Web Services Inc. is following up the new security capabilities it debuted at the start of the week with yet more features for defending application environments running on its cloud platform.

The first of the additions, which were announced late Thursday, is a tool called EC2 Instance Connect. It aims to provide more security for the information technology personnel who manage a company’s cloud environment.

When performing sensitive tasks such as configuration updates, administrators normally use a protocol called SSH to establish an encrypted connection to the system being modified. The technology is used near-universally in both on-premises and cloud environments. With EC2 Instance Connect, companies can manage SSH sessions using AWS’ built-in access control mechanisms.
additionalFields.headline: AWS rolls out new secure access features, cloud instances for enterprises

item.name: SLASSCOM and AWS collaborate to position Sri Lanka as hub for data science and AI

additionalFields.Description:
To position Sri Lanka as a hub for data science and artificial intelligence (AI) skills, the Sri Lanka Association of Software and Services Companies (SLASSCOM) today announced the launch of its knowledge and skills mission to train 50,000 engineering and non-engineering students in Sri Lanka.

The students will receive training on cloud computing and AI skills over the next two years in collaboration with Amazon Web Services (AWS) through the global AWS Educate program. AWS will also help Sri Lankan startups through its Activate program, which provides them with the resources they need to build quickly on AWS – including promotional credits, and remote training and support.

By making available cutting-edge technologies and learning to a broad section of Sri Lankan students and entrepreneurs, the initiative will seek to usher in innovation at a scale that is transformative.
additionalFields.headline: SLASSCOM and AWS collaborate to position Sri Lanka as hub for data science and AI

item.name: AWS Summit Hong Kong hosts AWS DeepRacer League for the first time; Explore autopiloting and machine learning

additionalFields.Description:
AWS Summit Hong Kong was held at the Hong Kong Convention and Exhibition Center yesterday.

Alex Yung, Corporate Vice President and Managing Director for Greater China, explained the reason of launching a new region in Hong Kong being Hong Kong’s position as a world financial center and believe it will be able to become a data exchange center. As the new AWS Hong Kong region comes into service, local users can store their data in Hong Kong, execute their applications on local platforms and further lower latency.
additionalFields.headline: AWS Summit Hong Kong hosts AWS DeepRacer League for the first time; Explore autopiloting and machine learning

item.name: Amazon Web Services to boost Argentina presence with data ‘Edge’

additionalFields.Description:
Amazon Web Services (AWS), a unit of Amazon.com Inc, said on Thursday it will bolster its presence in Latin America with an “Edge” location in Argentina, its first in the country that will help speed up use for local users.

The so-called “Edge,” to be located in capital Buenos Aires, where AWS opened an office in April 2018, will help deliver data, videos and applications at higher speeds and improve cyber security, the company said.
additionalFields.headline: Amazon Web Services to boost Argentina presence with data ‘Edge’

item.name: Andy Jassy: “Amazon Web Services’ growth is twice that of its nearest competitor”

additionalFields.Description:
In an interview with “Les Echos”, the boss of the giant’s IT activities explains that this is only the beginning of AWS’s journey. He’s not ruling out the possibility that the activity, which represents $31 billion, could eventually be bigger than the company’s retail business.

"What matters most to us is what customers want. But we offer more features than anyone else on this market. We have more partners because, given our market share, they all choose to work with us before joining the other platforms."
additionalFields.headline: Andy Jassy: “Amazon Web Services’ growth is twice that of its nearest competitor”

item.name: Amazon Web Services scores Australia-wide government cloud deal

additionalFields.Description:
Amazon Web Services (AWS) has signed a new whole-of-government deal with the Commonwealth of Australia, allowing all federal, state, and territory agencies and departments, as well as public universities and government-controlled corporations, to access AWS Cloud services.

The arrangement comes by way of a “simplified procurement model” that is outed as allowing agencies to save costs from the day they sign up, due to the economies of scale.

A statement from newly minted Minister for Government Services Stuart Robert said the new whole-of-government volume sourcing agreement with AWS will bring additional savings for government and taxpayers. “Government agencies regularly engage AWS services, each with separate contracts. The new arrangement represents an opportunity to provide cost reductions through efficiencies of scale,” he said.
additionalFields.headline: Amazon Web Services scores Australia-wide government cloud deal

item.name: AWS Summit Shanghai 2019: Obsessed with Customer, AWS is Bringing More Services to China

additionalFields.Description:
On June 20th, the AWS2019 Summit in Shanghai was held at the Expo Center. AWS Global Vice President and Greater China Executive Director Rong Yongkang said at the meeting that global revenues will reach $31 billion in global revenues in the 2019 natural year, with an annual growth rate of 41%. To date, Amazon AWS’s customer base covers 190 countries, with 21 regions and 66 Availability Zones worldwide, with a national coverage rate of 65% along the Belt and Road.

AWS continues to expand in Greater China

In China, AWS has spread across 19 cities in Greater China, has thousands of APN partners, and has partnered with partners to carry out technological innovations, including the establishment of six joint innovation centers in Shanghai, Qingdao, Nanjing, etc., which was established last November. The AWS Shanghai Artificial Intelligence Institute and the AWS IoT Lab established in Taiwan in March this year.
additionalFields.headline: AWS Summit Shanghai 2019: Obsessed with Customer, AWS is Bringing More Services to China

item.name: Amazon Web Services rolls out Control Tower and Security Hub, courting big business customers

additionalFields.Description:
After seven months in preview, Amazon Web Services on Monday night announced the general availability of AWS Control Tower and AWS Security Hub, aiming to make it easier for corporate customers to set up, secure and monitor cloud environments.

Unveiled at AWS re:Invent in Las Vegas last year, the new services are part of a broader effort by the public cloud leader to lower the barriers to entry for large businesses that want to shift to the cloud, and to reduce the friction for existing business customers that want to grow their cloud footprint.
additionalFields.headline: Amazon Web Services rolls out Control Tower and Security Hub, courting big business customers

item.name: Geek of the Week: Amazon’s David Ham takes Pride in his work and his role with LGBTQ group glamazon

additionalFields.Description:
June is a busy month for David Ham. The senior video program manager at Amazon Web Services has plenty to do during his day job. But as the president of the Seattle chapter of glamazon, the tech giant’s LGBTQ affinity group, Ham has extra Pride in his responsibilities.

“I’ve been involved with glamazon since I started at Amazon almost three and a half years ago because it’s a passion of mine to be part of the community that continues to make Amazon an inclusive workplace for everyone,” Ham said.

We’re proud to call Ham our latest Geek of the Week.
additionalFields.headline: Geek of the Week: Amazon’s David Ham takes Pride in his work and his role with LGBTQ group glamazon

item.name: An Amazon Web Services executive says its cloud is the best place to run Windows applications, and customers are switching from Microsoft’s cloud because of it

additionalFields.Description:
Within the next six months or so, Microsoft is going to pull the plug on supporting SQL Server 2008 and Windows Server 2008 — two outdated, but still reasonably common, server products.

For Amazon Web Services, Microsoft’s chief rival in the cloud wars, this could mean a big opportunity. Indeed, the cloud giant says, it’s already helped customers like Influence Health, Fugro, and eMarketer (a subsidiary of Business Insider parent company Axel Springer) move some of their critical Windows software from Microsoft’s Azure cloud to AWS.

In fact, Sandy Carter, vice president of Windows and enterprise workloads at Amazon Web Services, goes so far as to say that its cloud is the best place to run Windows and Windows software. AWS has supported running Windows software since 2008, which was actually two years before the formal launch of Microsoft Azure.

“We do have a lot of customers right now that are switching,” Carter said. “The number one reason is reliability.”
additionalFields.headline: An Amazon Web Services executive says its cloud is the best place to run Windows applications, and customers are switching from Microsoft’s cloud because of it

item.name: Meet the 10-Year-Old Helping Amazon Web Services's Robotics Team

additionalFields.Description:
Karthick Arun is like many 10-year-olds. He likes science and pizza, enjoys playing tennis and is excited to enter the 5th grade next year.

But when he was just 9 years old, Arun became the youngest person ever to pass Amazon Web Services' (AWS) Cloud Practitioner test.

Getting certified at such a young age didn't come without challenges. Arun says that when he first showed up to take the test, the proctor thought his dad was the one getting the AWS certification, not him.
additionalFields.headline: Meet the 10-Year-Old Helping Amazon Web Services's Robotics Team

item.name: How Facial Recognition is Fighting Child Sex Trafficking

additionalFields.Description:
One evening in April, a California law enforcement officer was browsing Facebook when she saw a post from the National Center for Missing and Exploited Children with a picture of a missing child. The officer took a screenshot of the image, which she later fed into a tool created by nonprofit Thorn to help investigators find underage sex-trafficking victims. The tool, called Spotlight, uses text- and image-processing algorithms to match faces and other clues in online sex ads with other evidence.

Using Amazon’s facial recognition technology, Spotlight quickly returned a list of online sex ads featuring the girl’s photo. She had been sold for weeks. The ads set in motion some more traditional police work. “Within weeks that child was recovered and removed from trauma,” Julie Cordua, CEO of Thorn, said, recounting the case at an Amazon conference in Las Vegas this month.

The rescue illustrates Thorn’s strategy of nurturing new technology to combat child sex-trafficking and exploitation online. The nonprofit was cofounded in 2009 by actors Demi Moore and Ashton Kutcher and has become influential with both law enforcement—who can use Spotlight and other tools for free—and the tech industry. Thorn’s partners include Facebook, Amazon, and Dropbox.
additionalFields.headline: How Facial Recognition is Fighting Child Sex Trafficking

item.name: Honda Showcases AWS Usage, Driving Data Drives Social Change

additionalFields.Description:
On June 14, 2019, Honda Motor Co., a major Japanese automaker, unveiled a series of technological developments using data collected from vehicles connected to the Internet (Connected Car). Amazon Web Services (AWS) will be used to collect and analyze data such as vehicle travel routes and travel times to help track traffic congestion.

It was announced at an event held by Amazon Web Services Japan on June 14, 2019. “Developing services that make use of vehicle data by expanding the scope of services beyond mobility to the realm of everyday life,” Minoru Fukumori, Head of the Business Development Division of the Corporate Planning Division, said.

The company is using AWS’s cloud as the foundation for its connected services, especially cars. In Japan, a service named “InterNavi” in which a car navigation system is linked with the Internet is provided.
additionalFields.headline: Honda Showcases AWS Usage, Driving Data Drives Social Change

item.name: Amazon Web Services scores with AWS Private Marketplace

additionalFields.Description:
With the AWS Private Marketplace, Amazon gives companies the option of offering their own customized version of the software catalog within the organization, with only pre-approved applications. According to Amazon, more than two hundred thousand customers regularly use AWS Marketplace. It is therefore the most used digital software catalog of the cloud industry. For the general jury of the Computable Awards 2019 reason to nominate Amazon Web Services in the IaaS / PaaS supplier of the Year category.

The new AWS Private Marketplace gives IT administrators the opportunity to approve software products in advance that comply with company policy. In addition to the private version of the Marketplace, Amazon is further expanding the catalog with more container products. Customers now have the choice of 160 container products from independent software suppliers, including Aqua, CloudBees, Software AG and Tibco. The products can be deployed on Amazon Elastic Container Service (Amazon ECS) and Amazon ECS for Kubernetes (Amazon EKS).
additionalFields.headline: Amazon Web Services scores with AWS Private Marketplace

item.name: Global standards not solution to security challenges – AWS CTO

additionalFields.Description:
Creating global security standards among industry players is not the way to deal with hacking, but it is rather up to each company to stay ahead of the game, Werner Vogels, CTO of Amazon Web Services (AWS) said Thursday.

Speaking to journalists in Santiago during the AWS Summit, Vogels said that global standards are a nice idea but don't work in practice because they are usually out of date by the time they are implemented and because we are facing a "moving target."

Vogels is a strong advocate of the idea that security is everybody’s job, not just that of a company’s security team.
additionalFields.headline: Global standards not solution to security challenges – AWS CTO

item.name: First Autonomous Car Race Held by AWS in Taipei, Attracting Hundred to Apply Ranging from Students to Engineers

additionalFields.Description:
AWS's AWS DeepRacer League was held in Taiwan for the first time, attracting more than 100 players to sign up. In this competition, the college students performed well and won the first and third respectively. The second was won by Trend Micro's software engineer Jason Lian, while the Taiwan-Taipei-CKSun on the London Tour virtual league was Sun Zhenlun, a full-end development engineer from Qoobit, which was ranked 24th in the Taipei Entity.

Before the players enter the competition, they need to use the Amason SageMaker RL platform to train the Reinforcement Learning model online. Zhang Xia, AWS's chief cloud computing business consultant, said that even those who do not have a strong background in learning can use the SageMaker platform to make the training process of AI simple, and even directly select three models that are pre-trained by AWS. Train the selected track and given parameters. "AWS wants to make AI easier and more popular through the DeepRacer competition."
additionalFields.headline: First Autonomous Car Race Held by AWS in Taipei, Attracting Hundred to Apply Ranging from Students to Engineers

item.name: AWS skills collaboration gives rise to two-year pre-university cloud qualification

additionalFields.Description:
Amazon Web Services (AWS) is joining forces with the Career Colleges Trust to create a qualification in cloud computing that will be offered through further education institutions and universities across the UK from early next year.

The two-year course will provide students with a pre-university qualification that could either pave the way for them to pursue a full bachelor’s degree in a related topic further down the line or prepare students for entry-level roles in cloud computing.

Its content is being shaped by the Career College Trust, plus a number of other further education curriculum leaders, and will draw on the cloud giant’s longstanding AWS Educate programme.
additionalFields.headline: AWS skills collaboration gives rise to two-year pre-university cloud qualification

item.name: Creating a skilled pool of Indian coders top priority: Amazon Cloud arm AWS

additionalFields.Description:
As disruptive technologies begin to touch every part of our daily lives, the world today needs builders who can write Cloud-driven smart algorithms to help companies deliver customer experiences -- be it retail, banking, food, transportation or health sector.

According to Amazon Web Services (AWS), the Cloud arm of retail giant Amazon, India that produced amazing software engineers in the first wave of technology is now set to create builders for the future.

“The whole idea is to write smart codes. With our ‘AWS Educate’ programme, we’re sort of setting new records in India where several institutions have signed up a number of students for the programme. The response to join the next phase of skilling has been tremendous for us in the country,” Peter Moore, Regional Managing Director for APAC and Japan, Worldwide Public Sector at Amazon, told IANS.
additionalFields.headline: Creating a skilled pool of Indian coders top priority: Amazon Cloud arm AWS

item.name: SENAI Agrees with AWS to Teach Technology to 2.5 Million Students

additionalFields.Description:
Brazil needs 70,000 new IT professionals per year, but industry data indicate that schools do not account for even half of these formations with up-to-date knowledge. Aiming at this shortage, SENAI has just signed an agreement with Amazon Web Services for free access to the educational platforms of the US cloud computing giant, as well as credits for the development of applications in practice.

"Getting in the dough is the most effective way to learn. It is not just reading and doing tests, but practicing. Of course, the courses and trainings are very important. But we also give credits so that students or instructors can effectively develop things, at no cost," says AWS's International Vice President, Max Peterson, who was in Brasília last week to sign what the company calls a strategic alliance with Senai. The agreement was unveiled to Convergência Digital during the AWS Public Sector Summit, in Washington.
additionalFields.headline: SENAI Agrees with AWS to Teach Technology to 2.5 Million Students

item.name: AWS partner program targets cloud migration of ISV workloads

additionalFields.Description:
AWS has introduced a cloud migration program to help partners move independent software vendor (ISV) workloads to its platform, amid intense competition from Microsoft and Google Cloud.

The AWS ISV Workload Migration Program is intended to create repeatable cloud migration plans for specific enterprise application workloads so partners and customers can complete projects faster and cheaper. AWS’s Partner Solutions Architect team will work alongside partners to develop these technical playbooks, AWS said in a blog post.
additionalFields.headline: AWS partner program targets cloud migration of ISV workloads

item.name: Governments use cloud technology to combat opioid crisis

additionalFields.Description:
During the hour-long “Battling the Opioid Crisis with Help from the Cloud” panel at the Amazon Web Services Public Sector Summit in Washington, D.C., on Tuesday, 130 people across the country died from an opioid overdose.

That’s according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention National Center for Health Statistics. At nearly 50,000 annually, it’s more people than those killed in traffic accidents, the more-often quoted statistic on accidental deaths in the U.S. each year.

The panelists have implemented cloud-based solutions across agencies in multiple levels of government to securely input, analyze, and distribute citizen data in support of programs designed to address substance abuse and behavioral health in their communities.
additionalFields.headline: Governments use cloud technology to combat opioid crisis

item.name: AWS CEO credits intelligence community for cloud’s public sector growth

additionalFields.Description:
Public-sector adoption of commercial cloud is booming, particularly in the U.S., Amazon Web Services CEO Andy Jassy said Wednesday. And he largely credits the U.S. intelligence community — through its successful adoption of the cloud in 2013 — as the pioneer of the movement.

Six years ago, when the CIA struck a $600 million deal with AWS to build out a private cloud for the entire IC, commercial cloud services were “just picking up mainstream adoption in the public sector,” he said at the 2019 AWS Public Sector Summit.

The IC’s acquisition of a private cloud environment from AWS “not only really helped get governments on track using the cloud, but it was a huge impact because so many enterprises said, ‘If it’s secure enough and performant enough for the intelligence community of the United States, it’s probably secure enough and performant enough for us,’“ Jassy said. “It just changed people’s outlooks and had a huge impact. I think [the intelligence community is] having a great deal of success on top of AWS. And what it’s really done is helped them move much more quickly in accomplishing the mission in a rate that wasn’t really viable before.”
additionalFields.headline: AWS CEO credits intelligence community for cloud’s public sector growth

item.name: Modi building Cloud-first approach to empower Indians: Top AWS official

additionalFields.Description:
For a country like India, the hope lies in a visionary leader like Prime Minister Narendra Modi who is aiming to create a Cloud-first approach towards skilling and digital transformation, thus empowering over a billion people, says Teresa Carlson, Vice President, Worldwide Public Sector, Amazon Web Services (AWS).

Carlson, who reports directly to AWS CEO Andy Jassy and has been in India twice in recent times to explore the government’s digital transformation initiatives, hailed the return of Modi government to power.

“Leaders like him understand that they require transformative actions and sustainable economic development models to drive the change which would eventually benefit the masses. “Adopting the secure Cloud-first approach is top priority for governments the world over. Data is like currency because that’s where all the information and the opportunities lie, which can make a real difference in the lives of millions of people,” Carlson told IANS on the sidelines of AWS Public Sector Summit attended by over 18,000 technologists here on Tuesday.
additionalFields.headline: Modi building Cloud-first approach to empower Indians: Top AWS official

item.name: AWS Educate Adds New Badges

additionalFields.Description: Amazon Web Services has introduced three new credentials for AWS services. Through AWS Educate, students and educators can earn badges for AWS RoboMaker, Amazon Sumerian and AWS DeepRacer. To complete each badge, learners work through up to 25 hours of course content.
additionalFields.headline: AWS Educate Adds New Badges

item.name: AWS: Brazil takes important steps to be cloud first

additionalFields.Description:
Sharp about the regulatory changes that the Brazilian government has been adopting in recent years, especially the strategy that favors the adoption of cloud computing to offer digital services, the vice president of Amazon Web Services for the Public Sector, Teresa Carlson, aligns the country among those who are preparing for digital transformation.

“In Brazil, beyond the federal level, we are seeing things happen at the state level as well. What makes sense, either by the demand of citizens, or because they have their own legislation and budgets,” said the executive in an interview with Convergência Digital during the 10th AWS Public Sector Summit, which takes place this week in Washington, USA.
additionalFields.headline: AWS: Brazil takes important steps to be cloud first

item.name: Teresa Carlson: Here’s how AWS is convincing the feds to adopt the cloud

additionalFields.Description:
If the AWS Public Sector Summit was about anything this year, it was about the cloud service provider’s outreach to preach the gospel and education of the technology.

Teresa Carlson, worldwide public sector business chief for Amazon Web Services, sat down with me to talk about what it will take for the federal government to fully embrace cloud and reskill its workforce and what keeps her up at night when it comes to competition.
additionalFields.headline: Teresa Carlson: Here’s how AWS is convincing the feds to adopt the cloud

item.name: Virginia universities and AWS announce cloud computing degree

additionalFields.Description:
George Mason University and Northern Virginia Community College announced a new degree in cloud computing on Tuesday in partnership with Amazon Web Services’ Educate program.

“This degree is the first of its kind to offer students a seamless transfer pathway from a 2-year associates degree to a 4-year associates bachelor’s degree in the cloud,” according to an announcement from AWS.

The new degree program, set to launch in fall 2020, builds off an existing associate degree in cloud computing offered by Northern Virginia Community College, or NOVA. That degree, launched in fall 2018, is designed to lead students to a bachelor’s degree at GMU.
additionalFields.headline: Virginia universities and AWS announce cloud computing degree

item.name: AWS adds new partner programs for cloud migrations and government projects

additionalFields.Description:
Amazon Web Services Inc. relies extensively on partners to assist enterprise customers with their cloud projects. Today, Amazon.com Inc.’s cloud computing unit launched new partner programs to address two types of cloud projects that account for an increasingly important part of its business.

First up is the ISV Workload Migration Program. It will provide resources for consultancies and other partners that help enterprises move their on-premises applications to the AWS’ cloud platform.

One of the incentives that AWS offers is project funding. The Amazon.com Inc. subsidiary will provide partners with up to 15% of its projected annual revenue from a migrated application to help offset the cost of moving the workload to the cloud. Lower project costs, in turn, mean that partners can realize higher profit margins in projects.
additionalFields.headline: AWS adds new partner programs for cloud migrations and government projects

item.name: AWS to Help Cal Poly Utilize Satellite Data for Public, Academic Work

additionalFields.Description:
The California Polytechnic State University is working with Amazon Web Services on a new initiative aiming to enhance satellite connectivity and access to data from low-Earth orbit to utilize the information for wildfire mitigation, agriculture yield assessment and other purposes.

Cal Poly’s Satellite Data Solutions initiative will mainly provide students and faculty with access to AWS services, technologies and technical expertise to utilize satellite data, AWS said Monday.

The SDS initiative will support projects to address challenges currently facing both academic institutions and the public sector, such as the integration of capabilities of satellite developers and operators, real-time data analysis, land-use planning, resource evaluation and environmental analysis.
additionalFields.headline: AWS to Help Cal Poly Utilize Satellite Data for Public, Academic Work

item.name: Top U.S. Intelligence Official Says Cloud ‘One of Best Decisions We Made’

additionalFields.Description:
Sue Gordon, the principal deputy director of national intelligence, said the intelligence community’s $600 million bet on cloud computing in 2013 has more than paid off.

Speaking Tuesday in Washington at the Amazon Web Services Public Sector Summit, Gordon said the decision to turn to a commercial cloud vendor to host an assortment of classified, sensitive data for intelligence agencies for analysis and other purposes was to “hedge our bets against” against a world of big data.

Gordon said the 17 agencies that comprise the intelligence community have kept pace with that world and singled out cloud computing as “one of the best decisions we made.” Gordon said the C2S environment has improved the efficiency of intelligence analysts that sift through mountains of data, ultimately leading to better data for decision- and policy-makers. In addition, Gordon said it was more secure from outside attackers than the intelligence community’s traditional legacy systems.
additionalFields.headline: Top U.S. Intelligence Official Says Cloud ‘One of Best Decisions We Made’

item.name: Amazon embraces U.S. government business, despite occasional controversy

additionalFields.Description:
The head of Amazon.com Inc’s cloud computing division on Monday said the company would work with any government agency that followed the law, in contrast with rival Microsoft Corp, which has touted its rejection of controversial sales.

“We will serve the federal government, and they will have to use the technology responsibly,” Andy Jassy, CEO of Amazon Web Services, said at the 2019 Code Conference after being asked if the company worked with U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement. “Any government department that’s following the law, we will serve them.”
additionalFields.headline: Amazon embraces U.S. government business, despite occasional controversy

item.name: How AWS Ground Station is taking its giant leap for satellite links in small steps

additionalFields.Description:
Amazon CEO Jeff Bezos says his company has gotten so big that it has to branch out into business lines that “move the needle,” like the recently revealed Project Kuiper broadband satellite constellation.

But Project Kuiper isn’t Amazon’s only potentially needle-moving satellite venture: Amazon Web Services’ effort to create a network of ground stations and an easy-to-use satellite control interface is a similarly big bet for the Seattle-based company. At least that’s how Shayn Hawthorne, general manager for AWS Ground Station, sees the situation.

“We really believe that we’re going to be a clearinghouse to provide ubiquitous communications to the world,” he told GeekWire during Amazon’s re:MARS conference in Las Vegas. “Jeff’s talking about Kuiper in that context, and that’s a very specific use case. That’s a broadband internet provider to the world. But there’s going to be a whole lot of other mission areas that we want to bring into AWS and connect to the internet and the world as well.”
additionalFields.headline: How AWS Ground Station is taking its giant leap for satellite links in small steps

item.name: AWS is now making Amazon Personalize available to all customers

additionalFields.Description:
Amazon Personalize, first announced during AWS re:Invent last November, is now available to all Amazon Web Services customers. The API enables developers to add custom machine learning models to their apps, including ones for personalized product recommendations, search results and direct marketing, even if they don’t have machine learning experience.

The API processes data using algorithms originally created for Amazon’s own retail business,  but the company says all data will be “kept completely private, owned entirely by the customer.” The service is now available to AWS users in three U.S. regions, East (Ohio), East (North Virginia) and West (Oregon), two Asia Pacific regions (Tokyo and Singapore) and Ireland in the European Union, with more regions to launch soon.

AWS customers who have already added Amazon Personalize to their apps include Yamaha Corporation of America, Subway, Zola and Segment. In Amazon’s press release, Yamaha Corporation of America Director of Information Technology Ishwar Bharbhari said Amazon Personalize “saves us up to 60% of the time needed to set up and tune the infrastructure and algorithms for our machine learning models when compared to building and configuring the environment on our own.”
additionalFields.headline: AWS is now making Amazon Personalize available to all customers

item.name: At re:MARS, Amazon sells itself as an AI innovator

additionalFields.Description:
Thirteen years after effectively creating the cloud computing market, Amazon Web Services remains the dominant market player. When it comes to artificial intelligence and machine learning services, the competition is much stiffer: Google arguably has the deepest portfolio of machine learning technology of the major cloud players, while Microsoft is known as a pioneer in speech and vision and natural language processing. That’s left Amazon with something to prove.

Going as far back as 25 years, Amazon has been “truly pioneering the way we apply machine learning to real world problems,” AWS CTO Werner Vogels claimed Thursday on at the re:MARS conference in Las Vegas.

With its new re:MARS conference, Amazon is aiming to change the narrative around AI. It laid out the way AI is integrated into every part of its massive e-commerce business. It announced a new, cutting-edge drone designs and pushed forward Alexa’s conversational speech capabilities. Amazon also dazzled conference attendees with appearances from tech luminaries like Andrew Ng and celebrities like Robert Downey, Jr. All told, the week served to sell Amazon to its potential partners and customers as an innovator and a leader in AI -- and a company that can help others gain their own AI-powered advantages.
additionalFields.headline: At re:MARS, Amazon sells itself as an AI innovator

item.name: Amazon Web Services Strengthens its Services for Healthcare Industry

additionalFields.Description:
Amazon Web Services Japan, a provider of cloud computing services, strengthens its services for the Japanese healthcare industry.

The company began offering services for the Japanese healthcare industry around 2012. It now provides services for data analysis and genome analysis of drug discovery research and development using the cloud for pharmaceutical companies, medical institutions and research institutions. Recently, the company is also actively promoting the natural language understanding service “Amazon Comprehensive Medical” which is specialized in the medical field.

“The need for cloud computing is accelerating. We want to strengthen our system to actively propose services to healthcare companies.” said Yoichi Takizawa, Director of Readiness & Tech Solutions, Technology at AWS Japan, at a conference for trade press held in Tokyo on May 4.
additionalFields.headline: Amazon Web Services Strengthens its Services for Healthcare Industry

item.name: NASCAR Partners With Amazon Web Services To Move 500,000 Hours Of Historical Video To The Cloud

additionalFields.Description:
Racing body NASCAR has entered into a multi-year agreement with Amazon Web Services to move their historical video content into the cloud. The partnership will see AWS use cloud-based machine learning and artificial intelligence to automate indexing and tagging of digital content that would otherwise take thousands of man hours to do manually.

All forms of motorsports lean heavily on the heritage, but it may be more so for the likes of NASCAR. The France family and the sanctioning body has collected 70 years worth of content, some of which is still digitized to tape. With tape storage end-of-life media, and the costs of infrastructure to support storing the massive amount of digital content, NASCAR sees the partnership as critical.

All told, NASCAR is migrating its 18-petabyte video archive -- approx. 500,000 hours of content -- to the AWS cloud. There the company will use its Amazon Rekognition service to examine every frame of content and automatically tag who or what is within.  AWS will also use their own proprietary voice recognition service to transcribe interviews or broadcasts of races. As part of the deal, a new video series on NASCAR.com called This Moment in NASCAR History powered by AWS will air.
additionalFields.headline: NASCAR Partners With Amazon Web Services To Move 500,000 Hours Of Historical Video To The Cloud
additionalFields.Source: NASCAR Partners With Amazon Web Services To Move 500,000 Hours Of Historical Video To The Cloud

item.name: Teresa Carlson: ‘The gender gap in tech should be addressed quickly’

additionalFields.Description:
Teresa Carlson: ‘The gender gap in tech should be addressed quickly’

More women are urgently needed in tech so that organizations can reap the benefits of more diversity. Education plays a key role in this regard.

‘Diversity is an absolute must for organizations that want to remain relevant in the long term,’ says Teresa Carlson, Vice President Worldwide Public Sector at Amazon Web Services (AWS). Of course, diversity is about more than bridging the gender gap, but according to Carlson, gender inequality in tech is a problem that needs to be tackled very quickly. The urgency is higher than in other sectors.
additionalFields.headline: Teresa Carlson: ‘The gender gap in tech should be addressed quickly’

item.name: McAfee join hands with Amazon Web Services for enhanced database security

additionalFields.Description:
The device-to-cloud cybersecurity company McAfee recently announced its collaboration with Amazon Web Services (AWS) to offer cloud-based security solutions. As per the alliance, McAfee announced its Database Security for Amazon Relational Database Service (Amazon RDS). McAfee stated its new security product delivers real-time visibility into all database activities and offers monitoring services to prevent sophisticated attacks.

The new alliance allows the users to benefit from real-time protection for database workloads migrated to Amazon RDS while monitoring databases. McAfee claims that its newly designed Database Security platform is a highly scalable software solution that monitors the Database Management System.
additionalFields.headline: McAfee join hands with Amazon Web Services for enhanced database security

item.name: First AWS Summit in Poland

additionalFields.Description:
The cloud computing community from Central and Eastern Europe could gain knowledge about building applications based on services and functionalities provided by Amazon Web Services (AWS) during the first AWS Summit technological conference organized in Poland, which took place on 30 May at Expo XXI in Warsaw.

Machine learning, the Internet of Things, database migration and security were the leading themes of the all-day cloud summit in the capital, where the AWS Global Competency Center is also being established. AWS Summits conferences are cyclically organized by the largest global cloud computing provider in major cities around the world and bring together specialists from all industries and at various levels of cloud computing platform advancement.
additionalFields.headline: First AWS Summit in Poland

item.name: AWS announces new IoT services and managed Kafka offering

additionalFields.Description:
Amazon Web Services Inc. Thursday announced the general availability of several new services that it announced during its annual re:Invent conference last November.

Two of the new services are focused on the “internet of things,” which is an area that AWS said it’s looking to expand into in order to satisfy its customer’s demands to be able to move edge data into the cloud and perform analytics.

AWS IoT Things Graph is described as a fully managed service that helps people build IoT applications without doing any coding. The service works allows customers to connect various devices and cloud services via a simple interface, Amazon said.
additionalFields.headline: AWS announces new IoT services and managed Kafka offering

item.name: Emirates NBD ties up with Amazon Web Services to build a bank of the future

additionalFields.Description:
Emirates NBD, Dubai’s largest lender by assets, has joined forces with Amazon Web Services to offer a more personalised banking experience to users by leveraging the latest technologies.

The bank will use AWS’ artificial intelligence, data analytics, Internet of Things, image recognition and machine learning capabilities to simplify its customer services.

“We look forward to use AWS’ technologies and innovation practices to make banking more easy and intuitive for our customers,” said Suvo Sarkar, senior executive vice president and group head - retail banking and wealth management - at Emirates NBD.
additionalFields.headline: Emirates NBD ties up with Amazon Web Services to build a bank of the future

item.name: AWS launches Textract, machine learning for text and data extraction

additionalFields.Description:
Need to extract content from a document quickly and automatically? You’re in luck if you’re an Amazon Web Services (AWS) customer. Amazon today announced the general availability of Textract, a cloud-hosted and fully managed service that uses machine learning to parse data tables, forms, and whole pages for text and data.

It’s available today in AWS’ US East (Ohio), US East (N. Virginia), US West (Oregon), EU (Ireland) regions, and will expand to additional regions in the coming year.

Textract is more capable than your average optical character recognition system. From files stored in an Amazon S3 bucket, it’s able to suss out the contents of fields and tables and the context in which this information is presented, like names and social security numbers in tax forms or totals from photographed receipts. As Amazon notes in a press release, Textract supports image formats including scans, PDFs, and photos, and it ingests a range of document formats, including those specific to financial services, insurance, and health care.
additionalFields.headline: AWS launches Textract, machine learning for text and data extraction

item.name: The kids are alright: How Amazon is preparing high-schoolers to fill Australia’s tech talent gap

additionalFields.Description:
At Amazon Web Service’s (AWS) Innovation Summit earlier this month, 18 inner-Sydney schools participated in a round of workshops and panel discussions with some of Australia’s brightest innovators, as part of AWS’ Student Track.

It’s the fourth year the company has run its Student Track, which seeks to educate and inspire “impressionable young minds” about the worlds of tech and coding. It’s part of the company’s broader goal of upskilling Australia’s students and workforce to create startup founders of the future.

Alongside a panel discussion with innovators from Canva and Formula One hosted by AWS’ worldwide lead solutions architect Glenn Gore, the students also learnt how to code ‘Sphero’ robots to navigate a maze, and program Amazon’s Alexa voice interface and develop new uses for it.
additionalFields.headline: The kids are alright: How Amazon is preparing high-schoolers to fill Australia’s tech talent gap

item.name: Free Amazon Classes for Quebec Civil Servants

additionalFields.Description:
Amazon is about to expand its tentacles by offering free classes to Quebec civil servants while Amazon lobbyists are scrambling to get public data hosting contracts, Le Journal learned.

“DigiGov is a two day, free program offered to any government employee who wants to learn about the cloud,” explains Réjean Bourgault, national leader for Amazon Web Services (AWS) public sector.

Basically, DigiGov is a two-day course “designed for public sector employees” to familiarize themselves with cloud computing and “the different services available through the AWS cloud.” It will be offered in June at Université Laval in Quebec City.
additionalFields.headline: Free Amazon Classes for Quebec Civil Servants

item.name: AWS cloud training event marks 2nd year with more PH locations

additionalFields.Description:
Cloud computing purveyor Amazon Web Services (AWS) will be hosting the AWS Siklab Pilipinas for the second consecutive year and will be expanding from Manila to Cebu and Davao, as well as some parts of Luzon, to extend its reach as a large-scale cloud technology training event to more students and educators.

“What we’re doing is we are connecting content to students and we are connecting students to jobs through this program,” said Vincent Quah, worldwide public sector regional head of AWS Asia Pacific and Japan. “It is really about teaching tomorrow’s cloud workforce today.  What we provide is an open-course content. Any institution can use the content that’s part of the program and incorporate into their teaching content and their teaching curriculum.”
additionalFields.headline: AWS cloud training event marks 2nd year with more PH locations

item.name: AWS Makes Japan Debut of Autonomous Vehicle “DeepRacer”: DNP is Using for AI Training

additionalFields.Description:
On May 23, Amazon Web Services (AWS) Japan unveiled its self-driving, 1/18-scale racing car AWS DeepRacer for the first time in Japan. At the same time, Dai Nippon Printing (DNP), which uses the service, explained the company’s efforts.

One of the elements that enables DeepRacer’ self-driving is reinforcement learning, a type of machine learning. In this method, the machine learns by being given a high reward function when it performs an ideal action. For example, if the position of the car is within 10% of the center line; 1.0 points are given, and if it is within 25%, 0.5 points are given. The location of the center line is recognized with images taken by the onboard camera.

“AWS has invested in machine learning for 20 years,” said Yoichi Takizawa, Senior Manager, Principal Solutions Architect of AWS Japan. “We developed this service because we wanted to bring reinforcement learning to all developers.”
additionalFields.headline: AWS Makes Japan Debut of Autonomous Vehicle “DeepRacer”: DNP is Using for AI Training

item.name: AWS Config Rules price change could cut cloud compliance costs

additionalFields.Description:
Planned changes to an AWS service’s pricing model could help customers maintain cloud compliance and possibly even save a little money.

AWS Config helps admins oversee their organization’s AWS resources for cloud compliance and security purposes. It maintains a record of resource configurations and sends alerts via AWS Simple Notification Service (SNS) when changes occur.

First introduced in 2014, AWS built upon Config in 2015 with AWS Config Rules. This service helps users apply granular rules, such as to ensure encryption for all Elastic Block Store volumes or scheduled rotation of security access keys.
additionalFields.headline: AWS Config Rules price change could cut cloud compliance costs

item.name: Q&A: As AI and machine-learning tech evolves, AWS keeps pace

additionalFields.Description:
Major data trends occurring in the enterprise are focused on cloud and artificial intelligence platforms. But while companies are often eager to learn more about this tech, they aren’t quite sure how they will benefit, according to Ariel Kelman, vice president of worldwide marketing at Amazon Web Services Inc.

“Machine-learning and AI are really at the forefront of a lot of discussions in enterprise IT, and there’s massive interest, but it’s still early,” said Kelman. “One of the things we’re seeing companies really focused on now is just getting all their data ready to do the machine-learning training and training all their people to be able to use new skills.”
additionalFields.headline: Q&A: As AI and machine-learning tech evolves, AWS keeps pace

item.name: How The New York Times moved an old COBOL app to a modern cloud

additionalFields.Description:
The NYT IT team chose AWS to run a business-critical app that managed daily home delivery of the newspaper since 1979. Find out why it was worth the bother.

Why would you ever bother to move an ancient COBOL-based application to the cloud? Sure, it sounds great—from pricey mainframe to cost-effective cloud—but buried in that transition is a lot of effort, far more than most realize. So why bother?

I asked that question of Brandon Edenfield, CEO of Modern Systems, a provider of modernization solutions for legacy application source code, data and platform transformations. Modern Systems worked with The New York Times to move a business-critical application that managed daily home delivery of the newspaper since 1979, supporting a line of business worth more than $500 million annually. The goal? Get it running on Amazon Web Services.
additionalFields.headline: How The New York Times moved an old COBOL app to a modern cloud

item.name: Amazon’s AWS Ground Station for satellite data hits general availability

additionalFields.Description:
Amazon has announced that AWS Ground Station, a service designed to help AWS cloud customers access and manage data from satellites, is now in general availability. The internet giant launched Ground Station in preview back in November, but from today it’s open to any AWS user.

The service entails placing satellite ground stations and antennas close to AWS datacenters, the first two of which are now in full operation.
additionalFields.headline: Amazon’s AWS Ground Station for satellite data hits general availability

item.name: AWS on India hiring spree to meet demand for AI, big data services

additionalFields.Description:
Cloud computing giant Amazon Web Services (AWS) has embarked on a major hiring spree in India spurred by a major uptake in services related to artificial intelligence, analytics and big data, a top executive told TechCircle.

Craig Stires, AWS’ Asia Pacific head of artificial intelligence, analytics and big data, said that the company was also recruiting rapidly in the three other markets in the region owing to the demand for such services.

“We are absolutely growing the teams,” Stires said. “We have been expanding them to provide the right kind of technical and customer support in all the markets in the region.” He added that AWS was also investing heavily in training capabilities across the region.
additionalFields.headline: AWS on India hiring spree to meet demand for AI, big data services

item.name: 20 Solution Providers With New AWS Partner Statuses And Competencies

additionalFields.Description:
The top-ranked public cloud provider continues to build out its expansive global partner network by introducing the Amazon Connect Service Delivery Partner program.

Blu, Metova, Syslink Xandria, JASK, Corvil and Immuta are among companies that are now Advanced Technology Partners for Amazon Web Services, and Ventech Solutions and Pyramid Systems are newly minted AWS Advanced Consulting Partners as the top-ranked public cloud provider continues to build out its expansive global partner program.
additionalFields.headline: 20 Solution Providers With New AWS Partner Statuses And Competencies

item.name: How Amazon Web Services’ Mai-Lan Tomsen Bukovec is preparing for a data explosion

additionalFields.Description:
One of the only certainties about the future of enterprise computing is that more data will be collected, processed, and analyzed by future businesses than we can fathom today. Mai-Lan Tomsen Bukovec is responsible for making sure today’s cloud computing leader is ready for that future.

That’s just one of the topics we’ll explore June 5th at the GeekWire Cloud Summit, where Tomsen Bukovec will be joining us on stage to talk about how Amazon Web Services is adjusting its storage strategy in light of this coming explosion of data. In a recent interview with GeekWire, she pointed out that just two technology trends — the growing numbers of sensors in industrial internet of things and autonomous cars — alone will generate reams and reams of data for future companies to collect and analyze.

“The explosion of data is going to be beyond what we’ve ever seen before,” Tomsen Bukovec said.
additionalFields.headline: How Amazon Web Services’ Mai-Lan Tomsen Bukovec is preparing for a data explosion

item.name: Cloud Computing Masterclass Held on AWSome Day in Nanjing

additionalFields.Description:
On May 21, Zhixin Zhiyuan – AWSome Day Cloud Computing Technology Class was held in Nanjing.

It is understood that Amazon Web Services (AWS) is Amazon’s cloud computing-focused subsidiary, providing cloud computing platforms and services to developers and enterprise customers. AWSome Day is an important event for AWS to tour around the world. It has been in China for six years. AWSome Day is based on the AWS Cloud Service Design Technology training course, which revolves around AWS core services.
additionalFields.headline: Cloud Computing Masterclass Held on AWSome Day in Nanjing

item.name: AWS MediaPackage adds support for just-in-time packaging for VoD

additionalFields.Description:
AWS Elemental’s MediaPackage is now able to package, encrypt and originate video-on-demand content.

The solution is already available for live channels but can now also package file-based video and live video to multiple distribution formats and protect content with multiple digital rights management (DRM) standards.

According to AWS, an adaptive bitrate (ABR) video asset, stored in a single format, can be ingested into a MediaPackage VoD packaging group. All VoD assets in a packaging group are then available for playback on a range of devices, with different combinations of distribution protocol, bitrate ladder, and DRM encryption defined by the VoD packaging configurations that are applied to the packaging group.
additionalFields.headline: AWS MediaPackage adds support for just-in-time packaging for VoD

item.name: Informatica signs a key deal with Amazon Web Services to help customers figure out the best way to move big chunks of data to the cloud by using AI

additionalFields.Description:
There’s so much data that needs to be moved to and process in the cloud, a platform like Amazon Web Services is turning to artificial intelligence to help its customers sort through huge chunks of information.

On Tuesday, Informatica, a 26-year-old company which makes software for managing business data, said it will be working with the cloud giant to do just that.

Informatica said it will be working with AWS and Cognizant, an IT services company, to give AWS clients a smarter way to move their data to the cloud. Informatica’s technology will be a free AI-based tool to help AWS clients come up with a cost-efficient plan to migrate their data over. AWS clients would also be able to buy a report on the data migration, with consulting services from Cognizant.
additionalFields.headline: Informatica signs a key deal with Amazon Web Services to help customers figure out the best way to move big chunks of data to the cloud by using AI

item.name: Experimentation has increased due to cloud computing, says AWS’ Olivier Klein

additionalFields.Description:
Amazon’s cloud platform - Amazon Web Services or AWS - has been operational for the past 13 years and over this time, has over 165 features as offerings for computer storage, database, networking, analytics, robotics, machine learning (ML), Artificial Intelligence (AI), Internet of Things (IoT), mobile, security, hybrid, virtual and augmented reality (VR and AR), media, and application development, deployment, and management.

Olivier Klein, Head of Emerging Technologies (Asia-Pacific and Europe), AWS, in an exclusive interaction with YourStory talks about new technologies, data security, and trends at AWS.
additionalFields.headline: Experimentation has increased due to cloud computing, says AWS’ Olivier Klein

item.name: Werner Vogels, CTO of Amazon, says, “Amazon’s innovation aims to make customers’ dreams come true.”

additionalFields.Description:
“The secret of Amazon’s success and innovation lies in consumer obsession,” said Werner Vogels, the Chief Technology Officer of Amazon.

In an email interview with the Korea Economic Daily on May 19, Vogels said that Amazon reinvents the customer experience in areas where there is opportunity to better serve customers by listening to their voices. He is expected to deliver a keynote speech at Strong Korea Forum 2019 hosted by the Ministry of Science and ICT (MSIT) and the Korea Economic Daily at Lotte Hotel in Seoul on May 23.

Vogels has been serving as CTO of Amazon for fourteen years since 2005, just a year after joining the company. “At Amazon, we don’t have geniuses who can predict what the future holds. We have arrived at where we are now by repeatedly turning consumers’ wishes into reality,” explained Vogels.
additionalFields.headline: Werner Vogels, CTO of Amazon, says, “Amazon’s innovation aims to make customers’ dreams come true.”

item.name: MCCCD and Amazon Web Services partner for new program

additionalFields.Description:
Maricopa Community Colleges have teamed up with Amazon Web Services to offer students a program to pursue cloud computing in the tech industry.

According to a release by Maricopa Community Colleges, students will have access to a program that offers 15-credit hours as soon as the Fall 2019 semester. They will be able to search the Amazon Web Services job board, partner network and customers while receiving interactive real-world, project-based assignments.

“Our collaboration with AWS is an exciting step forward to closing the employability gap and preparing the community for the workforce of today and tomorrow,” Harper-Marinick said in the release.
additionalFields.headline: MCCCD and Amazon Web Services partner for new program

item.name: AWS Solution Helps L.A. County Address Call Wait Times

additionalFields.Description:
After hearing feedback from internal and external customers, Los Angeles County is partnering with two communications providers to deploy technology that will transform its longstanding call center into a contact center.

A call center, officials emphasized to Techwire, merely responds to calls for service, often with human-to-human interaction that, while personalized, may not be the most efficient delivery method. That was the case with the county’s existing call center, which had existed on-prem for more than a decade, said Benny Chacko, deputy general manager of the Internal Services Department (ISD). A contact center, Chacko added, could enable “multiple modes of contact” including text, mobile and online.

“It was more of an opportunity to really leverage that type of newer technology as it relates to cloud-based contact centers, see how can we really get rid of those standard types of calls or those types of actions that our agents would typically have to take or receive those calls. And have those handled through some kind of automated fashion through artificial intelligence (AI),” Chacko said. The agency partnered with Presidio and Amazon Web Services in late 2018 to deploy the latter’s AWS Connect; and, though the rollout is ongoing, it is already seeing benefits in how AI and machine learning can streamline communication.
additionalFields.headline: AWS Solution Helps L.A. County Address Call Wait Times

item.name: Amazon Web Services launches availability zone in Mumbai

additionalFields.Description:
Cloud platform provider Amazon Web Services (AWS) said Wednesday it is witnessing a “rapid growth” in demand from India, which has made it expand its capacity in the country.

The company, a part of e-commerce major Amazon, has recently launched third availability zone of AWS Asia Pacific (Mumbai) Region, AWS said in a statement.

“Our continued expansion of availability zones in India is a result of the strong, and growing customer momentum we are seeing in the country across customer segments,” head of business development for Amazon Internet Services, Navdeep Manaktala, said.
additionalFields.headline: Amazon Web Services launches availability zone in Mumbai

item.name: VMware Cloud on AWS now available in India

additionalFields.Description:
Global enterprise software leader VMware on Tuesday announced the availability of VMware Cloud on Amazon Web Services (AWS) in India. VMware Cloud on AWS, e-tailer Amazon’s Cloud arm, would deliver a ubiquitous digital foundation to support customers’ and partners’ digital transformation, the company said in a statement.

With the addition of the AWS Asia Pacific (Mumbai) region, VMware Cloud on AWS is now available in 14 regions globally. VMware Cloud on AWS is available in early access in India, with expected general availability by the end of May.

“We have seen a lot of interest from Indian customers for VMware Cloud on AWS to help with their digital transformation,” said Arun Parameswaran, Vice President, VMware India.
additionalFields.headline: VMware Cloud on AWS now available in India

item.name: Indian enterprises going whole hog on Cloud adoption: AWS

additionalFields.Description:
India has just started to see a significant Cloud adoption by the enterprises and the Amazon Web Services (AWS), the Cloud arm of retail giant Amazon, is fast bringing in new services and capabilities to help both the existing customer base and new customers solve all sorts of fresh problems deliver enhanced experiences, a top company executive said here on Tuesday.

The company launched AWS Asia Pacific (Mumbai) Region with two availability zones in 2016 and has seen stupendous growth in adding new customers in the region.

“Over the last few years, we have brought an ever-expanding set of capabilities to our customers in India across industries - enterprises, governments and start-ups. In areas like Machine Learning (ML), data analytics, edge computing, services and so on, there’s still so much to do and we are right on it. There are still so many new opportunities for us to help organisations leverage the power of AWS Cloud,” Ed Lenta, Managing Director, Asia Pacific, AWS, told IANS.
additionalFields.headline: Indian enterprises going whole hog on Cloud adoption: AWS

item.name: Visit of Amazon’s headquarters: the offices behind the scenes

additionalFields.Description:
Located on two floors of the “Carpe Diem” tower at La Défense, Amazon Web Services’ offices are ultra-modern, connected ... and sometimes surprising. Le Figaro visited this company which has caused a lot of ink to flow.

The pioneer in e-commerce, the cloud and even the Kindle reader, is passionate about writing. The walls of the premises of its independent subsidiary, Amazon Web Services (AWS), have many tables where employees can write, draw, count... Everything is possible, except for Power Point! The collaborators can also become artists for a day to create a work of art inside the office. In order to appropriate their new workspaces, they had to choose a totem animal and draw it.

“We had a lot of fun,” remembers Stephan Hadinger, technical manager, and Boris Lecoeur, native digital business manager. The first has chosen the legendary Snoopy, in memory of his childhood, perhaps ... The second has opted for the unicorn, in reference to the start-ups AWS supports at Station F. Finally, newcomers must submit to a painting workshop where they smear their hands in brightly colored painting in order to leave their mark on a dedicated wall. Fun activities, but all in all, traditional.
additionalFields.headline: Visit of Amazon’s headquarters: the offices behind the scenes

item.name: VMware: AWS Is Our No. 1 Cloud Partner, ‘What We’ve Built Is Incredibly Unique’

additionalFields.Description:
VMware and Amazon Web Services (AWS) took their relationship up a notch with the announcement that customers can now buy VMware Cloud on AWS directly through AWS and the cloud provider’s partner network. Previously customers could only buy the hybrid cloud service through VMware or its partners.

This also allows customers purchasing through AWS to use incentive programs like the AWS Migration Acceleration Program (MAP).

“We wanted to provide the customer that flexibility to purchase through us, or VMware, or our partners, or VMware’s partners,” said Sandy Carter, VP of enterprise workloads at AWS, adding that “demand is so great [for VMware Cloud on AWS] that we can expand the sales team.”
additionalFields.headline: VMware: AWS Is Our No. 1 Cloud Partner, ‘What We’ve Built Is Incredibly Unique’

item.name: AWS’ new EC2 i3en instances boast more power and storage

additionalFields.Description:
After launching the Amazon Elastic Compute Cloud (EC2) i3 instances around two years ago, Amazon Web Services (AWS) has made available the i3en instances, touted by the company as boasting a lower price per TB of storage and increased storage density.

In a blog post penned by AWS Chief Evangelist Jeff Barr, the company said the new offering again came in response to customer needs, with users of the i3 instances using them to host distributed file systems, relational and NoSQL databases, in-memory caches, key-value stores, data warehouses, and MapReduce clusters.
additionalFields.headline: AWS’ new EC2 i3en instances boast more power and storage

item.name: Louisiana, Amazon partner for 1st ‘AWS Educate’ cloud computing degree program at state colleges

additionalFields.Description:
Louisiana is set to become the first state to adopt an Amazon-branded cloud computing degree for its state college systems.

Starting with a two-year program at the 12 Louisiana Community and Technical Colleges, state authorities said they expect to expand it from this summer to four-year computer science degree offerings across the University of Louisiana System, as well as at the Southern University and LSU systems.

The degrees will offer a curriculum developed by Amazon Web Services called “AWS Educate”, with subjects covering areas like artificial intelligence, voice and face recognition, and gaming.
additionalFields.headline: Louisiana, Amazon partner for 1st ‘AWS Educate’ cloud computing degree program at state colleges

item.name: AWS Partners Can Now Resell VMware Cloud on AWS

additionalFields.Description:
Amazon Web Services partners can now sell the VMware Cloud on AWS hybrid cloud service directly to their enterprise customers.

VMware and Amazon Web Services launched their groundbreaking joint product more than a year ago, but until Wednesday, sales had to go through VMware or its network of channel partners.

Opening the product to AWS direct sellers, and the AWS Partner Network, makes it easier for enterprise customers to maintain buying continuity, especially those participating in the AWS Enterprise Discount Program who want the same partner of record across their cloud spend, AWS Vice President Sandy Carter told CRN.
additionalFields.headline: AWS Partners Can Now Resell VMware Cloud on AWS

item.name: AWS debuts Get IT skills programme to encourage more girls to consider a career in tech

additionalFields.Description:
Cloud computing giant Amazon Web Services is continuing to expand its portfolio of training programmes and educational initiatives, with its latest one geared towards showing young girls there is more to a career in technology than they might think.

Amazon Web Services (AWS) is expanding its efforts to close the cloud computing skills gap in the UK and Ireland with a programme aimed at inspiring more secondary school-aged girls to consider a career in technology.

The AWS Get IT Programme is specifically designed to inspire girls 12 to 13 years old, across the UK and Ireland, to develop digital skills and – in turn – set them on a course to develop capabilities in using AWS technologies.
additionalFields.headline: AWS debuts Get IT skills programme to encourage more girls to consider a career in tech

item.name: Sookmyung Women’s University is the nation’s first women’s university to introduce cloud computing courses with AWS

additionalFields.Description:
Sookmyung Women’s University is the nation’s first women’s university to introduce cloud computing courses by leveraging AWS. Thus, the educational institution and AWS has both agreed on a crucial mission to nurture female software talents.

Jung-Ae Kang, President of Sookmyung Women’s University, said, “Cloud computing is the foundation of IT technologies that drive the 4th Industrial Revolution. We believe that cloud-related education could reshape the educational environment of the university, as well as the way our students live. Therefore, we have opened the cloud computing course as a regular curriculum.”

Currently, around 100 Sookmyung Women’s University students have taken the curriculums specializing in cloud computing. President Kang also showed her ambition to help students acquire AWS certification, one of the world’s top IT-related qualifications. In 2018, nearly 60 students were trained and acquired cloud certifications. The university plans to support all students to receive the related training, regardless of their majors, by 2020.
additionalFields.headline: Sookmyung Women’s University is the nation’s first women’s university to introduce cloud computing courses with AWS

item.name: AWS to power Australia’s 2021 online census

additionalFields.Description:
Amazon Web Services (AWS) will host Australia’s next online census exercise in 2021, following a successful bid by PwC Australia and The Adecco Group to deliver a slew of services to help Australians complete the national survey.

PwC Australia will build and operate the services, including an online form and a website, on AWS, which was awarded protected certification by the Australian Cyber Security Centre in January 2019, enabling public and private sector organisations to store and process sensitive data at the protected security classification level.
additionalFields.headline: AWS to power Australia’s 2021 online census

item.name: Interview With Navdeep Manaktala, Head- Business Development, Amazon Internet Services

additionalFields.Description:
In a recent interaction, Navdeep Manaktala – Head, Business Development, Amazon Internet Services Pvt. Ltd talks about key products & services and managing large enterprise customers in India.
