That’s the scenario in Africa where data optimization becomes critical, and it is why Timothy Kotin, co-founder and chief executive officer of SuperFluid Labs Ltd, is building his company around using data analysis to help enterprise clients deliver essential services, such as energy, in his country. “Ninety percent of the data in the world was created in just the last two years,” Kotin said. “We help small businesses to unlock their potential using the power of data.”

Situated at the United States Institute of Peace, the accelerator was created to assist citizens in conflict zones and create stability. Kotin is part of an eight-week training and mentorship program supported by Amazon Web Services Inc. and C5 Capital Limited.
additionalFields.headline: Unleashing the power of data analytics for African business

item.name: Nasty, new security threats are scaring .govs to the cloud

additionalFields.Description: The profusion of nasty, new cyber threats — nation state and sponsored state attacks, etc. — is lighting a fire under the seats of public sector information technology professionals. They are beginning to move uncharacteristically fast to new, tighter security technology, and finding it — somewhat ironically — in the cloud. Even after for-profit enterprises shook their cloud-security jitters, government agencies largely remained behind. The situation is changing thanks to a number of high-profile cloud adopters setting an example for fellow public sector entities, Wood explained. The Central Intelligence Agency’s decision to move to the Amazon Web Services Inc. cloud in 2013 was a bellwether.
additionalFields.headline: Nasty, new security threats are scaring .govs to the cloud

item.name: Security an enabler for government adoption of AWS cloud

additionalFields.Description: For years, U.S. government agencies were reluctant to follow the private sector and move information technology operations to the cloud. Concerns about security, legacy data, and the potential for vendor lock-in kept the federal government firmly planted in separate data centers.That picture has changed. Today, more than 2,000 government agencies are using Amazon Web Services Inc., and there is a distinct sense of cloud momentum in the public sector. In early February, the U.S. Department of Defense awarded a $950 million cloud contract to AWS partner REAN Cloud LLC. And late last year, AWS announced a new “secret region” for the U.S. Intelligence Community that will serve government workloads across all data classifications in a cloud-based structure.
additionalFields.headline: Security an enabler for government adoption of AWS cloud

item.name: Altruistic Amazon: AWS public sector seeks to help orgs save the world

additionalFields.Description: As the public sector moves into the digital age, Amazon Web Services Inc. has become a cloud services hero, helping the government, educational facilities and non-profits innovate and save money while benefiting mankind, according to Patricia Davis-Muffett director of global public sector marketing at AWS. “One of the things that’s been amazing is the passion that our customers have for our technology. … They get a little taste of it, and they go, ‘Wow, I can’t believe what I can do that. I thought it was impossible!’” said Davis-Muffett.
additionalFields.headline: Altruistic Amazon: AWS public sector seeks to help orgs save the world

item.name: AWS makes Serverless Application Repository generally available

additionalFields.Description: It's designed for producers and consumers of serverless apps, supporting publishing, discovery and deployment. Amazon Web Services (AWS) on Wednesday announced general availability of its AWS Serverless Application Repository that enables users to find and deploy serverless applications and components. It was previously available in a public preview. The Serverless Application Repository can be accessed from the Lambda Console.
additionalFields.headline: AWS makes Serverless Application Repository generally available

item.name: Former CIO helps IT leaders navigate AWS cloud journeys

additionalFields.Description: CIOs turning to the cloud to fuel digital transformations have an ally advisor in Stephen Orban. The head of enterprise strategy at AWS knows exactly what they’re going through thanks to his cloud-first experience as CIO of Dow Jones. When Stephen Orban joined Dow Jones as CIO in 2012 he instinctively wanted to move the News Corp. subsidiary to the cloud. Orban bet on Amazon Web Services, a prescient move at a time when most of his peers were still questioning the value, viability and safety of the cloud. "I found that AWS was the biggest enabler in our ability to make that transformation that I had seen in my entire career."
additionalFields.headline: Former CIO helps IT leaders navigate AWS cloud journeys

item.name: Amazon adds encryption at rest to DynamoDB database service

additionalFields.Description: Amazon Web Services Inc. today added a new encryption feature to its DynamoDB database service in order to help better secure users’ data. DynamoDB is Amazon’s NoSQL database service, which is designed for storing and retrieving unstructured data, and is typically used for big-data workloads and analysis. With the new update, Amazon says users can choose to encrypt data stored “at rest,” that is, when it’s not being used. The option is not switched on by default, so users will have to enable it manually when creating a new database table.
additionalFields.headline: Amazon adds encryption at rest to DynamoDB database service

item.name: Amazon launches a Polly WordPress plugin that turns blog posts into audio, including podcasts

additionalFields.Description:
Amazon today is launching a new Amazon Polly WordPress plugin that gives your blog a voice by creating audio versions of your posts. The resulting audio can be played from within the blog post itself, or accessed in podcast form using a feature called Amazon Pollycast, the company says.

The plugin itself was jointly designed by Amazon’s AWS team and managed WordPress platform provider WP Engine, and takes advantage of Amazon’s text-to-speech service, Polly.
additionalFields.headline: Amazon launches a Polly WordPress plugin that turns blog posts into audio, including podcasts

item.name: Amazon’s cloud is big enough to be the fifth-largest business software company in the world

additionalFields.Description: Amazon’s cloud business has grown so quickly in the past decade that it’s now the fifth-largest business software provider in the world. Revenue at Amazon Web Services jumped 43 percent in 2017 to $17.5 billion, representing about one-tenth of Amazon’s total revenue, the company said this week. The only publicly-traded business software companies ahead of AWS are Microsoft, IBM, Oracle and SAP, according to data from FactSet.
additionalFields.headline: Amazon’s cloud is big enough to be the fifth-largest business software company in the world

item.name: Inside Amazon’s artificial intelligence flywheel

additionalFields.Description:
How deep learning came to power Alexa, Amazon Web Services, and nearly every other division of the company.

By breaking out Alexa beyond the Echo, the company’s AI culture started to coalesce. Teams across the company began to realize that Alexa could be a useful voice service for their pet projects too. “So all that data and technology comes together, even though we are very big on single-threaded ownership,” Prasad says. First other Amazon products began integrating into Alexa: When you speak into your Alexa device you can access Amazon Music, Prime Video, your personal recommendations from the main shopping website, and other services. Then the technology began hopscotching through other Amazon domains. “Once we had the foundational speech capacity, we were able to bring it to non-Alexa products like Fire TV, voice shopping, the Dash wand for Amazon fresh, and, ultimately, AWS,” Lindsay says.
additionalFields.headline: Inside Amazon’s artificial intelligence flywheel

item.name: Predictive analytics is helping Kansas City catch up on a $40 million road repair backlog

additionalFields.Description: The local government of Kansas City, Missouri, says it's expecting to generate big cost savings and cut down on a bulging backlog of street repairs thanks to its recent smart city and data analytics efforts. Through use of Amazon Web Services, new street-level connected devices, and data analytics tools from the Chicago-based software company Xaqt, the city says it could save as much as 50 percent on its emergency road repairs.  Kansas City Chief Innovation Officer Bob Bennett told StateScoop the platform from Xaqt is helping the city to get a better handle on the $3 million to $6 million the city spends on road maintenance annually in two ways — by predicting where potholes are likely to occur and by prioritizing items on its backlog.
additionalFields.headline: Predictive analytics is helping Kansas City catch up on a $40 million road repair backlog

item.name: Amazon launches autoscaling service on AWS

additionalFields.Description: One of the primary advantages of cloud computing has always been the ability to scale up to meet short-term needs and scale back when that need has been met. That has mostly meant server capacity, but over time it has been applied to other cloud services. Now, developers can configure auto scaling across a set of AWS services in a single unified interface. Companies typically use multiple AWS services to build their applications, and up until now that required some work to make sure the various pieces were scaling as the application required it. In a company blog post announcing the new feature, Amazon’s Jeff Barr explained how the new service greatly simplifies auto-scaling for developers.
additionalFields.headline: Amazon launches autoscaling service on AWS

item.name: Comcast Cable signs new cloud deal with Amazon Web Services, building on its hybrid cloud strategy

additionalFields.Description: Amazon Web Services will start out the new year with an expanded cloud commitment from Comcast Cable to deploy new applications on AWS and move some older ones. Comcast already uses AWS for cloud-based workloads across Comcast Cable and NBCUniversal, but is now expanding that relationship under the “preferred cloud provider” moniker, the companies plan to announce Tuesday.
additionalFields.headline: Comcast Cable signs new cloud deal with Amazon Web Services, building on its hybrid cloud strategy

item.name: How higher education learning gets moving in the cloud

additionalFields.Description: University of Georgia (UGA) has brought many lecture-based courses online, but lab-based physical sciences and physical education posed a challenge to the distance-learning environment. UGA did not have access to physical servers, so working with AWS gave us flexibility and a robust set of tools to support our efforts. The open, well-documented and user-friendly API, as well as the server-less architecture provided by AWS Lambda, were a perfect fit because they allowed us to build an application that runs only when needed, which mitigates overhead costs for the class.
additionalFields.headline: How higher education learning gets moving in the cloud

item.name: Amazon has quietly released a game-changer for its cloud: Linux software that runs on corporate servers

additionalFields.Description: Last month, soon after Amazon Web Service's giant tech conference, the company started offering its enterprise customers a new version of the Linux operating system it calls Linux 2. The new product marks a departure for the cloud computing juggernaut — it's software that can be installed on customers' own servers rather than run from Amazon's data centers. Amazon will rent access to Linux 2 to its cloud customers. But it's also making the software available for companies to install on their own servers.
additionalFields.headline: Amazon has quietly released a game-changer for its cloud: Linux software that runs on corporate servers

item.name: AWS showed no signs of slowing down in 2017

additionalFields.Description: AWS had a successful year by any measure. The company continued to behave like a startup with the kind of energy and momentum to invest in new areas not usually seen in an incumbent with a significant marketshare lead.
additionalFields.headline: AWS showed no signs of slowing down in 2017

item.name: Future of live sports? How Amazon streamed NFL games to 200 countries and 600 types of devices

additionalFields.Description: Last week, Amazon streamed its 10th Thursday Night Football game using tools from both Amazon Web Services and AWS Elemental. "Everything from the source, all the way through to the consumption that happens on devices for viewers, is enabled in an underlying cloud-based technology,” said Keith Wymbs, Chief Marketing Officer for AWS Elemental. “It’s utilizing Amazon Web Services and built with a full set of redundancy to deliver an experience to the end user that’s even better than broadcast.”
additionalFields.headline: Future of live sports? How Amazon streamed NFL games to 200 countries and 600 types of devices

item.name: AWS expands cloud training to high schoolers

additionalFields.Description: High school students can now join their college-aged peers in learning about and building skills related to the cloud, as part of a recent expansion of AWS Educate. In its quest to “teach tomorrow’s cloud workforce today,” AWS Educate introduces students to cloud computing and the technology fueling artificial intelligence, voice recognition, facial recognition and gaming
additionalFields.headline: AWS expands cloud training to high schoolers

item.name: AWS Secret Region ‘game changing’ for intelligence community, CIA official says

additionalFields.Description: Amazon Web Service’s newly announced Secret Region has “stunning” implications for the U.S. intelligence community, a senior CIA technology official said. With the launch of the new region, which can handle federal data up to the secret level of security classification, AWS can now securely handle workloads at all levels of data classification for federal agencies, particularly those in the intelligence community. AWS is the only commercial cloud provider to claim secure workloads at each classification level.
additionalFields.headline: AWS Secret Region ‘game changing’ for intelligence community, CIA official says

item.name: Amazon signs Time Warner’s Turner unit as cloud customer

additionalFields.Description: Reuters reporter tha Time Warner Inc's broadcast unit, Turner, has gone all-in on AWS. Turner will be migrating "decades of content" and much of its computing operations onto AWS from their on-premise data centers.
additionalFields.headline: Amazon signs Time Warner’s Turner unit as cloud customer

item.name: Amazon Sumerian lets you build VR/AR spaces in a browser—with an AI guide

additionalFields.Description: At Midnight Madness, AWS announced Amazon Sumerian, a browser-based toolkit called Sumerian intended to make virtual reality and augmented reality development accessible to everyone. Built on AWS, Sumerian allows for the creation of VR and AR scenes that target platforms like the HTC Vive, Oculus Rift, and Google Daydream. The announcement comes as the first official launch at re:Invent 2017.
additionalFields.headline: Amazon Sumerian lets you build VR/AR spaces in a browser—with an AI guide

item.name: How Andy Jassy Plans To Keep Amazon Web Services On Top Of The Cloud

additionalFields.Description: Andy Jassy sat down with Forbes' John Furrier to discuss how Amazon Web Services has grown so rapidly, while maintaining its status as the gold standard of the industry. Jassy cites rapid pace of innovation and customer focus as two factors that will keep AWS ahead for years to come.
additionalFields.headline: How Andy Jassy Plans To Keep Amazon Web Services On Top Of The Cloud

item.name: Amazon Web Services releases five new Elemental cloud tools for video publishers

additionalFields.Description: On day one of re:Invent 2017, Amazon Web Services announced five new video tools built by AWS Elemental to be made avaialble immediately. The tools are itnended to allow publishers to deliver live video and video-on-demand to mobile devices without having to invest in the equipment required to accomplish that goal on their own
additionalFields.headline: Amazon Web Services releases five new Elemental cloud tools for video publishers

item.name: AWS launches new S3 encryption and security features

additionalFields.Description: In response to customers leaving important data unprotected, Amazon Web Services released new security features for the S3 storage servoce designed to help protect customer data. The five new features include Default Encryption, Permission Checks, Cross-Region Replication ACL Overwrite, Cross-Region Replication with Key Management Service, and Detailed Inventory Report.
additionalFields.headline: AWS launches new S3 encryption and security features

item.name: AWS continues to rule the cloud infrastructure market

additionalFields.Description: After Amazon's Q3 earnings call, TechCrunch reported that AWS is still the leader in the market due to its first-mover advantage, broad portfoilo of cloud services and strong awareness among developers. John Dinsdale from Synergy Research, an analyst firm that tracks cloud market share across the different types, reports that AWS is “in a league of its own,” with control of 35 percent of the market.
additionalFields.headline: AWS continues to rule the cloud infrastructure market

item.name: AWS Propels Amazon To Another Profitable Quarter

additionalFields.Description: Following Amazon's Q3 earnings call, CRN reported that AWS continues to be a key driver in Amazon’s profitability. AWS showed steady 42% growth year over year and accrued big customer wins across the automotive, life sciences, and tech setors.
additionalFields.headline: AWS Propels Amazon To Another Profitable Quarter

item.name: AWS and Microsoft double down on deep learning with Gluon, a simplified ML model builder

additionalFields.Description: AWS and Microsoft announced a collaboration on a new deep learning interface called Gluon. The two cloud giants developed Gluon as an open source project and is aimed at prototyping, building, training and deploying machine learning models for the cloud, devices at the edge and mobile apps.
additionalFields.headline: AWS and Microsoft double down on deep learning with Gluon, a simplified ML model builder

item.name: Amazon's Jassy on Growth, the Cloud, Alexa, Strategy

additionalFields.Description: At the GeekWire Summit in Seattle, AWS CEO Andy Jassy speaks with Bloomberg's Emily Chang about the growth of the company, competition, the rise of the cloud, his concerns over government requests for cloud data, the benefits of Alexa and his strategy for growth.
additionalFields.headline: Amazon's Jassy on Growth, the Cloud, Alexa, Strategy

item.name: Amazon Web Services shakes up cloud pricing with per-second billing

additionalFields.Description: AWS announced a new pricing structure that allows users of EC2 and EBS services to pay by the second. Previously, AWS offered per-hour billing. In a blog post, AWS chief evangelist, Jeff Barr, said, “Some of our more sophisticated customers have built systems to get the most value from EC2 by strategically choosing the most advantageous target instances when managing their gaming, ad tech, or 3D rendering fleets. Per-second billing obviates the need for this extra layer of instance management, and brings the costs savings to all customers and all workloads.”
additionalFields.headline: Amazon Web Services shakes up cloud pricing with per-second billing

item.name: Amazon makes elastic GPUs generally available

additionalFields.Description: On Wednesday, AWS announced the availability of Amazon EC2 Elastic GPUs for Windows. AWS’s Senior Technical Evangelist Randall Hunt described the offering in a blog post: "You can use Elastic GPUs with many instance types allowing you the flexibility to choose the right compute, memory, and storage balance for your application.”
additionalFields.headline: Amazon makes elastic GPUs generally available

item.name: VMware Cloud is now live on AWS — and IT pros just did a little happy dance

additionalFields.Description: At VMworld on Monday, it was announced that the hybrid-cloud product from VMware and AWS’s partnership is now generally available. VMware Cloud on AWS will reduce management problems by allowing companies moving to AWS to continue to run their VMware VMs in the public cloud. AWS CEO Jassy described the partnership: “The majority of the world’s enterprises have virtualized their data centers with VMware, and now these customers can easily move applications between their on-premises environments and AWS without having to purchase any new hardware, rewrite their applications, or modify their operations.”
additionalFields.headline: VMware Cloud is now live on AWS — and IT pros just did a little happy dance

item.name: AWS infrastructure is now behind three main streaming media providers

additionalFields.Description: AWS announced at AWS Summit New York it is now an infrastructure provider for streaming service Hulu. According to Hulu software development VP Rafael Soltanovich, AWS will provide key services and applications for Hulu’s new over-the-top (OTT) live TV service. Hulu joins the growing list of media services that choose AWS for their infrastructure.
additionalFields.headline: AWS infrastructure is now behind three main streaming media providers

item.name: AWS launches data security service called Macie with machine learning

additionalFields.Description: At the AWS Summit New York, AWS announced Amazon Macie, a managed security service that utilizes machine learning to identify, classify, and protect data across the cloud services. The system will initially support S3, but will be available for other data storage options in the future. Autodesk, Edmunds, and Netflix were cited as initial Macie customers in the keynote.
additionalFields.headline: AWS launches data security service called Macie with machine learning

item.name: AWS Introduces Intelligent Security And Integrated Cloud Migration Capabilities At New York Summit

additionalFields.Description: AWS announced on Monday the release of a number of new products and services, including ETL, AWS Glue, Migration Hub, and Amazon Macie. Macie, as described during the Summit keynote by Matt Wood, General Manager for AI, AWS, discovers threats and safeguards customer data using machine learning algorithms.
additionalFields.headline: AWS Introduces Intelligent Security And Integrated Cloud Migration Capabilities At New York Summit

item.name: AWS won’t be ceding its massive market share lead anytime soon

additionalFields.Description: The announcement of Amazon’s quarterly earnings showcased how profitable AWS was for the company. Despite steady growth for other major cloud players, AWS is still more than three times larger than any competitors.
additionalFields.headline: AWS won’t be ceding its massive market share lead anytime soon

item.name: The 52 most powerful people in enterprise tech in 2017

additionalFields.Description: Andy Jassy, CEO of AWS, was named the most powerful person in enterprise tech in 2017, according to a list compiled by Business Insider. The list highlights the 52 people currently shaping the multi-trillion dollar enterprise tech industry. Additionally, Werner Vogels, CTO of Amazon.com, ranked ninth on the list.
additionalFields.headline: The 52 most powerful people in enterprise tech in 2017

item.name: Amazon Inspire educational site opens to all schools, applying lessons learned in year-long beta

additionalFields.Description: Amazon Inspire, a site that offers a database of educational and classroom resources, is the latest in a number of Amazon offerings for the education community. Inspire is hosted on AWS, which is used by more than 5,000 educational customers for cloud storage and provides students and educators with access to free content, training, collaboration portals. Additionally, free access to AWS services is offered through its grant-based AWS Educate program.
additionalFields.headline: Amazon Inspire educational site opens to all schools, applying lessons learned in year-long beta

item.name: Amazon’s new GPU-powered service aims at VR, 3D video and remote workstations

additionalFields.Description: Last week, AWS launched G3, a new family of high performance GPU instances designed for 3D rendering, 3D visualizations, graphics-intensive remote workstations, video encoding, and virtual reality applications. Matt Garman, Vice President of Amazon EC2, says “Customers have told us that having the ability to choose the right instance for the right workload enables them to operate more efficiently and go to market faster, which is why we continue to innovate to better support any workload.”
additionalFields.headline: Amazon’s new GPU-powered service aims at VR, 3D video and remote workstations

item.name: Kelley Blue Book turns to AWS for AI to power its new chatbot

additionalFields.Description: Kelley Blue Book announced at VentureBeat’s MobileBeat Conference that they will leverage Amazon Lex and Amazon Polly to create a chatbot that helps customers understand how much their car is worth. AWS’s Swami Sivasubramanian, Vice President of AI, introduced the chatbot, which understands voice and text, as an example of what AWS customers are doing with its AI services.
additionalFields.headline: Kelley Blue Book turns to AWS for AI to power its new chatbot

item.name: AWS Launches Greengrass Software, Giving Parters A Way To Boost Edge Computing In IoT Devices

additionalFields.Description: On Wednesday, AWS announced the general availability of AWS Greengrass, which allows customers to run AWS compute, messaging, data caching, and sync capabilities on connected devices. AWS’s Dirk Didascalou, Vice President of IoT, states that “By embedding AWS Lambda and AWS IoT capabilities in connected devices, AWS Greengrass gives customers the flexibility to have devices act locally on the data they generate while using the AWS Cloud for management, analytics, and storage – all using a single, familiar AWS programming model.” AWS partners Qualcomm, Intel, Samsung, and Lenovo are just a few of the companies bringing AWS Greengrass to connected devices.
additionalFields.headline: AWS Launches Greengrass Software, Giving Parters A Way To Boost Edge Computing In IoT Devices

item.name: OakNorth and AWS: building the UK’s first cloud-based bank

additionalFields.Description: OakNorth Bank became the UK's first cloud-based bank by migrating to the AWS Cloud. Francesca Gandolfo, COO of OakNorth, says the bank chose AWS because, "We really wanted to have a global player that could leverage across all our geography, and bring us all the benefits of scale and scope that we could not afford being a start-up."
additionalFields.headline: OakNorth and AWS: building the UK’s first cloud-based bank

item.name: The Best Way To Transmit Satellite Data? In Trucks. Really

additionalFields.Description: DigitalGlobe, one of the world’s leading providers of high-resolution Earth imagery, data and analysis, is using AWS Snowmobile to move 100 petabytes of data to the cloud. On May 9th, DigitalGlobe’s Snowmobile left the Colorado office en route to one of AWS’s datacenters. As DigitalGlobe’s migrates image archives into the AWS Cloud, algorithms will be able to better categorize and classify the data for the use of third-party entities such as government officials, conservationists, and journalists. The company’s decision to use AWS Snowmobile was driven by its desire to deliver all of its data to customers in the shortest amount of time after realizing its internal library was limiting this possibility.
additionalFields.headline: The Best Way To Transmit Satellite Data? In Trucks. Really

item.name: U.S. Census Collaboration to Leverage Data's Societal Problem-Solving Utility

additionalFields.Description: The U.S. Census Bureau and data.world launched a new AWS Public Dataset with the goal to integrate and streamline data from the yearly American Community Survey (ACS). Jeff Meisel, Chief Marketing Officer for the U.S. Census Bureau, says AWS now hosts the complete data set, including individual strands of datasets from income to health insurance. Meisel says, “A data scientist can now go to the cloud and they can spin up their own [Amazon] Elastic Compute Cloud instance and begin building replicas to work on their research in the cloud.”
additionalFields.headline: U.S. Census Collaboration to Leverage Data's Societal Problem-Solving Utility

item.name: Red Hat and Amazon integrate AWS, RHEL, and OpenShift

additionalFields.Description: As part of an extended strategic alliance between Red Hat and AWS, Red Hat announced that it will natively package access to a large number of AWS services within Red Hat OpenShift. Jim Whitehurst, Red Hat's CEO, explained in the press release, “Container adoption is taking off in the enterprise, and this alliance is designed to accelerate that by giving customers access to AWS services directly within Red Hat OpenShift Container Platform. By bringing together the incredible pace of innovation and breadth of functionality that AWS provides with the industry's most comprehensive enterprise-grade container platform, we're enabling customers to bring the combined advantages of these offerings across their hybrid environments with the backing of our joint support.”
additionalFields.headline: Red Hat and Amazon integrate AWS, RHEL, and OpenShift

item.name: AWS: The new neighborhood architect for Nextdoor.com

additionalFields.Description: Nextdoor.com, a social network for neighborhoods and communities, spoke at AWS Summit San Francisco about how AWS is supporting its growing online communities. The flexibility, scalability, and agility of AWS allows Nextdoor to focus on its business without the burden of managing its own infrastructure. Prakash Janakiraman, co-founder and chief architect of Nextdoor says, “We started out on EC2 and S3, and over time, as we fast forward to today, we’re using almost 30 different AWS services, including DynamoDB, ECS, Redshift, Kinesis. And so all of these components fit together in running our business.”
additionalFields.headline: AWS: The new neighborhood architect for Nextdoor.com

item.name: How Amazon Web Services Ushered Major League Baseball into the Digital Age with Scalable, Cloud-Based Infrastructure

additionalFields.Description: Major League Baseball (MLB) knew it was sitting on a goldmine of data its fans were sure to love, but the organization needed a way to harness and broadcast that information. The company’s digital arm, Major League Baseball Advanced Media (MLBAM), created Statcast to harness that data in interesting ways for its customer and quickly found that AWS was the right tool—from a financial and data storage standpoint—to develop it on.  Joe Inzerillo, CTO for MLBAM says, “At MLB, we are very committed to the fan and getting that fan what they want and when they want it,” Joe said. “To do that, we need next-generation technology and we need partners that know how to innovate. When we looked at who was going to help us power Statcast, there was only one real clear choice. It had to be AWS.”
additionalFields.headline: How Amazon Web Services Ushered Major League Baseball into the Digital Age with Scalable, Cloud-Based Infrastructure

item.name: Amazon blazes a trail to the next frontier in AI: the cloud

additionalFields.Description: At the AWS Summit San Francisco, SiliconANGLE spoke to Swami Sivasubramanian, Vice President of Machine Learning at AWS about the range of work AWS is doing in machine learning and AI through Amazon Lex, Amazon Polly, and Amazon Rekognition. When asked what AWS plans to do with AI, Sivasubramanian explains, “We want to enable building new kinds of intelligent applications that can actually do things that humans have been able to do, like being able to see or hear or speak or understand. And we enable businesses and enterprises to make intelligent decisions on top of the data that they have stored in AWS.”
additionalFields.headline: Amazon blazes a trail to the next frontier in AI: the cloud

item.name: HERE Puts Eggs In AWS Basket To Expand Connected Car Services

additionalFields.Description: HERE Technologies (HERE), a leading global provider of maps and location services, named AWS as its preferred cloud infrastructure provider.  Already an AWS customer for several years, HERE will be building its newest business extensions on AWS that will allow the company to collect and use real-time sensor data from connected vehicles. Angel L. Mendez, Chief Operating Officer at HERE says, “We started using AWS’s storage and compute services for our production workloads several years ago and quickly came to rely on the unmatched security, reliability, performance, breadth, and scalability that AWS provides to us and to our own end customers. As we continue to expand the reach of our Open Location Platform and enable global access to the world’s leading mapping and location services for consumers and businesses, building on the leading cloud provider with the broadest and deepest capabilities is key to our development and global expansion.”
additionalFields.headline: HERE Puts Eggs In AWS Basket To Expand Connected Car Services

item.name: Dunkin’ runs on AWS

additionalFields.Description: Dunkin' Brands Group, Inc., the parent company of Dunkin’ Donuts and Baskin-Robbins, has selected AWS as its cloud infrastructure provider  . AWS will support Dunkin’ Brand’s mobile applications, loyalty reward program, e-commerce websites, and other critical corporate IT infrastructure applications. In a press release, the company says, “While Dunkin’ Brands had previously found it increasingly difficult to predict and manage the on-premises capacity needed to provide an optimal digital experience for its guests during these times, it now relies on AWS to easily and reliably scale up and down as needed.  In addition, Dunkin’ Brands has also migrated internal corporate IT infrastructure applications to AWS to reduce costs and increase availability.”
additionalFields.headline: Dunkin’ runs on AWS

item.name: The Secret Ingredients NASA Used to Builds Its Huge Photo Library

additionalFields.Description: NASA announced the public is now able to access their online content featuring more than 140,000 images, audio files, and videos after the migration of the content platform to AWS. The NASA Image and Video Library is now housed at Images.Nasa.gov, and marks the progress in NASA’s mission of making its data more publically accessible. “What we attempted to do here was put the best of the best from 60 collections NASA had into one place,” said Rodney Grubbs, NASA imagery expert program manager. “Up until now, we haven’t had one single location on the web where you could search across that wide a gamut of content.”
additionalFields.headline: The Secret Ingredients NASA Used to Builds Its Huge Photo Library

item.name: Blackboard brings learning to the AWS GovCloud

additionalFields.Description: Blackboard, the learning management system provider, announced its Blackboard Learn platform is now available for federal agencies the military, and state and local governments on AWS GovCloud (US). Helen Remily, capability manager of the Army Training and Doctrine Command’s Distributed Learning Program explains, "Having the ability to deploy this invaluable capability on the FedRAMP-certified AWS GovCloud gives us the added confidence that our most sensitive data is safe and secure at all times.”
additionalFields.headline: Blackboard brings learning to the AWS GovCloud

item.name: Amazon Web Services plays role in NASA’s first ultra-HD live video from space

additionalFields.Description: NASA astronaut, Dr. Peggy Whitson will be featured in the highest-resolution video ever broadcasted live from the International Space Station supported by AWS technology. The 4L ultra-high-definition livestream will use a UHD-capable video encoder from AWS Elemental and this event comes during the 2017 National Association of Broadcasters Show in Las Vegas. Whitson will be speaking with Sam Blackman, CEO and co-founder of AWS Elemental to demonstrate how cloud and imaging technologies are supporting new scientific research.
additionalFields.headline: Amazon Web Services plays role in NASA’s first ultra-HD live video from space

item.name: Amazon Web Services to open data centers in Sweden in 2018, continuing global growth

additionalFields.Description: AWS announced plans to open an infrastructure Region composed of three Availability Zones in Sweden in 2018 to serve customers in the Nordic countries. AWS currently provides 42 Availability Zones across 16 infrastructure regions worldwide, with another five Availability Zones expected to be launched  throughout 2017 and 2018. AWS CEO, Andy Jassy said, “An AWS Region in Stockholm enables Swedish and Nordic customers, with local latency or data sovereignty requirements, to move the rest of their applications to AWS and enjoy cost and agility advantages across their entire application portfolio.”
additionalFields.headline: Amazon Web Services to open data centers in Sweden in 2018, continuing global growth

item.name: Visy embraces Amazon Web Services

additionalFields.Description: Visy Industries, one of the world's largest privately owned packaging and resource recovery companies, is moving a majority of its workloads to the AWS Cloud. The Melbourne, Australia-based company made this decision in order to focus on its core IT functions and remove the burden of hosting their own infrastructure. Visy’s Chief Information Officer, David Peano, hopes that the business can focus on new strategic initiatives by capitalizing on emerging trends in technology such as data analytics, machine learning and IoT.
additionalFields.headline: Visy embraces Amazon Web Services

item.name: More AWS services get FedRAMP High authorization

additionalFields.Description: AWS announced additional services that have received Federal Risk and Authorization Management Program (FedRAMP) High authorizations.  Amazon Glacier, Amazon DynamoDB and Amazon Redshift were among the services issued Provisional Authority to Operate (P-ATO) and are now available on AWS GovCloud (US). These authorizations continue to allow customers to process and store critical workloads with sensitive data on the AWS Cloud.
additionalFields.headline: More AWS services get FedRAMP High authorization

item.name: Creating the Cloud Learning Platform of the Future

additionalFields.Description: The University of Maryland University College (UMUC) chose AWS for building a virtual learning environment for their 95,000 students across the globe.  UMUC chose Amazon WorkSpaces because it allows easy provisioning of cloud-based virtual desktops and remote access. AWS has helped UMUC scale in response to a 4x increase in traffic and has saved them 40% on development costs alone.
additionalFields.headline: Creating the Cloud Learning Platform of the Future

item.name: AHA Launches Cardiac Precision Medicine Data Platform

additionalFields.Description: The American Heart Association’s (AHA) Precision Medicine Platform will allow researchers and physicians unprecedented access to volumes of medical data from cardiovascular events and stroke patients. AHA developed the Platform on the AWS Cloud with the goal of securely sharing the massive collections of data within medical communities to provide more comprehensive research and educational material for treating cardiovascular diseases. Jennifer Hall, Ph.D., the AHA’s Chief of the Institute for Precision Cardiovascular Medicine said, “The platform provides an opportunity to learn, search and discover in new and efficient ways, and we will keep working with the community to weave in new diverse data to help us drill deeper and enrich our understanding.”
additionalFields.headline: AHA Launches Cardiac Precision Medicine Data Platform

item.name: How Pernod Ricard Uses Amazon Web Services to Coordinate International Marketing Efforts

additionalFields.Description: As Pernod Ricard went through a technology overhaul, the spirits and wine company chose the AWS Cloud for the responsiveness, security and scalability benefits of AWS Lambda. Pete McVicar, Head of IT Marketing and Sales Solutions, explained how the company needed to respond to global demands for mobile content and spiking online traffic from marketing campaigns that were not supported by their outdated platform. With AWS Lambda, the company was able to fulfill a successful international social media competition for St. Patrick’s Day 2017 and continues to respond to constantly changing market demands.
additionalFields.headline: How Pernod Ricard Uses Amazon Web Services to Coordinate International Marketing Efforts

item.name: The Cloud Is Making It Easier for States and Localities to Issue Alerts in Seconds

additionalFields.Description: The Federation for Internet Alerts (FIA) is using the AWS Cloud to help save lives by issuing hundreds of millions of alerts – from child abductions to tornado warnings – benefiting from AWS’ global scale, security, and the ability to rapidly deploy when every second matters. FIA has been able to deliver more than 800 million AMBER Alert impressions during 794 abductions because of the scalability of AWS. FIA plans to expand its partner program worldwide and to do so with the AWS Cloud.
additionalFields.headline: The Cloud Is Making It Easier for States and Localities to Issue Alerts in Seconds

item.name: Amazon Web Services starts offering free cloud storage and computing for Alexa skills

additionalFields.Description: Amazon announced it will offer $100 Amazon Web Services (AWS) credit to Alexa skills developers. All developers have to do is apply. The AWS Free Tier already offers one million AWS Lambda requests and up to 750 hours of Amazon EC2 compute time per month, but now third-party developers who exceed these limits will receive $100 in promotional credit with up to an additional $100/month. Since 2015, third-party developers are responsible for the development of over 10,000 Alexa skills.
additionalFields.headline: Amazon Web Services starts offering free cloud storage and computing for Alexa skills

item.name: AWS to Support Govt Service Modernization Efforts in Chile, Honduras

additionalFields.Description: With the support of AWS, Chile and Honduras are making efforts to modernize government services by initiating cloud-first government priorities in Latin America.  AWS will provide support to Honduras and Chile’s open data efforts and updates to internal systems to provide more transparent and efficient operations. Within these countries, AWS will also collaborate with public and private universities through the AWS Educate Program and will facilitate workshops, training, and other educational efforts for local technology startups to foster and encourage innovation.
additionalFields.headline: AWS to Support Govt Service Modernization Efforts in Chile, Honduras

item.name: How Brisbane security startup FunCaptcha got in front of Electronic Arts and Facebook

additionalFields.Description: FunCaptcha, a security startup in Brisbane, Australia, chose the AWS Cloud platform to build and deliver their website and services because of the scalability and responsiveness it provides as they grow their customer base. Kevin Gosschalk, Founder of FunCaptcha, says that the scalability of the AWS Cloud was “absolutely pivotal to our success, because Australian companies couldn’t have built that kind of infrastructure 10 years ago. But we now have customers in pretty much every country you can think of, and we can service them all really easily with a core developer team based in Brisbane, Australia.”
additionalFields.headline: How Brisbane security startup FunCaptcha got in front of Electronic Arts and Facebook

item.name: Crunching half a petabyte on AWS: Victoria's Dept of Environment taps Bulletproof

additionalFields.Description: The Department of Environment, Land, Water and Planning (DELWP) for Victoria, Australia turned to Bulletproof, an AWS Premier Consulting Partner in Australia/New Zealand, to find a AWS Cloud solution to support their expanding data infrastructure. The migration to the AWS Cloud reduced the time to retrieve archived data from 3 weeks to less than 12 hours. According to Bulletproof, “The entire architecture is purposefully event-driven. Using a combination of event sources including Amazon S3, AWS Lambda, Amazon API Gateway and Amazon SQS events, the system is able to scale. Components are decoupled ensuring flexibility for future requirements.”
additionalFields.headline: Crunching half a petabyte on AWS: Victoria's Dept of Environment taps Bulletproof

item.name: School districts get chance to compete in Amazon Web Services challenge

additionalFields.Description: AWS has expanded its fourth City on a Cloud Innovation Challenge, now allowing school districts for a chance to submit applications. The City on a Cloud Innovation Challenge recognizes local and regional governments, and private and public schools and districts as hubs of innovation. John Stephenson, Senior Manager of Public Policy at AWS notes that, “Since providing K-12 education services is one of the most important missions many state and local governments own, adding school districts was a natural evolution for the City on a Cloud Innovation Challenge for 2017. We know from our existing K-12 customers that some incredibly innovative uses of the cloud are already transforming the classroom. We wanted to give both these existing customers and new customers in the state, local, and education spaces the opportunity to explore and showcase how the cloud can empower teachers, administrators and other educators.”  Schools can apply here and the entry period ends May 12 for all participants.
additionalFields.headline: School districts get chance to compete in Amazon Web Services challenge

item.name: Missguided overcomes flexibility issues with AWS

additionalFields.Description: Missguided, a global multi-channel fashion brand, migrated 170 servers to the AWS Cloud to improve scalability after dealing with peaks in traffic surrounding marketing campaigns and social media collaborations. John Allen, CTO of Missguided wanted a cloud provider that could provide a high degree of growth at an economy scale. Allen stated, “Very quickly we got down to what the two best options for the PHP/Magento environment and AWS was one frequently referenced as not just a suitable platform, but an ideal one. It was clear that they were massively bigger than anybody else in the market.”
additionalFields.headline: Missguided overcomes flexibility issues with AWS

item.name: ASX takes major application to AWS Lambda

additionalFields.Description: The Australian Securities Exchange (ASX) has re-engineered their margin optimization application to run in AWS Lambda to fix performance issues and improve operational efficiency. The ASX has used AWS Lambda to maximize the efficiency of its margin optimization platform which is a key element of the ‘clearing house’ function of the ASX’s multi-billion dollar daily operations. ASX’s general manager of Application Development and DevOps, Katherine Squire is leading a new culture of ‘experimentation’ around IT and has seen positive results from these initiatives. Squire claims, “The margin optimiser application is so well suited to cloud because it’s computationally intensive, and very bursty.” Squire said, “I think we are now working within a safe, trusting environment where we all just work in a better way.”
additionalFields.headline: ASX takes major application to AWS Lambda

item.name: Amazon partners with state for new cybersecurity education pipeline

additionalFields.Description: Governor Terry McAuliffe announced details for a new strategic relationship between the Virginia Cyber Range and AWS to expand cybersecurity education. AWS will provide a scalable cloud infrastructure and is joining forces with the Commonwealth of Virginia and Virginia Tech in developing cybersecurity education. Gov. McAuliffe explains, “Creation of the Cyber Range is just one example of the steps that the Commonwealth of Virginia is taking to position the state as a leader in cybersecurity. In Virginia and across the country, businesses, governments, and private individuals are impacted by the growing threat of cyber-attacks. We need a capable workforce that understands these swiftly changing threats and is ready to mount an agile defense against them.”
additionalFields.headline: Amazon partners with state for new cybersecurity education pipeline

item.name: The Untapped Potential of the Hyperscale Cloud

additionalFields.Description: The Defense Department is making moves to the AWS Ccloud following the advantages seen by fellow public sector success stories such fromas The Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services and the National Geospatial-Intelligence Agency. The Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services turned to the cloudAWS for the scalability needed to meet demands for the traffic to Healthcare.gov and were able to prevent repeating failures caused by the initial traffic spikes. The scalability, speed, power and breadth of functionality of the AWS Cloud has the potential for significant positive changes for the Defense Department as well. Lt. Gen. Samuel Greaves, Air Force space and missile systems center commander, claims the Amazon Web ServicesAWS’ testing environment, “let them buy a lot of schedule back,” for the next-generation GPS operational control segment program that was close to being terminated due to scheduling overruns.
additionalFields.headline: The Untapped Potential of the Hyperscale Cloud

item.name: Mithi’s journey to the Cloud

additionalFields.Description: Mithi Software Technologies, an India-based provider of email, team communication and archiving solutions, recently began the migration to the AWS Cloud after facing complications with data management decisions and numerous compromises associated with traditional data centers. Co-founder and CTO of Mithi says, “Moving to AWS has enabled Mithi to innovate faster, bringing newer and better offerings to its customers…The greater flexibility, reduced capital costs, improved security, dependability and faster upgrades that AWS offers is a welcome change.”
additionalFields.headline: Mithi’s journey to the Cloud

item.name: How Nintendo taught EB Games to get the most out of AWS

additionalFields.Description: EB Games, Australia’s largest video game retailer, was having trouble scaling because of its own success in the online retail world. As EB’s online store grew 250%, peak traffic increased up to 700%, creating long loading times for customers. To improve agility and responsiveness, EB began the process of migrating to the AWS Cloud to manage fluctuations in traffic. EB Games senior technology manager Kevin Clarke says, “We found that we actually saved in operational costs while increasing performance. We've taken cost efficiencies from an operational/depreciation cost and can now actively look for how we can drive more efficiencies.”
additionalFields.headline: How Nintendo taught EB Games to get the most out of AWS

item.name: Why veterans can fill your company’s tech skills gap

additionalFields.Description: Amazon recently announced an apprenticeship program with the Department of Labor to hire and train 25,000 veterans and military spouses. 10,000 or more will be trained as AWS cloud support associates. Ardine Williams, vice president of talent acquisition for AWS, says, “Veterans provide an attractive candidate pool for fast-paced, innovative companies like Amazon, and tech roles offer both a competitive wage and, even more important, a career path.” Amazon joins a coalition of over 160 companies addressing the veteran workforce and tech skills gaps.
additionalFields.headline: Why veterans can fill your company’s tech skills gap

item.name: For Those About to Rock, Ticketmaster Migrates Infrastructure to AWS

additionalFields.Description: Ticketmaster parent Live Nation Entertainment Inc., the world's leading live entertainment and ticketing company, announced they are migrating their global IT infrastructure to the cloud. The company will use AWS Lambda, Amazon RDS, Amazon Aurora, and Amazon S3 to simplify management of large-scale databases and for storage of logs and static content.  Jody Mulkey, Chief Technology Officer at Ticketmaster, says “The benefit is agility;” the cloud allows Live Nation to scale computing capacity when the company projects high traffic for ticket release dates.
additionalFields.headline: For Those About to Rock, Ticketmaster Migrates Infrastructure to AWS

item.name: How Philips is turning toothbrushes and MRI machines into IoT devices

additionalFields.Description: Philips is inventing  new ways to provide its customers access to more data to improve patient health and machine productivity.  The company is developing IoT connected toothbrushes and MRI machines that collect data and send it to the AWS Cloud for analysis.  These IoT connected devices provide reduced maintenance costs and a more in-depth picture of patient’s health records. Dale Wiggins, VP and General Manager of the Philips HealthSuite Digital Platform says, “We’re transforming from mainly a device-focused business to a health technology company focused on the health continuum of care and service.”
additionalFields.headline: How Philips is turning toothbrushes and MRI machines into IoT devices

item.name: The man with millions of jobs that need doing

additionalFields.Description: Matt Barrie, a Sydney-based entrepreneur and founder of the website Freelancer, is changing the way people are connecting to the global job market. Freelancer was designed to connect those looking for talent and those with the appropriate qualifications regardless of location.  After 8 years, Freelancer now has 22.5 million users globally, and is based entirely on Amazon Web Services.
additionalFields.headline: The man with millions of jobs that need doing

item.name: Securing IoT devices from within

additionalFields.Description: To eliminate the process of preregistering devices and generating encryption keys for organizations with thousands of IoT-enabled devices, Microchip Technology Inc. and AWS have developed a hardware solution providing built-in end-to-end security connecting devices to the cloud. Eustace Asanghanwa, strategic marketing manager for Microchip Technology says, “If you consider not just hardware but also implementation, such as the capital and operational costs of securely injecting keys and managing them in a supply chain, the AWS-ECC508 actually creates a significant cost-reduction for any given product.”
additionalFields.headline: Securing IoT devices from within

item.name: Dutch businesses have heads in the cloud

additionalFields.Description: From larger multinationals to startups, the Netherlands is experiencing a migration of businesses to the cloud. One Dutch company, Aviko, an internal potato processor, was new to Chinese markets and was facing challenges creating a connection to the company’s existing enterprise resource planning (ERP) system. The presence of AWS in China allowed the SAP installation into the cloud to go live in three weeks after months of stagnation. Aviko has additional plans for Chinese markets and will continue to expand with the help of the AWS Cloud.
additionalFields.headline: Dutch businesses have heads in the cloud

item.name: Cloud.gov clears FedRAMP

additionalFields.Description: The General Services Administration (GSA)-run Cloud.gov has achieved Federal Risk and Authorization Management Program (FedRAMP) authorization. Cloud.gov, which runs on AWS GovCloud (US), is a platform-as-a-service designed to help government agencies improve their IT management. It is the first fully open-sourced service to attain FedRAMP authorization. With this final stage complete, agencies can start using Cloud.gov in production with less upfront work, and the ability to deliver services faster.
additionalFields.headline: Cloud.gov clears FedRAMP

item.name: LendingRobot launches hedge fund that uses blockchain and machine learning — with no human intervention

additionalFields.Description: LendingRobot is an automated online investment-management service that is eliminating the need for human intervention in the investment-management process.  The company is launching a hedge fund that will use Amazon Web Services’ machine learning, compute servers, and blockchain technology to ease the complexity and increase efficiency of evaluating investments. AWS's machine learning will help sift through and score the individual person-to-person loans offered to investors and identify the best investments. CEO Emmanuel Marot says that "When demand requires it, AWS servers scale up quickly to run thousands of attribute assessments around those times, then scale back down to a much lower baseline level."
additionalFields.headline: LendingRobot launches hedge fund that uses blockchain and machine learning — with no human intervention

item.name: AWS Details FPGA Rationale and Market Trajectory

additionalFields.Description: At the end of 2016, Amazon Web Services announced it would be making high-end Xilinx FPGAs available via a cloud delivery model, beginning first in a developer preview mode before branching out with higher-level tools to help potential new users onboard and experiment with FPGA acceleration as the year rolls on. Deepak Singh, General Manager for the Container and HPC division within AWS discusses general purpose vs. specialized computing, and AWS’s FPGA offering in this article.
additionalFields.headline: AWS Details FPGA Rationale and Market Trajectory

item.name: ASG takes project services firm Clough to Amazon Web Services

additionalFields.Description: Western Australian mining services company Clough has gone all-in with AWS, including running Amazon WorkSpaces, to drive efficiency, reduce cost, and improve agility. Supported by AWS Partner, ASG, Clough was able to “reduce its IT capital by 70 percent, operational costs by 50 percent and server costs by 33 percent,” in addition to dramatically improving the timeline for deploying IT services to its employees.
additionalFields.headline: ASG takes project services firm Clough to Amazon Web Services

item.name: Enel Moves Onto Amazon To Implement New Utility Strategy

additionalFields.Description: Enel, an Italian electricity producer and supplier that serves a total of 62 million customers, is embracing the cloud. The move to the AWS Cloud was motivated by the need to support Enel’s Open Power strategy around the world and other green power source initiatives.  Its journey to the cloud has enabled the company to bring a new approach to serving both traditional and new customers in new ways. Enel’s head of technology services, Fabio Veronese, said in an interview, “AWS provides us with an environment where these projects will flourish. We want to foster creation of a platform where our energy management systems can grow and interact with each other. The idea is to provide an environment that makes us learn quickly."
additionalFields.headline: Enel Moves Onto Amazon To Implement New Utility Strategy

item.name: AWS moves into IT training and job placement with re:Start, a UK cloud skills program

additionalFields.Description: This week, AWS announced the launch of AWS re:Start, a UK-based cloud skills program that provides IT skills training, specifically in cloud computing, and job placement for young adults and military vets and their spouses. This program was developed through a partnership with AWS and the UK’s Ministry of Defense, the Prince’s Trust, and QA Consulting. Karen Bradley, UK Secretary of State for Culture, Media, and Sport says that, “[i]ncreasing digital skills in the UK is a major priority for the Government and we are working to make sure that everyone has the skills they need.”
additionalFields.headline: AWS moves into IT training and job placement with re:Start, a UK cloud skills program

item.name: Three AWS services get FedRAMP High approval

additionalFields.Description: On January 6, the Joint Authorization Board (JAB) approved three additional AWS services in the AWS GovCloud (US) Region (Amazon RDS, Amazon CloudWatch Logs, and AWS CloudTrail) for Provisional Authority to Operate (P-ATO) for the Federal Risk and Authorization Management Program (FedRAMP) High baseline. This approval gives US government agencies the ability to use these services for highly sensitive data, including Personal Identifiable Information (PII), Protected Health Information (PHI), Controlled Unclassified Information (CUI), criminal justice information (CJI), and financial data in AWS GovCloud (US).
additionalFields.headline: Three AWS services get FedRAMP High approval

item.name: This company is using Amazon Snowmobile to transfer petabytes of data to the cloud

additionalFields.Description: DigitalGlobe (DGI) is using AWS Snowmobile to move petabytes of data from their data centers to the AWS Cloud. Since 1992, DGI has been accumulating over 100 petabytes of data from their satellites to create a geospatial big data platform named GBDX. After years of building their own IT infrastructure to manage the data, DGI decided to embrace the cloud. AWS Snowmobile has enabled the company to cut years off the timeline for migrating all of that data.
additionalFields.headline: This company is using Amazon Snowmobile to transfer petabytes of data to the cloud

item.name: AWS opens its first UK region in London

additionalFields.Description: The AWS Europe (London) Region is now available to customers. The AWS Europe (London) Region is AWS’s third European Region, joining existing regions in Ireland and Germany and consists of two Availability Zones. With this launch, AWS now provides 42 Availability Zones across 16 technology regions globally.
additionalFields.headline: AWS opens its first UK region in London

item.name: Amazon Web Services expands with its first Canadian region

additionalFields.Description: The AWS Canada (Central) Region is now available to customers. The new region is AWS's sixth in North America and consists of two Availability Zones, bringing AWS up to 40 AZs across 15 infrastructure regions worldwide. The new AWS Canada (Central) Region continues the company’s focus on delivering cloud technologies to customers in an environmentally friendly way. AWS data centers in Canada will draw from a regional electricity grid that is 99 percent powered by hydropower.
additionalFields.headline: Amazon Web Services expands with its first Canadian region

item.name: Qantas flying high with cloud-based innovation: AWS

additionalFields.Description: Qantas Airlines came to AWS to run a compute-heavy algorithm that would determine the best route to fly from Sydney to Dallas, TX. Running the analysis on AWS reduced compute time from four months to four hours. Since then, Qantas has begun to move its online boking site to AWS, resulting in real-time booking processing times and increasing the data processing time by 100x and reducing the amount of code needed by 90 percent. Overall, Qantas reports that moving to the AWS Cloud will save the company AU$30 million over five years.
additionalFields.headline: Qantas flying high with cloud-based innovation: AWS

item.name: Smartphone app uses multiple Amazon Web Services to cut emergency response time after crashes

additionalFields.Description: MileUp is a cloud-based crash detection app that collects data from a smartphone's accelerometer, magnetometer, gyroscope and GPS to determine not only if a car crash has happened, but also to help predict the likelihood of a crash. It uses Amazon Pinpoint to manage campaigns, segment users, and notifications. The data MileUp collects aims to cut the average EMS notification time down to less than 30 seconds from the current average of three minutes (in urban areas) and seven minutes (in rural areas). Accomplishing this would save up to 3,000 lives per year, according to the U.S. Department of Transportation.
additionalFields.headline: Smartphone app uses multiple Amazon Web Services to cut emergency response time after crashes

item.name: Capital One rides the cloud to tech company transformation

additionalFields.Description: The Capital One mobile app runs on the AWS Cloud and Capital One is steadily migrating its legacy applications over as well. To become more of a technology company, CIO Rob Alexander says that Capital One is building better data and analytics. Currently, it is looking into using machine learning for customer service, fraud protection, and cybersecurity. Capital One hopes that this shift will attract top talent, increase the pace of innovation within the company and improve the customer experience.
additionalFields.headline: Capital One rides the cloud to tech company transformation

item.name: FINRA Commits Mission-Critical App To Amazon Cloud

additionalFields.Description: FINRA's 20 petabyte data set consists of five-years' worth of approximately 75 billion orders for quotes and trades it collects per day. In 2014, it trained 500 of its IT staff on Amazon EC2 and moved the mission-critical surveillance application that searches these orders for suspicious activity to AWS. This move, according to FINRA executive VP and CIO Steve Randich, has enabled FINRA to improve performance by 400% and cut down processing time for a 20-minute query to sub-second response times. FINRA is now looking to move its registration system to the cloud.
additionalFields.headline: FINRA Commits Mission-Critical App To Amazon Cloud

item.name: BP to go all-in on public cloud to cut datacentre upkeep costs

additionalFields.Description: At AWS re:Invent 2016, BP confirmed that it would be going all-in on AWS. In 2013, BP moved its website onto AWS, but is now looking at a "full-scale datacenter exit." This move will require shifting 3,000 line-of-business applications and 7,000 servers to the cloud. Paul Schuster, director of shared services architecture says that BP needs to be flexible and agile enough to take advantage of new technology opportunities and has turned to the cloud because of its flexibility.
additionalFields.headline: BP to go all-in on public cloud to cut datacentre upkeep costs

item.name: Netflix to hand infrastructure heavy lifting to AWS

additionalFields.Description: Speaking at re:Invent 2016, Netflix chief product officer Neil Hunt confirmed that Netflix is operating 100% on AWS. After completing migration of its last data center earlier this year, Hunt noted that Netflix has "achieved productivity, scalability, [and has] a much more nimble architecture." Over the past year, Netflix has embraced containers in order to optimize its microservices architecture and plans to leverage Blox in that process.
additionalFields.headline: Netflix to hand infrastructure heavy lifting to AWS

item.name: Going all-in with AWS cloud computing: Four takeaways from Matson CIO Peter Weis

additionalFields.Description: Matson has gone all-in on AWS, closing four of its data centers and running eighty-five percent of its mission critical apps on AWS. This migration has cut Matson's costs in half, opening up more opportunity for Matson to invest in analytics and big data in the cloud. Efficiency is key and using the cloud has enabled Matson to invest in automation at its shipping terminals and improve customer experience.
additionalFields.headline: Going all-in with AWS cloud computing: Four takeaways from Matson CIO Peter Weis

item.name: Amazon Broadens Cloud Services as Big Companies Sign On

additionalFields.Description: AWS is constantly increasing the breadth and depth of its services and is investing in building software and other services on top of its basic computing and storage platform and is “not close to being done adding new capabilities.” When asked how AWS decides which area to expand to next, CEO Andy Jassy states it is “almost always in areas that our customers are demanding us to get involved in.” The cloud computing market is evolving so rapidly that there is ample space for AWS and its partners to flourish and offer differentiated services.
additionalFields.headline: Amazon Broadens Cloud Services as Big Companies Sign On

item.name: How Amazon snatched huge customer Motorola away from Microsoft

additionalFields.Description: Motorola Solutions is going all-in on the cloud and has moved has moved approximately 450 servers to AWS. Leo Wang, head of cloud computing, says this move saves Motorola millions per year. Beyond AWS's technologies and functionality, AWS's Criminal Justice Information Services certification was key in Motorola’s decision to move its data center to the cloud because of its work with government agencies.
additionalFields.headline: How Amazon snatched huge customer Motorola away from Microsoft

item.name: Why Vevo built an analytics platform from scratch

additionalFields.Description: Miguel Alvarado, Vice President of Data and Analytics at Vevo, tapped AWS when tasked to create an analytics solution from scratch for the company’s music streaming service. Vevo uses Amazon Kinesis, Amazon Redshift and Amazon Aurora, among other services, to build out the solution. Using AWS allows all organizations within Vevo to access the data and has “led to a more efficient and less reactive philosophy” that enables Vevo to make decisions and analyze trends based on real data.
additionalFields.headline: Why Vevo built an analytics platform from scratch

item.name: American Heart Association Builds Precision Medicine Platform on AWS

additionalFields.Description:
American Heart Association (AHA), the nation’s oldest and largest voluntary organization dedicated to fighting heart disease and stroke—the two leading causes of death in the world—is building its Precision Medicine Platform on the AWS Cloud.

The AHA Precision Medicine Platform will include a vast array of curated datasets that are centrally stored, easily searched and accessible, and managed on the AWS Cloud. The platform enables researchers and clinicians to aggregate and analyze a rich breadth and depth of data, including longitudinal cohorts, proteomic, genomic, and gene-expression data using a precision medicine approach. This data and analysis will in turn allow researchers to uncover critical cardiovascular disease insights that translate into medical innovations and positively impact millions of lives.

“By using the AWS Cloud, the Platform will harness the power of big data to revolutionize the way cardiovascular research is performed and speed the promise of precision cardiovascular medicine,” said AHA CEO Nancy Brown. “The AHA remains steadfast in its commitment to eliminate the tragic global burden cardiovascular disease places on individuals, families, healthcare systems, and entire nations by mapping scientific discovery to the dramatic advances in biomedical research and technology innovation.”
additionalFields.headline: American Heart Association Builds Precision Medicine Platform on AWS

item.name: Human Longevity, Inc. – Changing Medicine Through Genomics Research

additionalFields.Description: Human Longevity, Inc. (HLI) is at the forefront of genomics research and wants to build the world’s largest database of human genomes along with related phenotype and clinical data, all in support of preventive healthcare. Going all-in on AWS, HLI saw a dramatic improvement in speed and lower cost, along with rapidly advancing visualization and analytics tools, allowing them to collect and analyze vast amounts of data in close to real time. It used to take a full year and $100M to analyze the approximate 100 GB in one genome, but now HLI can sequence a genome in around three days for a few thousand dollars. Users, in turn, can now test a hypothesis on that data in days or hours, compared to months or years.
additionalFields.headline: Human Longevity, Inc. – Changing Medicine Through Genomics Research

item.name: Amazon Brings on Five New Solar Projects to Power Its Cloud

additionalFields.Description: AWS plans to bring a total of 180 MW of solar energy onto the grid in Virginia with the announcement of five new solar farms. This is in addition to the 80 MW facility currently in operation. Once live, these six projects will produce 580,000 MWh of energy annually and will make Amazon the largest corporate backer of solar projects east of the Mississippi. AWS also announced that it will exceed its goal of 40% renewable energy by the end of this year and has set a goal of 50% by the end of 2017.
additionalFields.headline: Amazon Brings on Five New Solar Projects to Power Its Cloud

item.name: Amazon Spreads Its Marketplace Magic

additionalFields.Description: AWS customers can now take advantage of SaaS Subscriptions, an offering on the AWS Marketplace that enables customers to find and buy software through AWS and receive one single bill for the software. The streamlined process enables customers to find new software vendors, as well as for partners to reach new customers on the AWS Marketplace. Additionally, this flexibility gives customers the ability to try new software at a lower financial risk by only paying for what they use.
additionalFields.headline: Amazon Spreads Its Marketplace Magic

item.name: G4S halves data centre costs by moving to AWS

additionalFields.Description: UK-based security firm G4S has implemented a cloud-first policy, recognizing that it is more cost effective and scalable to build on the cloud. By moving its biggest outsourced data center to AWS, G4S has more than halved its data center costs in the UK. On choosing AWS, CIO Nick Folkes said AWS “represented the most mature model.”
additionalFields.headline: G4S halves data centre costs by moving to AWS

item.name: Blackboard to Migrate 29 Global Data Centers to AWS

additionalFields.Description:
Blackboard, the world’s leading provider of learner success-focused technology solutions and services for the education market, is going all in on AWS by moving 29 data centers on four continents to AWS.

Blackboard conducted an evaluation of major cloud platforms for the massive data center migration, and ultimately chose AWS for its reliability and scalability. The company also plans to leverage a wide range of AWS compute, database, storage, and network connectivity services to support its network of 16,000 schools and organizations in more than 100 countries.

The migration will entail moving thousands of virtual machines and multiple petabytes of data from data centers in North America, Europe, Asia, and Australia.

“By using AWS, we can take advantage of not only the operational strengths and global scale of AWS, but also the increasingly formidable breadth of capabilities it provides,” said Peter George, Chief Product Officer, Blackboard.
additionalFields.headline: Blackboard to Migrate 29 Global Data Centers to AWS

item.name: AWS launches QuickSight business intelligence tool out of preview

additionalFields.Description: Amazon QuickSight is now available to AWS customers in the US East (N. Virginia), US West (Oregon), and EU (Ireland) Regions, with expansions to other regions in the coming months. Amazon QuickSight enables users to quickly and easily build visualizations, perform ad-hoc analysis and quickly get business insights from their data. MLB Advanced Media (MLBAM) uses Amazon QuickSight to gain insights into its digital content by providing a real-time view of the business “without being constrained by a pre-built dashboard and metrics,” said Brandon SanGiovanni, Traffic Manger. MLBAM was able to expand the use of its stored data to make informed decisions about its products. Click here to learn more about Amazon QuickSight.
additionalFields.headline: AWS launches QuickSight business intelligence tool out of preview

item.name: Amazon Web Services to cut compute prices, continuing the decline in cloud costs

additionalFields.Description: Starting on December 1st, AWS will be cutting the price of Amazon EC2 Instance types, C4, M4, and T2 by up to 25 percent across the US East (N. Virginia), EU (Ireland), Asia Pacific (Mumbai) and Asia Pacific (Singapore) Regions. This price cut is AWS’s 53rd since inception.
additionalFields.headline: Amazon Web Services to cut compute prices, continuing the decline in cloud costs

item.name: Missguided drives accelerated growth with AWS and Claranet

additionalFields.Description: Missguided is a ‘rapid fashion’ brand that relies on speed and agility to fulfill the spontaneous purchase decisions of its customers. With the help of AWS Premier Partner, Claranet, Missguided migrated approximately 170 servers to AWS in six weeks. Using Amazon Aurora, Missugided was able to increase its maximum database throughput from 2 million transactions a minute to over 5 million, allowing the website to process all orders during critical flash sales. CTO John Allen says that Missguided has begun deploying trading platforms and back-office systems in AWS and has made a strategic decision to push as much as possible onto AWS.
additionalFields.headline: Missguided drives accelerated growth with AWS and Claranet

item.name: Zillow Develops Neural Networks to ‘See’ Like a House Hunter

additionalFields.Description: Zillow leverages the AWS Cloud to power their deep learning technology used to take home interior images and estimate the value of the home. These 'neural networks' mimic how the human brain processes visual images by correlating specific collections of image pixels with valuation signals. Through iterations of their valuation algorithm, Zillow has reduced its error rate from 14% to 4.5% and will use these neural networks to further increase its accuracy.
additionalFields.headline: Zillow Develops Neural Networks to ‘See’ Like a House Hunter

item.name: HSBC combines AWS with agile thinking to tap into growing demand for mobile banking

additionalFields.Description: HSBC's mobile-first digital transformation push is fueled by customers increasingly using mobile and other digital platforms to keep on top of their finances. HSBC is implementing cross-functional teams to develop new mobile applications and services in the AWS Cloud. Marco Pera, HSBC global head of platform management, said that what attracted them to AWS was the ability to “have environments that are totally dedicated to [HSBC]” in terms of access, security, monitoring and scalability.
additionalFields.headline: HSBC combines AWS with agile thinking to tap into growing demand for mobile banking

item.name: Enterprises no longer fear cloud security weaknesses - AWS

additionalFields.Description: At the AWS Enterprise Summit in London, Chris Bunch, head of Europe at Cloudreach, discussed how enterprise customers' concerns around security have decreased noting, “we are proactively saying [the cloud] is more secure than you can do yourself.” Bunch continued saying, AWS's scale enables it to acquire and maintain more security accreditations and badges than a single organization may be able to on their own.
additionalFields.headline: Enterprises no longer fear cloud security weaknesses - AWS
