item.name: How the cloud gave Direct Line Group an appetite for innovation

additionalFields.Description: Direct Line Group began using the AWS Cloud as a dev and test environment when trying to find faster technology. Direct Line issues 13,000 car insurance quotes per day, sells a new policy every 10 seconds and manages eight million policies. They have also moved several of their websites into production on AWS. Since starting with AWS, Direct Line's culture has become more innovative and experimental because there are fewer barriers to gaining access to the technology.
additionalFields.headline: How the cloud gave Direct Line Group an appetite for innovation

item.name: How Amazon is planning for the second decade of the cloud revolution

additionalFields.Description: At the 2016 Structure Conference, AWS's Matt Wood discussed the company’s leadership position and plans for continued growth and innovation. Wood notes that there are an increasing number of verticals adopting the cloud, even those who have high security needs like the financial sector. Wood also notes that big data, hybrid cloud, and innovative tools and services will continue to play a role in AWS's next decade.
additionalFields.headline: How Amazon is planning for the second decade of the cloud revolution

item.name: Partner opportunity moves to monitoring as Symantec hits the cloud

additionalFields.Description: Symantec has revamped its cyber security offering and is investing in ways to make security monitoring more seamless for its partners. An upgraded, simpler user interface will be run in the cloud so it can be accessed across multiple devices. Symantec will run many of the customer-facing services on AWS to take advantage of AWS's global footprint and reduce latency. Nick Savvides, cyber security strategy manager, commented that it would be "hard to justify" the cost to build their own data centers when considering AWS's maturity and global locations.
additionalFields.headline: Partner opportunity moves to monitoring as Symantec hits the cloud

item.name: Bayer Digital Farming Enables Hyper-Localized Decision-Making on AWS

additionalFields.Description:
The Bayer Digital Farming team in the company’s Crop Science division has a mission: to empower farmers to make smarter decisions and contribute to solving the challenge of feeding a growing world population, while at the same time reducing their environmental footprint. To achieve this, Bayer Digital Farming runs all-in on AWS.

Bayer Digital Farming provides outcome-based services to farmers to help them make smarter and more precise decisions about their crops and agricultural challenges such as crop disease and weather volatility. The organization’s services are based on insights from large amounts of agronomic-relevant data collected at farming sites across the country. The need to process and analyze large amounts of data, optimize and run calibrated models, and transform real-life data streams are what led Bayer Digital Farming to select AWS.

“We chose an AWS-based, cloud-only implementation approach directly from the beginning to allow for highly scalable data management and processing, as well as to serve a growing number of customers,” says Thomas Schilling, head of IT at Bayer Digital Farming. “AWS offers the best combination of stability, scalability, ease of use, and features of any cloud platform. In addition, AWS meets our data-privacy and access requirements through its expansive global infrastructure.”
additionalFields.headline: Bayer Digital Farming Enables Hyper-Localized Decision-Making on AWS

item.name: Why Xero migrated to AWS - and what it cost

additionalFields.Description: Xero began migrating its 700,000 customers to AWS in August. This migration to AWS will allow Xero to “release new software more rapidly, scale to meet times of high user demand, and grow to millions of subscribers globally.” During its earnings announcement, it was also noted that Xero plans to capitalize on AWS's machine learning capabilities.
additionalFields.headline: Why Xero migrated to AWS - and what it cost

item.name: Here’s why you’re seeing the Amazon Web Services logo during the World Series

additionalFields.Description: The MLB uses the AWS Cloud to power Statcast, a player tracking system measuring all of the plays in a baseball game. Amazon EC2, Amazon S3, and Amazon DynamoDB process and analyze these data to produce stats like, pitching velocity, launch angles of home runs and acceleration of base runners. The MLB chose AWS because of its ability to scale and efficiently distribute data from all of the stadiums around the US.
additionalFields.headline: Here’s why you’re seeing the Amazon Web Services logo during the World Series

item.name: LG Electronics Selects AWS to Power Worldwide Smart TV Technology Infrastructure

additionalFields.Description:
LG Electronics, a global leader and technology innovator in consumer electronics, mobile communications, and home appliances, has selected AWS to run its mission-critical services for more than 35 million LG Smart TVs across the globe.

When assessing existing on-premises data centers, the company realized it needed more data capacity and highly scalable computing resources for its Smart TVs to handle the dramatic instant traffic peaks that come with broadcasting live sports events such as the World Cup and Olympic Games.

“After assessing all of our cloud platform options, we decided to migrate to AWS so we could leverage the most reliable, high-performance, and secure cloud platform available for companies around the world today. We have successfully migrated the infrastructure that powers more than 35 million internet-connected LG Smart TVs in over 150 countries worldwide to the AWS Cloud and cut operation costs by 40 percent,” said Hong-Jae Kim, Cloud Center, LG Electronics.
additionalFields.headline: LG Electronics Selects AWS to Power Worldwide Smart TV Technology Infrastructure

item.name: AWS releases Amazon Linux container image for use in on-premises data centers

additionalFields.Description: The Amazon Linux container image is now available for cloud and on-premises use through Amazon EC2 Container Registry. It is built from the same software components as the Amazon Linux AMI and can be used as-is or as the basis for building images. AWS customers who have used Amazon Linux in the cloud can now deploy it on their own servers.
additionalFields.headline: AWS releases Amazon Linux container image for use in on-premises data centers

item.name: Amazon’s Andy Jassy on the Promise of the Cloud

additionalFields.Description: Andy Jassy, CEO of AWS, discussed the benefits of cloud computing and the importance of not being afraid to fail at the WSJ.D LIVE event.  Jassy stated that AWS’s investments into and focus on security provide customers with a “much stronger security posture in…the cloud” than they would have on-premises. And while cost is always a factor when moving to the cloud, customers in all segments leverage the agility of the AWS Cloud and are able to experiment and test out ideas without having to raise a lot of capital. Jassy noted that lessons learned from the Fire Phone project were incorporated into other Amazon devices.
additionalFields.headline: Amazon’s Andy Jassy on the Promise of the Cloud

item.name: Nextdoor Builds Popular Social Network on AWS

additionalFields.Description:
Social-network innovator Nextdoor is running its big-data and analytics solution on AWS, resulting in a 20 percent conversion on notifications—a key indicator of customer use—along with a 15 percent increase in unique content viewed per member.

The free and popular service is available in more than 115,000 neighborhoods across the country and growing every day. But that growth posed challenges for the company, so it turned to AWS.

“Our members and city agencies are increasingly using Nextdoor for time-critical updates for disaster recovery, crime and safety, local events, and more,” says Prakash Janakiraman, Nextdoor’s cofounder and chief architect. “Managing the increasing volume of content and email-push notifications became unwieldy for members. We wanted to improve the user experience by routing only the ‘best’ content notifications more effectively, which required us to examine and respond to behavioral data in real time. It had to be easy to operate and to understand, extend, and scale.”

Nextdoor used machine learning models, Amazon EC2 Container Service (Amazon ECS), Amazon Elastic MapReduce, AWS Lambda, Amazon Kinesis, and Spark to create a “trending post” feature that notifies users of the top daily discussion in their neighborhood. Data is analyzed, transformed, and deposited into an Amazon DynamoDB data store that can be accessed by live production systems. Notification systems then read aggregate data and determine who should be notified. Additionally, the company found ways to improve its newsfeed experience by prioritizing more “interesting” conversations above others.
additionalFields.headline: Nextdoor Builds Popular Social Network on AWS

item.name: Under Armour Goes All-In On AWS Cloud for Connected Fitness Apps

additionalFields.Description:
Under Armour, a world leader in the sports apparel industry, chose AWS to run its Connected Fitness platform, and is using the reliability and scalability of AWS to provide a great customer experience for its 175 million users.

Previously, Under Armour struggled to manage the rapid growth of its Connected Fitness platform when its IT resided in two external data centers. Looking for an alternative, the company selected AWS for better performance, scalability, and availability during peak periods, including weekends, New Year’s Day, and summer months when users tend to use the Connected Fitness app the most.

“Going all-in on AWS for Connected Fitness has enabled us to optimize all of our apps—including UA Record, MapMyFitness, Endomondo, and MyFitnessPal—along with an IoT hardware solution called HealthBox, which includes a scale, wristband, and heart rate monitor. It lets us deliver a seamless fitness experience to our global digital community, especially during peak seasons,” says Jesse Demmel, vice president of platform engineering at Under Armour. Demmel added that AWS also provides a secure cloud platform for developing new products. “With AWS, we can innovate faster to introduce the features our users are asking for, and we know we have the most secure, highest-performance cloud platform behind us.”
additionalFields.headline: Under Armour Goes All-In On AWS Cloud for Connected Fitness Apps

item.name: Liberty Mutual Uses New Technologies and Agile Approach to Develop Cloud-Based Solution Providing Competitive Advantages

additionalFields.Description: Liberty Mutual Benefits business set a goal to bring new products to market in nine months. To achieve this, Liberty leveraged EIS Group’s software and the AWS Cloud to speed the implementation and innovation of their new, cloud-based benefits platform, Serview. Liberty continues to leverage AWS to extend beyond its core insurance operations allowing for complementary innovations and increased speed, agility, visibility into its operations.
additionalFields.headline: Liberty Mutual Uses New Technologies and Agile Approach to Develop Cloud-Based Solution Providing Competitive Advantages

item.name: Customer Messaging Platform Intercom Goes All-In on AWS

additionalFields.Description:
Intercom, a messaging platform on a mission to make business personal again, is consolidating all services and data onto Amazon Web Services (AWS) to support the company’s rapid growth without the necessity of a large operations team. With more than 13,000 businesses using the product to connect with a billion people worldwide, Intercom wanted to avoid the limits of its existing relational database. Early in its migration, the company decided to move a live database with more than two billion rows into Amazon Aurora. It was able to do this with almost no downtime and without losing a single row, which led to fewer complexities of sharding, lower costs, and reduced latency in its queries.

“At the heart of Intercom is a simple relationship between users and the messages they receive. With more than a billion people on the platform, this translates into a lot of messages,” says Ciaran Lee, Intercom’s CTO and cofounder. “By going all-in on AWS, we will be able to keep real-time conversations running at a consistent speed, with low latency, to better serve our customers and have real conversations that build real connections.”
additionalFields.headline: Customer Messaging Platform Intercom Goes All-In on AWS

item.name: Illumina Selects AWS to Power BaseSpace Data Analysis Tool

additionalFields.Description:
Illumina, Inc., a global leader in next-generation gene sequencing that has generated more than 90 percent of all DNA data sequenced, has selected Amazon Web Services (AWS) to support its rapid growth and storage needs for its BaseSpace Informatics Suite.

Illumina evaluated several public cloud providers before selecting AWS based on the platform’s reliability, scalability, and superior global reach. Since then, running BaseSpace on AWS has enabled Illumina’s customers to explore and process genomic data faster and in more detail, leading to advancements in both research and clinical settings.

“We chose AWS to deliver innovative and scalable solutions to our customers around the world, many of whom are using genomic analysis to save lives and improve health outcomes,” said Sanjay Chikarmane, SVP and general manager of the Enterprise Informatics Business Unit at Illumina.
additionalFields.headline: Illumina Selects AWS to Power BaseSpace Data Analysis Tool

item.name: BBVA travels deeper into the cloud

additionalFields.Description: Banco Bilbao Vizcaya Argentaria (BBVA) will further its global transformation by leveraging AWS to build a secure, flexible and scalable cloud-based solution that will help meet the exponential growth in transactions, from 542 million per day currently to over one billion per day in 2017. The agreement will include the creation of a ‘Cloud Community’ to improve knowledge sharing and ensure regulatory compliance. BBVA currently uses AWS to run its analytics application for retailers, Commerce 360, and plans to keep expanding its use of AWS. Ricardo Moreno, global head of BBVA Engineering says the AWS products and expertise will “accelerate [BBVA’s] transformation.”
additionalFields.headline: BBVA travels deeper into the cloud

item.name: Open for business: How public data in private places works for AWS, publishers and users

additionalFields.Description: Publishing open data in the cloud can help to increase overall use and decrease the pressure on an organization's servers. The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration analyzed the usage of its Next Generation Weather Radar (NEXRAD) system data and found that making it available on the AWS Cloud led to a 230% increase in usage and a 50% decrease in usage of their own servers. Data publishers use the AWS Cloud as a lab that allows them to demonstrate the capabilities of their platforms and give users interesting data to work with. Startups can leverage these open data sets to build commercial products making the data easier to handle.
additionalFields.headline: Open for business: How public data in private places works for AWS, publishers and users

item.name: Moneyball 2.0 – tech driven innovation in sports

additionalFields.Description: Using the AWS Cloud, sports data companies in Australia are able to eliminate the need to estimate capacity requirements, employ a ‘fail fast’ strategy allowing ideas to be tested quickly, and reduce infrastructure costs. Catapult Sports is able to track player performance by employing a wearable device that can 1,000 data points per minute and is exploring how to present this information to fans in the stands. SportsTG is innovating ways to make the entire experience more seamless through mobile payment, food delivery, and restroom and concession line tracking. The scalability of the AWS cloud allows Sports TG to handle the over 200% increase in website users on Sunday nights.
additionalFields.headline: Moneyball 2.0 – tech driven innovation in sports

item.name: Amazon Web Services expands its budgeting feature, aiming to help cut cloud-computing costs

additionalFields.Description: AWS added features to the billing console, providing AWS customers with a unified view of their cloud computing costs in order to help control unexpected spending. The features lets customers set budgets for business units and track spending by region, service, department or individual user. Once user-set thresholds have been reached, managers can be notified or automatically shut down the service.
additionalFields.headline: Amazon Web Services expands its budgeting feature, aiming to help cut cloud-computing costs

item.name: Amazon adds new features to Aurora database

additionalFields.Description: AWS customers can now invoke AWS Lambda functions and load data from Amazon S3 directly into Amazon Aurora. These changes allow for increased integration of AWS services and streamlines the process for importing Amazon S3 bucket data into Amazon Aurora. To learn more about Amazon Aurora, visit the AWS website.
additionalFields.headline: Amazon adds new features to Aurora database

item.name: Amazon ramps up AWS Educate with free e-learning and job ads

additionalFields.Description: AWS Educate is furthering its vision of cultivating a “cloud-enabled workforce” by launching the AWS Educate Job Board and offering content modules with over 30 hours of training in four professional areas. Users earn badges and certificates as they complete the ‘Cloud Career Pathways’ modules and are matched with relevant job postings from in-demand technology employers from the Job Board. Click here to learn more about AWS Educate.
additionalFields.headline: Amazon ramps up AWS Educate with free e-learning and job ads

item.name: Amazon Web Services adds Ohio region, for lower latency throughout middle and eastern U.S.

additionalFields.Description: The AWS US East (Ohio) Region is now available, providing customers an additional US Region that is designed to cut latency among customers in the eastern and central United States. The new region consists of three Availability Zones, bringing the AWS total up to 38 AZs across 14 technology infrastructure regions worldwide. Click here to learn more about AWS’s Global Infrastructure.
additionalFields.headline: Amazon Web Services adds Ohio region, for lower latency throughout middle and eastern U.S.

item.name: CIA CIO: Amazon Web Services is key to developing secure apps

additionalFields.Description: The CIA’s adoption of the AWS Cloud has increased its ability to quickly develop, test, and share secure code, a “mission essential” task when dealing with evolving cyberattacks, said Luke McCormack, CIO of the Homeland Security Department. He also added that Homeland Security is “building in a fraction of the time and a fraction of the cost.” The Department of Homeland Security is expected to continue its development and adoption of a hybrid cloud environment, citing AWS’s increased ability to meet the CIA’s high bar for security as a main reason to decrease reliance on in-house data centers.
additionalFields.headline: CIA CIO: Amazon Web Services is key to developing secure apps

item.name: AWS, VMWare announce strategic partnership, new hybrid cloud service

additionalFields.Description: AWS and VMWare announced a strategic alliance to build and deliver a seamlessly integrated hybrid offering that will give customers the full software-defined data center (SDDC) experience. VMware Cloud on AWS will enable customers to run applications across VMware vSphere-based private, public, and hybrid cloud environments. Pat Gelsinger, CEO of VMWare noted that this alliance is a result of customers "telling us what they needed" and what they needed was a hybrid environment.
additionalFields.headline: AWS, VMWare announce strategic partnership, new hybrid cloud service

item.name: 3D data start-up Pointerra gets process right

additionalFields.Description: Pointerra delivers massive geospatial datasets in a 3D format that can be easily processed, managed, and analyzed. The Pointerra platform is deployed on the AWS Cloud and takes datasets, hundreds of gigabytes in size containing hundreds billions of 3D point clouds, and compresses them without any loss in resolution so they can be delivered to any device, anywhere in the world. Ian Olson, managing director, notes, “Nobody can do what we can at scale, our competition tends to max out at a couple of hundred million points.” Pointerra cuts the cost of data capture and processing, increasing the ability for people to see, use, and share 3D data.
additionalFields.headline: 3D data start-up Pointerra gets process right

item.name: AT&T hitches its Internet of Things network to Amazon’s cloud

additionalFields.Description: AT&T and AWS will integrate their Internet of Things platforms to expand AT&T’s NetBond private network. Connected devices on AT&T’s network will be able to more easily and securely transmit data into the AWS cloud by enhancing visibility of NetBond network traffic.
additionalFields.headline: AT&T hitches its Internet of Things network to Amazon’s cloud

item.name: FileMaker liberates iOS for enterprise app development

additionalFields.Description: FileMaker Cloud lets organizations develop and maintain custom mobile apps that can be shared across iOS, Windows, Mac and the web. It leverages the AWS Cloud to provide enterprise business units with the tools to develop apps in a flexible, scalable, and secure environment. Ann Monroe, Vice President of Worldwide Marketing, says this allows customers to “focus on creating apps for their specific business needs without worrying about upfront hardware expenditures and ongoing server maintenance.”
additionalFields.headline: FileMaker liberates iOS for enterprise app development

item.name: Machine analytics fuel Cardinal Health's IT transformation

additionalFields.Description: Cardinal Health has improved its ecommerce software performance, warehouse management application accuracy, and new customer onboarding processes with the help of AWS Partner Network Advanced Technology Partner, Splunk. Using machine analytics, Splunk's software aggregates, compresses and encrypts Cardinal log files before shipping them to AWS. Scot Lindsey, VP of Enterprise IT, said that it is hard to see the bigger picture at Cardinal Health's scale and complexity, but that Splunk crunches “huge amounts of data” to present the pattern.
additionalFields.headline: Machine analytics fuel Cardinal Health's IT transformation

item.name: Flight data at your fingertips

additionalFields.Description: The National Geospatial-Intelligence Agency (NGA) Aeronautical Office leverages the AWS Cloud for its Aero electronic flight bag app. The app gives more than 25,000 pilots in-flight access to updated 3-D moving maps and charts, airport directories, procedures and weather information, reducing the planning and prep time before flights. When a pilot lost electrical power over the Middle East, Aero allowed crew to "safely navigate…for 45 minutes" until power was restored.
additionalFields.headline: Flight data at your fingertips

item.name: New P2 Instance Type for Amazon EC2 – Up to 16 GPUs

additionalFields.Description:
AWS announced the availability of Amazon EC2 P2 Instances, leveraging NVIDIA GPUs for compute-intensive applications including artificial intelligence, high performance computing, and big data processing. These kinds of massively parallel workloads can now be processed faster and more efficiently. Click here to learn more about Amazon EC2 P2 Instances.

  • Forbes: Amazon Boosts Cloud-Computing Performance With New, GPU-Accelerated AWS Instances
  • CRN: AWS Introduces P2 Instances To Power AI, High-Performance Workloads
additionalFields.headline: New P2 Instance Type for Amazon EC2 – Up to 16 GPUs

item.name: Allez, rendez-vous à Paris – An AWS Region is coming to France!

additionalFields.Description:
AWS announced that a new AWS Region will open in the Paris area in 2017, providing even lower latency for users who want to store their content in data centers in France. As a result of AWS' growth in France, more than 80 percent of companies listed on the CAC 40 (the French stock market index) are using the AWS Cloud to speed their time-to-market, lower their costs, and support their businesses globally.

  • GeekWire: Amazon announces plan to open Paris-area web services region
  • VentureBeat: AWS’ next data center site will be in Paris
  • ZDNet: Amazon Web Services spreads its cloud: Now AWS opens up France region
additionalFields.headline: Allez, rendez-vous à Paris – An AWS Region is coming to France!

item.name: Parsec joins the cloud gaming fray with a new low-latency service

additionalFields.Description: Parsec offers a low-latency, high-powered, interactive video streaming service that allows gamers to play remotely and avoid purchasing costly hardware. Parsec leverages the AWS Cloud to help it scale more easily, keep its prices competitive to competitors, and reduce latency. Co-founder Benjy Boxer commented that using the AWS Cloud allows his team to focus on “delivering entertainment and software directly to the consumer via low-powered devices.”
additionalFields.headline: Parsec joins the cloud gaming fray with a new low-latency service

item.name: News UK explains how and why it went cloud first on AWS

additionalFields.Description: News UK hosts its digital assets on the AWS Cloud and has now begun to move its enterprise workloads as part of their cloud first strategy. Danny Tedora, transformation program manager, noted that the security team was persuaded to adopt this cloud first strategy because AWS' security is as good as or better than on-premises. Tedora and his team found that at least 80% of workloads at News UK are suitable for the cloud now based on the technical, security, and financial criteria they set forth. Through this process, News UK has already decommissioned 400 of their 3,500 servers that were no longer needed.
additionalFields.headline: News UK explains how and why it went cloud first on AWS

item.name: Dollar Shave Club grooming AWS cloud services for smoother growth

additionalFields.Description: Dollar Shave Club (DSC) uses Amazon EC2, Amazon S3, Amazon Redshift and Amazon Kinesis Analytics to power its custom marketing automation, customer resources management, fulfillment and customer service apps. DTC's technology is built to handle the scale, complexity, and different needs of these customer services. Jason Bosco, director of backend engineering at Dollar Shave Club, notes that in embracing the AWS services, DSC can focus on "leveraging what AWS has already taken care of … and build[ing] on top of that."
additionalFields.headline: Dollar Shave Club grooming AWS cloud services for smoother growth

item.name: A Food Waste Company Connected Its Low-Tech Digesters To The Cloud Using AWS And Slack

additionalFields.Description: BioHiTech has leveraged the AWS Cloud to collect trillions of pieces of food waste data from 400 aerobic digesters since 2013. By using Slack channels to monitor the devices, BioHiTech can query any digester device remotely from their phones. They are able to look at trends, like which foods are getting tossed out the most, and spot outliers to suggest changes to minimize waste in the supply chain. BioHiTech plans to expand the use of Alto, its cloud technology, to become a player in the IoT market.
additionalFields.headline: A Food Waste Company Connected Its Low-Tech Digesters To The Cloud Using AWS And Slack

item.name: White House Unveils Data Sharing Platform for Climate Change Research

additionalFields.Description:
The White House launched the Partnership for Resilience and Preparedness (PREP) to identify information needs, reduce access and usability barriers, and develop an open-source platform to share data on climate resilience. AWS will make new climate-related datasets available, provide cloud services, and open a call for proposals for new tools and applications for climate resilience and preparedness activities as part of the Joint Declaration on Harnessing the Data Revolution for Climate Resistance.  

  • NextGov: White House Unveils Data Sharing Platform for Climate Change Research
  • Environmental Leader: White House, Google, Amazon, Launch Big Data Tool to Help Companies’ Climate Resilience Planning
  • World Resources Institute: PREP-aring for a Changing Climate by Harnessing the Data Revolution
additionalFields.headline: White House Unveils Data Sharing Platform for Climate Change Research

item.name: Why this hospital is moving to Amazon’s cloud

additionalFields.Description: The USMD Health System has moved its accounting system, human resources app, practice management system, and medical imaging into the AWS Cloud. USMD Health leverages the security, elasticity, and low cost of the AWS Cloud to ensure HIPPA compliance and centralize the IT operations.
additionalFields.headline: Why this hospital is moving to Amazon’s cloud

item.name: Cloud fuels ANZ digital disruption

additionalFields.Description: Large customers in Australia and New Zealand such as Xero, Domain, AMP, and the Australian Stock Exchange are pushing workloads into the cloud and experiencing increased innovation. In moving to AWS, Domain went from one release every three weeks to an average release-to production of 60 software updates per week. Craig Ryman, CIO of AMP, says the move to AWS gave AMP the “fuel for digital disruption.”
additionalFields.headline: Cloud fuels ANZ digital disruption

item.name: Deep Learning Paves Way for Better Diagnostics

additionalFields.Description: Two final-year PhD students at Stanford University are leveraging Amazon EC2, Amazon S3 and Amazon EBS to run deep learning workloads to improve diagnostics for a chronic eye disease. Researcher Jason Su noted that “AWS provides … flexibility for scaling up and scaling down, for cost, and for trying out different ideas.”
additionalFields.headline: Deep Learning Paves Way for Better Diagnostics

item.name: Cloud goes back to the Bronze Age: University of Manchester takes world famous collections to AWS Cloud

additionalFields.Description: The University of Manchester Library is moving 30TB of digital material from its Special Collection including rare books, manuscripts and artifacts to the AWS Cloud. This move will enable the University of Manchester to capitalize on cost efficiencies and consolidate digital materials to one platform widely available and accessible to all.
additionalFields.headline: Cloud goes back to the Bronze Age: University of Manchester takes world famous collections to AWS Cloud

item.name: Amazon Web's Kabali moment: The cloud powers almost everything

additionalFields.Description: Ticketing company, TicketNew and digital cinema company, Qube Cinemas leveraged the AWS Cloud to scale their businesses and keep costs low for the release of the film Kabali in India. Senthil Kumar, co-founder of Qbe Cinemas, noted that it was the cost-effectiveness that drove him to choose the AWS Cloud to generate and distribute the keys to the theaters showing Kabali. Prior to the release, TicketNow's projected resource restrictions prompted the move to AWS and enabled them to “sell 100,000 tickets in … [the first] eight hours and handle a million users” on each of the following seven days.
additionalFields.headline: Amazon Web's Kabali moment: The cloud powers almost everything

item.name: Xero CEO Rod Drury says machine learning and AI at heart of its new products

additionalFields.Description: Xero has migrated its global platform onto AWS to leverage the machine learning and artificial intelligence capabilities. In the past 12 months, Xero has collected $1 trillion in transactions and is using big data to provide accountants with new insights and influence its upcoming service launches like the Facebook Messenger chat-bot, automatic invoice coding and the Live Contacts software. Xero is globally leading the charge on accounting technology through their innovative advancements in fintech.
additionalFields.headline: Xero CEO Rod Drury says machine learning and AI at heart of its new products

item.name: Oregon Joins CJIS-Compliant Amazon Web Services Cloud

additionalFields.Description: Oregon is the fourth state to sign a Criminal Justice Information Services (CJIS) agreement with AWS, giving their police access to the AWS Cloud. Major Tom M. Worthy, Oregon State Police CSO, notes that this agreement meets every requirement of the FBI's CJIS Security Policy and will provide agencies with additional hosting options that enhance the security of their information.
additionalFields.headline: Oregon Joins CJIS-Compliant Amazon Web Services Cloud

item.name: AWS SDK for C++ Ready for Production Use

additionalFields.Description: AWS SDK for C++ is available for production use, providing a modern C++ interface for AWS. Its C++ library will include credential management, logging, asynchronous requests, memory allocation, streaming, and will support integration with Amazon S3, Amazon Kinesis, and Amazon DynamoDB. The SDK will be updated frequently to support new AWS API changes to make C++ development easier and more secure. Visit our website to learn more about AWS SDK for C++.
additionalFields.headline: AWS SDK for C++ Ready for Production Use

item.name: AWS Voted Top Cloud Enterprise Cloud for Third Consecutive Year

additionalFields.Description: AWS was ranked the top cloud enterprise cloud by subscribers of PCMag for the third year in a row. Voters highlighted the storage options, accessibility, reliability, and flexibility/elasticity of the services and would recommend AWS to their colleagues. To learn more about how to get started on AWS, visit our website
additionalFields.headline: AWS Voted Top Cloud Enterprise Cloud for Third Consecutive Year

item.name: Forbes Cloud 100: Meet The Private Companies Leading Cloud Computing In 2016

additionalFields.Description: Congratulations to AWS customer, Slack, for being named the leading private cloud computing company by Forbes. Forbes Cloud 100's inaugural class consists of security, collaboration, finance, analytics, IT and marketing companies who are transforming how companies do business. Slack uses Amazon EC2, Amazon S3, and AWS Identity and Access Management, among other AWS services to ensure speed of innovation and responsiveness, reliability, and security features to ensure the confidentiality of customer information. To learn more about how Slack is using AWS, click here.
additionalFields.headline: Forbes Cloud 100: Meet The Private Companies Leading Cloud Computing In 2016

item.name: Why the U.S. Government Finally Loves Cloud Computing

additionalFields.Description: Authorizations like FedRAMP, the CIA's use of the AWS Cloud, and the vast quantity of data being collected, has driven the U.S. government to embrace cloud computing. Since 2011, the AWS GovCloud (US) has grown 221% year-over-year with government agencies leveraging the cloud to help automate their data analysis processes to gain new insights. Justin Langseth, chief executive of Zoomdata, remarks that the government has “accelerated beyond what enterprises are doing,” in cloud adoption.
additionalFields.headline: Why the U.S. Government Finally Loves Cloud Computing

item.name: ANZ Bank ups cloud focus with open networks for fintech collaboration

additionalFields.Description: The ANZ Banking group performs disaster recovery tests every 20 minutes through AWS-hosted Chaos Monkey to assess their network's ability to withstand problems and reduce the possibility of banking outages. Christian Venter, general manager of consumer digital technology, says that to adapt to customers who want services “sooner, faster, better and cheaper,” ANZ has embraced AWS to improve their mobile service delivery and offerings.
additionalFields.headline: ANZ Bank ups cloud focus with open networks for fintech collaboration

item.name: Cloud Chronicles

additionalFields.Description: The Economist profiles AWS’s origins within Amazon, its fast growth and scale, and its success with both startups and enterprises. The article highlights AWS's momentum and “progress towards full dominance of cloud computing's wide skies.”
additionalFields.headline: Cloud Chronicles

item.name: Q&A with Thorn - A Tech Innovation Fighting Child Sexual Exploitation

additionalFields.Description: Thorn's web based tool, Spotlight, leverages the AWS Cloud, machine learning algorithms, and insight from officers in the field to connect disparate data, which helps improve the effectiveness and efficiency of domestic sex trafficking investigations. To date, Spotlight been used in over 4,400 investigations, to identify over 1,000 traffickers, and to identify over 2,300 victims of human trafficking, including over 900 children.
additionalFields.headline: Q&A with Thorn - A Tech Innovation Fighting Child Sexual Exploitation

item.name: Axis Bank gives shapes to its innovation lab

additionalFields.Description: Axis Bank is launching an innovation lab aimed to introduce disruptive technologies in the banking and financial sector, particularly in payments, customer experience and risk management. AWS will provide technology, access to mentorships and other startup-focused trainings to those going through the accelerator program.
additionalFields.headline: Axis Bank gives shapes to its innovation lab

item.name: New York Public Library reads up on the cloud

additionalFields.Description: The New York Public Library (NYPL) has reduced its number of on-premises servers by 40% and is saving 95% on hardware and software costs. The company runs approximately 80 websites on the AWS Cloud, which allows their patrons to browse a collection of 51 million items. Jay Haque, Director of DevOps and Enterprise Computing at NYPL, says that, due to patron demand and expectations, "the website can't [afford to] go down" and that AWS's availability, security and scalability ensure that it doesn't.
additionalFields.headline: New York Public Library reads up on the cloud

item.name: Intelligence community couples new cloud systems with 'revolutionary' concepts

additionalFields.Description: The Intelligence Community IT Enterprise (ICITE) leverages the NSA's GovCloud and the AWS Commercial Cloud Services (C2S) to increase sharing, security and efficiency of the information within the intelligence community (IC). Jennifer Kron, deputy chief information officer for the IC, says the “cloud can be an enabler to security [and that it] can be seen as secure as/or more secure than the traditional environment.” The ICITE aims to create trust among the IC and facilitate further adoption of cloud services by other agencies.
additionalFields.headline: Intelligence community couples new cloud systems with 'revolutionary' concepts

item.name: New AWS Application Load Balancer

additionalFields.Description:
AWS Application Load Balancer (ALB) for Amazon ELB was announced at the AWS New York Summit. The Application Load Balancer allows developers more control over how content gets distributed across servers and features content-based routing, containerized application support, HTTP/2 and WebSockets support. To learn more, visit the AWS Application Load Balancer page.

  • GeekWire: Amazon Web Services announces Layer 7 application load balancer, 47% cut in cost of Elastic Block Store ‘snapshots’
  • TechCrunch: New AWS load balancing tool puts developers in complete control
additionalFields.headline: New AWS Application Load Balancer

item.name: How Lyft gets a lift from Amazon’s cloud

additionalFields.Description: Lyft has been “all-in” on the AWS Cloud since its launch in 2012. It has since grown rapidly and currently provides over 14 million rides per month. Lyft leverages numerous AWS services including Amazon DynamoDB, Redshift, and Kinesis to store, analyze, and manage its data. CTO Chris Lambert said that the auto scaling ability allowed Lyft's launch in 24 new cities in 24 hours to go off “without a hitch.”
additionalFields.headline: How Lyft gets a lift from Amazon’s cloud

item.name: CIA Official: ‘Cloud Has Been a Godsend’

additionalFields.Description: The CIA leverages AWS to improve their cybersecurity posture and speed in handling national security threats. Since building the cloud infrastructure for the 17 agencies comprising the intelligence community (IC), AWS has developed and launched the IC Marketplace and continually improved the offerings with input from the CIA. Officials say that the “cloud has been a Godsend for folks trying to implement systems quickly and for us to secure workloads better.”
additionalFields.headline: CIA Official: ‘Cloud Has Been a Godsend’

item.name: Cloud Tech Boosts HIV Drug Resistance Testing

additionalFields.Description: Researchers from the South African National Bioinformatics Institute developed Exatype, a drug resistance testing platform run on AWS, to improve clinicians' ability to diagnose HIV drug resistance and provide the correct course of treatment. With the help of Hyrax Biosciences, they are further developing and commercializing the technology with the ultimate hope to make the machines portable enough to use at the point of care. On using AWS, Simon Travers, CEO and Founder of Hydrax Biosciences states that in addition to cost-savings, the scalability allows for the simultaneous analysis of "thousands of samples…without any delay in getting results back to the clinician."
additionalFields.headline: Cloud Tech Boosts HIV Drug Resistance Testing

item.name: Why DTCC is using Amazon’s Cloud

additionalFields.Description: An increasing number of financial services players are turning to the AWS Cloud, because of AWS’s compliance with the SEC's regulatory requirements and focus on security. One such company, the Depository Trust & Clearing Corporation (DTCC) provides clearing, settlement, and central custody services to the financial markets. In addition to migrating Avox Data Services, the DTCC’s legal entity reference data arm, to the AWS Cloud, they have leveraged AWS for real-time swaps data reporting. The move to the cloud is saving the company through lower infrastructure costs, and allowing DTCC to focus on innovation.
additionalFields.headline: Why DTCC is using Amazon’s Cloud

item.name: Golden Manager and limitless growth on AWS

additionalFields.Description: Golden Manager, a multi-platform game launched by Barcelona based publisher Kerad Games, is all in on AWS and benefits from the scalability, price flexibility and innovation as it expands around the world. With the help of APN Partner, Claranet, Kerad Games transitioned from an on-premises infrastructure to a hybrid environment and finally to a complete cloud solution. Alberto Guerrero, CEO of Kerald Games, says having a completely managed platform allows the team to “dedicate themselves exclusively to creating and developing the game.”
additionalFields.headline: Golden Manager and limitless growth on AWS

item.name: Amazon Web Services has been named “Leader” in the IaaS Magic Quadrant for 6th Consecutive Year

additionalFields.Description:
In the 2016 “Magic Quadrant for Cloud Infrastructure as a Service, Worldwide,” Amazon Web Services is positioned highest and furthest for its ability to execute and completeness of vision in the Leaders’ quadrant. Check out some of the coverage following Gartner’s release of the MQ:  

  • Fortune: Why Amazon Is the Cumulonimbus Cloud of Business Technology
  • NetworkWorld: Amazon remains top dog in Gartner’s cloud Magic Quadrant
  • TechRepublic: Amazon still crushing cloud competition, says Gartner Magic Quadrant for IaaS
