additionalFields.headline: Amazon Web Services has been named “Leader” in the IaaS Magic Quadrant for 6th Consecutive Year

item.name: Accenture helps ATO move to Amazon Web Services

additionalFields.Description: The Australian Taxation Office moved one of its mission-critical applications to AWS with the help of APN partner, Accenture. Craig Fox, ATO service operations A/g first assistant commissioner cites the need to deliver highly available, modern services and reduce infrastructure costs as major reasons to leverage AWS during their busy tax time period.
additionalFields.headline: Accenture helps ATO move to Amazon Web Services

item.name: Sub-Sahara Tree Survey Finds Success with AWS, Hybrid Cloud

additionalFields.Description: Scientists from University of Minnesota and the NASA Center for Climate Simulation used a combination of NASA resources and the AWS Cloud to conduct a biomass census of the estimated one billion trees and shrubs in the Sub-Sahara region of Africa. The scope of processing and analyzing all the satellite data for this massive 10 million square kilometer region of Africa puts it in the category of data-intensive science. Using Amazon EC2 Spot Instances, 43 terabytes of image data was processed in 72 hours for less than $2,000, something that previously would have taken months.
additionalFields.headline: Sub-Sahara Tree Survey Finds Success with AWS, Hybrid Cloud

item.name: Amazon Relational Database Service Named Winner of DBTA Readers' Choice Awards, Best Cloud Database

additionalFields.Description: The winners for the Database Trends and Applications Readers' Choice Awards have been announced and Amazon RDS has been named the winner of the Best Cloud Database for the second year in a row. Amazon RDS provides cost-efficient and resizable capacity while managing time-consuming database administration tasks, freeing you up to focus on your applications and business. Click here to learn more about Amazon RDS.
additionalFields.headline: Amazon Relational Database Service Named Winner of DBTA Readers' Choice Awards, Best Cloud Database

item.name: MyOptique keeps close eye on risk mitigation in move to AWS

additionalFields.Description: MyOptique has migrated its entire web server estate to AWS with the help of APN Partner, Claranet, and has decreased the average purchase time on their site by 20% because of the speed of the new infrastructure. Howard Bryant, CFO and CIO says MyOptique now has “almost limitless” innovation capabilities and is currently migrating its operational systems to the cloud.
additionalFields.headline: MyOptique keeps close eye on risk mitigation in move to AWS

item.name: Five things retailers can learn from Gousto

additionalFields.Description: Gousto, a food delivery startup, is collecting previously untapped customer data and leveraging AWS to personalize their customers’ experience with the service. Shaun Pearce, VP of Engineering, says AWS has given Gousto the “ultimate flexibility” to experiment, test new ideas, quickly make changes, and scale as they grow to meet end-user demand.
additionalFields.headline: Five things retailers can learn from Gousto

item.name: Building a New Model for Data-Driven Decision-Making

additionalFields.Description: The University of Maryland University College was named one of the 2016 Campus Technology Innovators Awards recipients for the Office of Analytics' integrated business intelligence platform. Their spin off startup, HelioCampus relies on AWS to host, process, and deliver data analytics for its platform and services. Darren Catalano, CEO of HelioCampus, says what took them five years and over $10 million to build, can now be offered at a fraction of the cost, with implementations taking only six months.
additionalFields.headline: Building a New Model for Data-Driven Decision-Making

item.name: Banks Look Up to the Cloud as Computer Security Concerns Recede

additionalFields.Description: Bloomberg Technology discusses how banks are embracing cloud technology as security in the cloud strengthens and are realizing cost benefits and increasing innovation. For example, CapitalOne offers customers access to auto, mortgage, and home-equity info using Alexa on the Amazon Echo. CIO Rob Alexander notes, there is “nothing [they] aren't willing to put in the public cloud.”
additionalFields.headline: Banks Look Up to the Cloud as Computer Security Concerns Recede

item.name: DBS Bank signs AWS to focus on fintech

additionalFields.Description: ZDNet profiles how DBS Bank will leverage AWS to compute pricing and valuing of financial instruments and handle short-term surges in trading volumes. Additionally, DBS is looking to migrate up to 50% of its compute workload into the cloud in the next two years to take advantage of the flexibility and speed that will allow them to improve service delivery and change the customer journey.
additionalFields.headline: DBS Bank signs AWS to focus on fintech

item.name: What iRobot's partnership with Amazon will mean for the future of connected robots

additionalFields.Description: The Boston Business Journal covers how leveraging the AWS Cloud will allow iRobot to migrate their control systems, scale the number of connected robots they support, and store information gathered by the robots. On these options, CEO Colin Angle says the map created by the Roomba 980 could be uploaded to the AWS Cloud and would allow the user to see and manipulate its path and eventually see a holistic map of all connected devices within the home.
additionalFields.headline: What iRobot's partnership with Amazon will mean for the future of connected robots

item.name: Canadian SVOD service shomi prepares video assets 20% faster and streamlines workflows with Elemental and AWS

additionalFields.Description: Video Net reports on shomi's relationship with Elemental Technologies and AWS as it scales its business with the growing streaming market in Canada. shomi is scaling to enable viewing 20% faster and has moved all of their content to the Elemental Cloud and all of their video origin and storage to the AWS Cloud. Augusto Rosa, Senior Director of Video and Network Infrastructure says this expansion is "critical" to meet the demand.
additionalFields.headline: Canadian SVOD service shomi prepares video assets 20% faster and streamlines workflows with Elemental and AWS

item.name: Can Big Still Be Beautiful?

additionalFields.Description: Fortune profiles Johnson & Johnson's resilience as a large, differentiated multinational company and the steps they've taken to ensure the J&J brands remain successful. Moving almost all of the company’s data to the AWS Cloud allows for the standardization of processes among their 250 operating companies, saving $1 billion, says Sandi Peterson, Group Worldwide Chairman.
additionalFields.headline: Can Big Still Be Beautiful?

item.name: 2016 Magic Quadrant for Public Cloud Storage Services, Worldwide

additionalFields.Description:
In the 2016 Magic Quadrant for Public Cloud Storage Services, Worldwide, Gartner placed Amazon Web Services in the “Leaders” Quadrant. AWS is placed highest for ability to execute and furthest for completeness of vision. Check out some of the coverage: 

  • NetworkWorld: Gartner: Amazon’s cloud storage is 1.6x bigger than all other competitors combined
  • Geekwire: Amazon Web Services tops Microsoft, Google and everyone else in Gartner’s new public cloud ratings
  • Fortune: Why Amazon Continues to Dominate in the Cloud Storage Wars
additionalFields.headline: 2016 Magic Quadrant for Public Cloud Storage Services, Worldwide

item.name: Iris and fingerprint scanning coming to Sea-Tac Airport security as new option this week

additionalFields.Description: GeekWire covers Clear's launch of iris and fingerprint security screening terminals at the Seattle-Tacoma International Airport. This technology will decrease time in line and increase security at TSA checkpoints. On using AWS GovCloud to protect passenger information, CEO Caryn Steidman-Baker says the security procedures, “surpass industry best practices.”
additionalFields.headline: Iris and fingerprint scanning coming to Sea-Tac Airport security as new option this week

item.name: Amazon says 26 AWS services meet tough new credit-card security standard

additionalFields.Description: GeekWire covers the announcement that 26 AWS services, including Amazon EC2 Container Service, AWS Config, and AWS WAF, adhere to the newest Payment Card Industry Data Security Standards. This version ensures organizations keep critical data-security controls in place and up to date.
additionalFields.headline: Amazon says 26 AWS services meet tough new credit-card security standard

item.name: Amazon added so much extra capacity for Prime Day that it could have powered the whole site in 2009

additionalFields.Description: Business Insider covers Amazon's Prime Day and how they were able to handle the biggest day in company history. By increasing their capacity on AWS by an amount equivalent to all of AWS and Amazon.com in 2009, Amazon was able to handle the increased website traffic in addition to one million first-time downloads of the Amazon app.
additionalFields.headline: Amazon added so much extra capacity for Prime Day that it could have powered the whole site in 2009

item.name: Hudl Sports Video Analysis Service Grows Fast On Amazon

additionalFields.Description: InformationWeek profiles how Hudl leverages the AWS Cloud to provide coaches and players with a platform for uploading, viewing, analyzing, and sharing their sports footage. CTO Brian Kaiser says that, in peak season, 35 hours of video per minute are being uploaded by their estimated 45 million users and that using AWS was “instrumental” in the company's rapid growth.
additionalFields.headline: Hudl Sports Video Analysis Service Grows Fast On Amazon

item.name: Why cloud workload portability is a pipe dream

additionalFields.Description: InfoWorld profiles Hudl as a long time AWS user that uses Amazon Redshift for “everything.” The article goes on to discuss workload portability and the reality that, while it has become easier, companies get “hooked” to the services of the platforms and keep their workloads on one platform.
additionalFields.headline: Why cloud workload portability is a pipe dream

item.name: Data for Public Good

additionalFields.Description: Trajectory Magazine covers how The Climate Corporation, Open AQ, and The World Bank leverage AWS Earth observation data to enhance decision-making tools for farmers, as well as monitor air quality and electricity use in areas of poverty. Adam Pasch of The Climate Corporation says, “Data evaluation that previously took hours or days can now be conducted in real-time.”
additionalFields.headline: Data for Public Good

item.name: Gene-Sequencer Illumina Builds Knowledge Base on Amazon

additionalFields.Description: Illumina, uses the AWS Cloud  to obtain the results from sequencing an individual genome in 24 hours at a cost of $1,000, a process previously taking “weeks or months and cost[ing] hundreds of thousands of dollars.” The resulting knowledge bank Illumina has created increases the likelihood of successfully battling cancer by giving doctors vital information to prescribe genetically targeted, mutation-based treatments.
additionalFields.headline: Gene-Sequencer Illumina Builds Knowledge Base on Amazon

item.name: A More Useful Third-Party Voter Registrar for States

additionalFields.Description: Route Fifty covers Rock the Vote's relaunch of its online voter registration platform on the AWS Cloud. The move will increase the scalability, speed, and efficiency of Rock the Vote when registering the anticipated two million new voters online and on their mobile platform as registration deadlines near and registrations spike.
additionalFields.headline: A More Useful Third-Party Voter Registrar for States

item.name: Trainline.com dumps Oracle and Microsoft, gulps AWS Kool-Aid

additionalFields.Description: The Register [U.K.] interviewed The Trainline.com CTO Mark Holt on the decision to completely migrate to the AWS Cloud. Holt cites numerous benefits including £1.2m savings in capital expenditures, a 5,000% faster time-to-market, and reduced latency.
additionalFields.headline: Trainline.com dumps Oracle and Microsoft, gulps AWS Kool-Aid

item.name: White House Initiative Brings Together Cross-Sector Partners to Spur Criminal Justice Reform

additionalFields.Description:
The White House Data Driven Justice (DDJ) Initiative aims to reduce the number of individuals incarcerated for low-level offenses by improving communities, reforming sentencing, and investing in the re-entry process. To assist the DDJ in using data-driven strategies to improve criminal justice, AWS will convene a Technology and Research Consortium to identify viable technology solutions, and provide a secure platform for criminal justice officials and health care practitioners to share data.

  • The Intersector Project: White House Initiative Brings Together Cross-Sector Partners to Spur Criminal Justice Reform  
  • CNET: White House says data can help fix America's overcrowded jails
  • Wired: The White House Is On A Mission To Shrink US Prisons With Data
  • Directions Magazine: Esri Pledging $500,000 to White House Data Driven Justice Initiative
additionalFields.headline: White House Initiative Brings Together Cross-Sector Partners to Spur Criminal Justice Reform

item.name: Secure Countrywide Data Sharing in the Amazon GovCloud

additionalFields.Description: Police officers in 29 departments within Bucks County, PA are now able to access shared records in real-time thanks to a collaboration between CODY Systems’ COBRA.net and AWS. The program aggregates information stored on different record management systems into a secure, scalable network accessible by all departments in AWS GovCloud. Public Safety Director Fred Harran says the system “saves lives” by giving officers data to better handle on-the-ground situations and is looking into expanding the network to neighboring counties.
additionalFields.headline: Secure Countrywide Data Sharing in the Amazon GovCloud

item.name: How Dollar Shave Club went from viral marketer to engineering powerhouse

additionalFields.Description: Dollar Shave Club leveraged AWS to handle all of the traffic brought to their website from their first Super Bowl ad without the site going down. The reliability and “almost infinite” scalability of AWS allow Dollar Shave Club to support their custom built applications and grow as an evolving, disruptive startup.
additionalFields.headline: How Dollar Shave Club went from viral marketer to engineering powerhouse

item.name: Highlights from the AWS London Summit

additionalFields.Description:
Check out some great coverage following the AWS London Summit, including how customers are using the cloud experimentally to gain a competitive edge and the value of serverless computing.

  • Computer Weekly [U.K.]: Amazon.com CTO cautions enterprises against underestimating value of test and development
  • City A.M. [U.K.]: Amazon will plough ahead with UK data centre plans despite Brexit
  • The Register [U.K.]: AWS works on 'urgent' deals for UK customers as £ dips against $
  • The Register [U.K.]: Next big thing after containers? Amazon CTO talks up serverless computing
additionalFields.headline: Highlights from the AWS London Summit

item.name: AWS Helps Fermilab Researchers 'See' Neutrino Particles

additionalFields.Description: Information Week covers Fermi National Accelerator Laboratory's research on neutrino particles and how they were able to run three complex physics analysis programs to achieve their results. The analysis of large quantities of data would have strained many computer clusters, but the use of the Amazon EC2 Spot Market allowed them to complete their analysis and double their processing capacity on demand. To learn more about Amazon EC2 Spot Market, click here.
additionalFields.headline: AWS Helps Fermilab Researchers 'See' Neutrino Particles

item.name: American Heart Association Taps Amazon to Support Precision Cardiovascular Research

additionalFields.Description: The American Heart Association announced a collaboration with AWS allowing winners of the AHA Data grant to utilize AWS services for their computational storage and analysis research. On this collaboration, AHA CEO Nancy Brown says it "will unite the global research community to accelerate discovery in cardiovascular health and usher in a new era of tailored prevention and treatment that will help patients and lessen the global burden of cardiovascular disease."
additionalFields.headline: American Heart Association Taps Amazon to Support Precision Cardiovascular Research

item.name: AWS Expands Database Migration Service, Adds Replication

additionalFields.Description: Following the AWS Santa Clara Summit, InformationWeek details the expanded capabilities of the AWS Database Migration Service. Expanded functionality includes support of data migrations from Oracle and Teradata warehouses to Amazon Redshift as well as continuous data replication.
additionalFields.headline: AWS Expands Database Migration Service, Adds Replication

item.name: Cloud Computing Changed How Los Angeles responds to a Crisis

additionalFields.Description: The City of Los Angeles has backed up its evacuation tracking, hazard mitigation, and emergency communications systems on AWS, following concerns that legacy alternative emergency operations centers (EOC) would be unable to handle a failure in the main EOC. This decision grants city officials peace of mind knowing they can "set up a virtual EOC anytime, anywhere." To learn more about how local government agencies are innovating on the AWS Cloud, visit our Public Sector page.
additionalFields.headline: Cloud Computing Changed How Los Angeles responds to a Crisis

item.name: What the Defense Intelligence Agency Learned from Amazon

additionalFields.Description: After visiting the AWS offices, the DIA implemented smaller developer teams for two projects based on Jeff Bezos’ “two-pizza rule.” These teams worked on examining data to uncover predictors of protests and matching resumes to appropriate vacancy ads.
additionalFields.headline: What the Defense Intelligence Agency Learned from Amazon

item.name: Zynga Adopts Aurora Database, More Amazon Services

additionalFields.Description: Zynga’s usage of Amazon Aurora to reduce the operational burden on the company’s engineers is highlighted by InformationWeek’s Charlie Babcock. Chris Broglie, a Zynga architect, says that “[Amazon] Aurora has delivered the necessary performance without any of the operational overhead of running MySQL” and that “Using AWS allows Zynga to focus on developing great games, investing in product innovation, and improving player experiences.”
additionalFields.headline: Zynga Adopts Aurora Database, More Amazon Services

item.name: Amazon Web Services Achieves FedRAMP High Authorization

additionalFields.Description:
AWS is pleased to announce that AWS GovCloud (US) has received a Provisional Authority to Operate (P-ATO) from the Joint Authorization Board (JAB) under the Federal Risk and Authorization Management Program (FedRAMP) High baseline - one of the first cloud service providers to meet the baseline. Compliance without compromise is possible with AWS GovCloud (US) and this recognition validates AWS GovCloud (US) as a secure environment to run highly sensitive government workloads. Click here for more information on AWS GovCloud (US).

  • FedScoop: FedRAMP finally releases high-impact security baseline
  • FCW: FedRAMP rolls out high security baseline
  • Federal Times: FedRAMP finalizes controls for highly sensitive data in the cloud
additionalFields.headline: Amazon Web Services Achieves FedRAMP High Authorization
additionalFields.Source: AWS Government, Education, and Nonprofits Blog

item.name: AWS Public Sector Summit 2016 - Fireside Chat With Andy Jassy, CEO and Teresa Carlson, VP WWPS

additionalFields.Description:
Check out some coverage following the fireside chat between Andy Jassy and Teresa Carlson at the AWS Public Sector Summit in Washington, DC. This fireside chat covered topics like the future of AWS, and the factors that have driven customers to move to the cloud.

  • Fortune: Amazon Cloud Chief Says New Customers Weigh Many Clouds, but End Up with One
  • Business Insider: The CEO of Amazon's most profitable unit explains how it’s putting pressure on companies like Oracle
  • GeekWire: Amazon Web Services CEO Andy Jassy: Virtually every major country will have an AWS region
additionalFields.headline: AWS Public Sector Summit 2016 - Fireside Chat With Andy Jassy, CEO and Teresa Carlson, VP WWPS

item.name: Learn About the New AWS Government Competency

additionalFields.Description:
Check out some great coverage following the launch of the AWS Government Competency. Government Competency Partners provide solutions to—and/or have deep experience working with—government customers to deliver mission-critical workloads and applications on AWS. For a full list of launch partners, check out the APN blog post.

  • CRN: AWS Introduces Government Competency To Partner Program
  • Talkin’ Cloud: AWS Doubles Down on Government Cloud with New Partner Competency, Program
  • Channelnomics: AWS' new government competency
additionalFields.headline: Learn About the New AWS Government Competency

item.name: Spin Class 2.0: When fitness meets the cloud, data and gamification

additionalFields.Description: ZDNet profiles how startup Peloton is utilizing the AWS Cloud to run its servers, power its real-time platform and maintain a virtual cluster of about 300 machines. With this, the company is able to host thousands of people on the platform simultaneously.
additionalFields.headline: Spin Class 2.0: When fitness meets the cloud, data and gamification

item.name: Will Amazon’s IC Marketplace Disrupt IT Acquisition?

additionalFields.Description: NextGov covers how the AWS Marketplace for the U.S. Intelligence Community (IC) aims to change the status quo for how the 17 intelligence agencies will buy technology. With this Marketplace, AWS is offering an alternative to large-scale software acquisitions that have cost taxpayers $10 billion over the last 10 years.
additionalFields.headline: Will Amazon’s IC Marketplace Disrupt IT Acquisition?

item.name: Amazon Web Services Signs CJIS Agreement with the State of Colorado

additionalFields.Description: AWS has signed a Criminal Justice Information Services (CJIS) agreement with the State of Colorado that will allow law enforcement throughout the state to leverage cloud technology in ways that increase IT and data security, improve operational efficiencies, and provide access to next-generation technologies and tools.
additionalFields.headline: Amazon Web Services Signs CJIS Agreement with the State of Colorado

item.name: C3 IoT, AWS tighten Internet of things, cloud integration

additionalFields.Description: Following the announcement of their “all-in” status with AWS, ZDNet highlights C3 IoT’s announcement that it will deliver a tightly integrated, end-to-end platform as a service that accelerates organizations’ success with Industrial Internet of Things (IIoT) applications and other big data initiatives based on AWS.
additionalFields.headline: C3 IoT, AWS tighten Internet of things, cloud integration

item.name: Is the role of CIO changing?

additionalFields.Description: Following comments made by Teresa Carlson, AWS’s Vice President of Worldwide Public Sector, at the Defense One Summit, C4ISR & Networks covered how the role of the CIO in government agencies and companies has evolved into an essential role as the face of the technology office.
additionalFields.headline: Is the role of CIO changing?

item.name: Big data is a big reason government IT is embracing Amazon Web Services

additionalFields.Description: Tech Republic profiles how APN partner BlueCanopy is using the AWS Cloud to provide IT and cyber security solutions to US government and commercial enterprises. BlueCanopy says this about AWS, “For us, Amazon has the most mature and capable cloud environment. It lets us get things done quickly for our clients—and that's what we want to do.”
additionalFields.headline: Big data is a big reason government IT is embracing Amazon Web Services

item.name: New AWS Competency – AWS Migration

additionalFields.Description:
Check out some great coverage following the launch of the AWS Migration Competency. AWS Migration Competency Partners provide solutions and have deep experience helping businesses move successfully to AWS, through all phases of a complex migration projects – discovery, planning, migration and operations. For the full list of launch partners, check out the APN blog post.

  • CRN: AWS Launches Migration Competency
  • Forbes: Amazon Launches New Partner Competency To Target Enterprise Cloud Migrations
  • GeekWire: Amazon Web Services starts certifying partners that help customers move to the cloud
additionalFields.headline: New AWS Competency – AWS Migration

item.name: Omaha, surrounding county move government websites to AWS cloud

additionalFields.Description: StateScoop profiles how the Douglas-Omaha Technology Commission is in the midst of moving their government websites from on premises to the AWS Cloud. Despite facing some initial resistance in securing the funds to make this migration happen, Vijay Badal, the commission’s director of application service, noted that the transition could save the city and county roughly $800,000. The article concludes, “Knock on wood, we haven’t had a single outage on any of our sites on AWS, and none of our sites have been compromised…that’s huge, in and of itself.”
additionalFields.headline: Omaha, surrounding county move government websites to AWS cloud

item.name: Banking on the cloud

additionalFields.Description: Check out this great article how various financial companies such as FINRA, Bankinter (Spain), and the Commonwealth Bank of Australia are using the AWS Cloud to drive down costs, enable innovation, and create the flexibility needed to respond to change.
additionalFields.headline: Banking on the cloud

item.name: A Texas-sized cloud storage challenge

additionalFields.Description: GCN profiles how the Texas State Library and Archives Commission (TSLAC) worked with AWS Partner Preservica to securely preserve all the records produced during former Gov. Rick Perry’s administration into AWS GovCloud. With Preservica’s help, TSLAC was able to move over 30TB of data into AWS. Of the move, Preservica CEO Jonathan Tilbury says, “Cloud gives the opportunity to get started within days. And you get updates instantly, the cost is lower, so it’s a better service and it’s cheaper. What’s not to like?”
additionalFields.headline: A Texas-sized cloud storage challenge

item.name: Salesforce Selects AWS as Preferred Public Cloud Infrastructure Provider

additionalFields.Description:
Check out some great coverage following an announcement that Salesforce has selected AWS as its preferred public cloud infrastructure provider. Salesforce will expand use of AWS to core services—including Sales Cloud, Service Cloud, App Cloud, Community Cloud, Analytics Cloud and more—for the company’s planned international infrastructure expansion.

  • The New York Times: Salesforce to Use Amazon’s Cloud to Expand in Canada and Australia
  • The Wall Street Journal: In $400 Million Deal, Salesforce to Piggyback on Amazon’s Growing Cloud
  • ZDNet: Salesforce and AWS pair up: Here's what it means for cloud computing
additionalFields.headline: Salesforce Selects AWS as Preferred Public Cloud Infrastructure Provider

item.name: Singapore retailer shifts IT infrastructure to the cloud

additionalFields.Description: Computer Weekly profiles how Singapore electronics retailer Challenger worked with AWS Partner Network member Datapipe to move its point-of-sale, enterprise resource planning and online marketplaces to AWS. With this move, Challenger reduced the time it takes to get IT infrastructure set up for new stores from up to eight weeks to a matter of days, enabling it to easily automate and scale infrastructure.
additionalFields.headline: Singapore retailer shifts IT infrastructure to the cloud

item.name: a16z Podcast: The Cloud and The Public Sector

additionalFields.Description: Check out this podcast with Teresa Carlson, Vice President of Worldwide Public Sector, as she explains how public sector customers and governments around the globe are adopting, and benefiting from the AWS Cloud.
additionalFields.headline: a16z Podcast: The Cloud and The Public Sector

item.name: 2016 Women of the Channel

additionalFields.Description: Congratulations to AWS’ Dorothy Copeland, Director of the Global Partner Program, for being named one of CRN’s Power 100 Vendors which highlights “female executives whose insight and influence help drive channel success.”
additionalFields.headline: 2016 Women of the Channel

item.name: Global tech leader Sabre takes to the cloud and announces collaboration with Amazon Web Services to deliver new travel solutions

additionalFields.Description: Travel technology leader Sabre Corporation announced today that it will offer faster cloud-based flight availability using solutions built on the AWS Cloud. With these solutions, airline carriers will house their availability data in the AWS Cloud and manage availability for different channels through one source, thus allowing customers to benefit from faster shopping. Of this collaboration, Tom Klein, president and CEO of Sabre says, “Our customers use Sabre solutions because they want only the best, and the AWS relationship will further enhance our ability to deliver even faster and better offerings.”
additionalFields.headline: Global tech leader Sabre takes to the cloud and announces collaboration with Amazon Web Services to deliver new travel solutions

item.name: Highlights from the AWS Sydney Summit

additionalFields.Description:
Check out some of the stories from the AWS Sydney Summit, including coverage about how customers are migrating to the AWS Cloud in Australia, how high school students are learning about new careers in the cloud, and how Australian customers are already deploying new services such as AWS Snowball.

  • ARN: AWS Snowball gets first Australian deployment
  • The Australian Financial Review: Kid entrepreneurs have amazing opportunities, says Amazon tech chief
  • The Australian Financial Review: Cloud computing gives local businesses an edge
  • ZDNet Australia: Qantas.com takes AWS route to the cloud
additionalFields.headline: Highlights from the AWS Sydney Summit

item.name: Why banks are finally cashing in on the public cloud

additionalFields.Description: CIO profiles how banks including Capitol One and World Bank are overcoming their fears about security and regulatory risks, and moving their data to the cloud. Under the guidance of Stephanie von Friedeburg, CIO of World Bank, the bank began migrating several functions to the AWS Cloud and now has a goal to reduce its data center footprint from five to one.
additionalFields.headline: Why banks are finally cashing in on the public cloud

item.name: Chicago Bank finds Public Cloud Ready for Prime Time

additionalFields.Description: Network World covers how the Federal Home Loan Bank (FHLB) of Chicago migrated most of its IT functions into the AWS Cloud, including its enterprise resource planning (ERP) system, human resources system, and core IT apps. Regarding any potential security concerns, Eric Geiger, vice president of IT operations for the bank says, “I just simply don’t believe that a traditional data center hosted somewhere in Chicago is going to be more secure than Amazon.”
additionalFields.headline: Chicago Bank finds Public Cloud Ready for Prime Time

item.name: Texas teams with AWS to overhaul Alamo website

additionalFields.Description: StateScoop profiles how the Texas General Land Office worked with AWS to develop a new cloud-based website for the Alamo in order to keep up with the bandwidth demands of over 250,000 visitors that visit the website each month.
additionalFields.headline: Texas teams with AWS to overhaul Alamo website

item.name: Amazon Steps Up Blockchain Commitment; Web Services Partners With Digital Currency Group

additionalFields.Description: AWS Partner Digital Currency Group is collaborating with AWS to provide a platform for blockchain experimentation on the AWS Cloud so that blockchain providers in DCG’s portfolio can work in a secure environment with clients including financial institutions, insurance companies, and enterprise technology companies. This will help make financial services more efficient, as well as lower costs.
additionalFields.headline: Amazon Steps Up Blockchain Commitment; Web Services Partners With Digital Currency Group

item.name: Amazon Cracks Code on How to Attract Innovators to Federal Market

additionalFields.Description: National Defense Magazine covers how the adoption of AWS in the intelligence community has made it easier for government buyers to procure software, and created new channels for vendors to sell products. With the cloud, the government can buy IT services for one-tenth of the cost of traditional approaches, while meeting stringent security requirements.
additionalFields.headline: Amazon Cracks Code on How to Attract Innovators to Federal Market

item.name: Researchers discover benefits of freedom to fail in the cloud

additionalFields.Description: The Australian covers how researchers are leveraging cloud computing services to crunch vast volumes of data and co-ordinate the efforts of scientists across the globe, highlighting the Australian Museum’s Australian Centre for Wildlife Genomics efforts in mapping the koala’s genome. Glenn Gore, Asia-Pacific head of technology for AWS, says that for researchers, the flexibility and scalability offered by AWS gives them more freedom to experiment.
additionalFields.headline: Researchers discover benefits of freedom to fail in the cloud

item.name: How do cloud services platforms compare?

additionalFields.Description: ReadWrite highlights the many benefits AWS offers developers, including the variety of networking, storage, databases, and delivery/deployment options available. With AWS, enterprises can quickly drill down to locate problems and resolve them before end users are impacted by an issue, while bottlenecks or underperforming services can be isolated for review.
additionalFields.headline: How do cloud services platforms compare?

item.name: Highlights from the AWS Chicago Summit

additionalFields.Description:
Check out some great coverage following announcements made at the AWS Summit in Chicago, including the launch of two new volume types for Amazon Elastic Block Store (EBS), the general availability of Amazon Inspector, and various other capabilities to help customers migrate existing workloads to AWS.

  • ZDNet: Amazon Web Services launches security service, more cloud storage options
  • TechTarget: New AWS migration tools target big data behind a firewall
  • ComputerWorld: AWS powers new big data services with giant hard disks
additionalFields.headline: Highlights from the AWS Chicago Summit

item.name: GE Oil & Gas Finds Amazon Use Lowers TCO 52%

additionalFields.Description: InformationWeek covers how GE Oil & Gas is moving hundreds of applications to the AWS Cloud, using numerous AWS services including AWS Snowball, Amazon Aurora, and AWS Elastic Beanstalk. GE Oil & Gas says that on average, applications moved into the cloud had a 52% reduced cost of ownership compared to on-premises applications.
additionalFields.headline: GE Oil & Gas Finds Amazon Use Lowers TCO 52%

item.name: National Championship gives Villanova's website huge traffic boost

additionalFields.Description: The Philadelphia Business Journal details how Villanova University used the AWS Cloud during the NCAA Basketball Championship Game to accommodate increased traffic when visitors to the website more than quadrupled from 40,000 to 190,000. Gabe Monteleone, Assistant Vice President of enterprise applications at Villanova University explains, “Back in 2012, we were trying to figure out how we could support the web environment at the university. With the Amazon web hosting cloud, we can now manage it through that application, and we have an environment that’s much more scalable…When we made the run at the Final Four this year, we were able to scale properly.”
additionalFields.headline: National Championship gives Villanova's website huge traffic boost

item.name: Review: Amazon Web Services is eating the world

additionalFields.Description: Check out this article rounding up the array of features, services, and options offered by AWS for our customers. The article highlights how AWS delivers the simplest way to create complex, highly scalable, data-rich applications and provides programmers and data analysts with cheaper and faster tools and services.
additionalFields.headline: Review: Amazon Web Services is eating the world

item.name: Interview: Dr. Michael Ernst from Brookhaven National Laboratory

additionalFields.Description: insideBigData interviews Dr. Michael Ernst, Director of the Relativistic Heavy Ion Collider (RHIC) and ATLAS Computing Facility at Brookhaven National Laboratory, to discuss how the laboratory is using Amazon EC2 Spot instances when working with CERN’s Large Hadron Collider ATLAS experiment in order to speed up research during critical time periods. The article ends with a quote from Dr. Ernst, “[With Spot instances], we can provision thousands of compute cores within a few hours when we need them, something that is impossible with traditional infrastructure.”
additionalFields.headline: Interview: Dr. Michael Ernst from Brookhaven National Laboratory

item.name: Billing by Millionths of Pennies, Cloud Computing’s Giants Take In Billions

additionalFields.Description: The New York Times explores how cloud computing companies, like AWS, are using micro-pricing to enable customers to pay for IT resources only in the moments that they use them. AWS Lambda is one such service that offers this; at $0.20 per 1 million requests. Matt Wood, general manager of product strategy at AWS, is quoted in the article as saying, “The scale at which we operate allows us to do innovative things…When we get better economies of scale, we’ll use that to our advantage.”
additionalFields.headline: Billing by Millionths of Pennies, Cloud Computing’s Giants Take In Billions

item.name: NOAA is Hosting More Weather Data in the Cloud

additionalFields.Description: NextGov profiles the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration’s (NOAA) Big Data Project, where the agency hosted government-collected environmental data on the AWS Cloud, thus slashing the workload on its archive systems, freeing up bandwidth and resources on constrained legacy systems. By running models in the cloud, NOAA was able to reduce infrastructure technology costs and improve their time to market by two to three weeks.
additionalFields.headline: NOAA is Hosting More Weather Data in the Cloud

item.name: The 2016 Federal 100

additionalFields.Description:
Congratulations to the following AWS customers for being awarded the Federal 100 Awards that recognizes government and industry leaders who have played pivotal roles in the federal government IT community and have made a difference in the way technology has transformed their agency or accelerated their agency's mission.

  • Energy Department: Michael Ernst
  • National Geospatial-Intelligence Agency: Sue Gordon
  • General Services Administration: Noah Kunin
  • International Trade Administration, Commerce Department: Joe Paiva
  • Department of the Treasury: Timothy Womack
additionalFields.headline: The 2016 Federal 100

item.name: How Partnering With AWS Helped MSP’s Revenue Soar

additionalFields.Description: Jason Deck, vice president of strategic development for Logicworks, shares with IT Best of Breed its journey toward becoming a Premier Partner in the AWS Partner Network, and the success the company is seeing as more clients demand value-added services around their AWS environments. For information on the various AWS Partner Programs, visit our site.
additionalFields.headline: How Partnering With AWS Helped MSP’s Revenue Soar

item.name: iPods, dinner parties and the cure for cancer: How Seattle scientists, cloud companies collaborate

additionalFields.Description: Check out this great article from the Puget Sound Business Journal covering how cancer researchers are utilizing the computing power of the cloud to map human genomes and develop cancer treatments. Dr. Hy Levitsky, chief science officer at AWS customer Juno Therapeutics, says, “[Cancer researchers] absolutely have needed and benefited now from computational tools that can work with these databases in a way that allows the picture to emerge.”
additionalFields.headline: iPods, dinner parties and the cure for cancer: How Seattle scientists, cloud companies collaborate

item.name: For IT, climate change means preparing for disaster

additionalFields.Description: Computerworld covers how companies are starting to migrate to the cloud in order to improve disaster recovery tools and systems. The article highlights the New York City Department of Transportation’s (DoT) usage of the AWS cloud as part of its disaster recovery strategy. New York’s DoT CTO, Cordell Schachter, says, “If you're not in the cloud in some way right now -- even if it's just for testing purposes -- it's really malpractice if you're in IT.”
additionalFields.headline: For IT, climate change means preparing for disaster

item.name: Rackspace opens up Fanatical Support for AWS in ANZ market

additionalFields.Description: Rackspace announced Fanatical Support for Amazon Web Services for Australian and New Zealand businesses, with AWS customer Simpology already taking advantage of the offering. Of this partnership, Stefan Jansen, Head of Channels and Alliances for AWS Australia and New Zealand, says the services Rackspace is offering will bring added choice to the rapidly growing AWS customer base across all segments in the region.
additionalFields.headline: Rackspace opens up Fanatical Support for AWS in ANZ market

item.name: Fuelling innovation with cloud computing

additionalFields.Description: In this article, Shane Owenby, Managing Director for AWS Asia-Pacific, highlights how cloud computing plays a pivotal role in helping Singapore’s small and medium enterprises manage operating costs and expand their business globally, as well as overcome limited capital and manpower limitations. The article features AWS customer’s RedMart and redBus. To learn more about building and scaling startups on AWS, visit this page.
additionalFields.headline: Fuelling innovation with cloud computing

item.name: Chicago Releases User-Friendly Open Data Tool

additionalFields.Description: Tom Schenk Jr., Chicago’s chief data officer highlights the benefits of OpenGrid, an open-source tool that plots the city’s data sets on an easy-to-read map and supports data retrieval and real-time analytics that will soon be available on the AWS Marketplace. The City of Chicago won AWS’s City on a Cloud Innovation Challenge last November for OpenGrid, and used the award of $50,000 in AWS credits to ensure cloud scalability for the tool. To learn more about how government agencies, educational institutions, and non-profits are innovating on the AWS Cloud, visit our Public Sector page.
additionalFields.headline: Chicago Releases User-Friendly Open Data Tool

item.name: Person of the Year: Amazon Web Services’ Andy Jassy

additionalFields.Description: Check out this great article focusing on the history and culture of AWS and highlighting Andy Jassy’s 2016 Financial Times Boldness in Business Person of the Year award.
additionalFields.headline: Person of the Year: Amazon Web Services’ Andy Jassy

item.name: CloudNOW Announces Top 10 Cloud Evangelists, 2016

additionalFields.Description: Congratulations to AWS’ Technical Evangelist, Tara Walker, for being named one of the Top 10 Cloud Evangelists who has “contributed to the astronomical growth of cloud, open source, and converging technologies.”
additionalFields.headline: CloudNOW Announces Top 10 Cloud Evangelists, 2016

item.name: GPO Taps Amazon Web Services for Library Mgmt System Cloud Migration

additionalFields.Description: ExecutiveBiz covers news that the U.S. Government Publishing Office (GPO) has started to transition its public-facing websites to the AWS Cloud, in an effort to comply with the government-wide Federal Cloud First policy. Chuck Riddle, chief information officer of the GPO, is quoted as saying, “Moving these sites to the cloud demonstrates our ongoing commitment to leverage the best technology tools to support GPO’s mission of keeping America informed.” To learn more about how AWS supports the U.S. government, visit our public sector page.
additionalFields.headline: GPO Taps Amazon Web Services for Library Mgmt System Cloud Migration

item.name: Amazon to Launch Cloud Migration Service

additionalFields.Description: The Wall Street Journal profiles AWS customer Thomas Publishing Co., a 118-year-old company that is using the new AWS Database Migration Service. Now generally available, the AWS Database Migration Service helps customers migrate databases from Oracle to Amazon Aurora. On the move, Thomas chief technical officer Hans Wald said, “We want to be out of the business of running data centers.” Learn more about the AWS Database Migration Service here.
additionalFields.headline: Amazon to Launch Cloud Migration Service

item.name: Ten Years in the AWS Cloud – How Time Flies!

additionalFields.Description:
A decade ago today, AWS officially launched with the availability of our first service, Amazon S3, on March 14, 2006. Since then, over a million active customers across 190 countries ranging from startups to enterprises and government agencies to educational institutions have adopted the AWS Cloud. Check out some great blog posts highlighting how our customers use AWS services to deliver unique solutions, as well as what AWS executives have learned from 10 years in the business.

  • AWS Blog: Flatiron Health – Using AWS to Help Improve Cancer Treatment
  • AWS Blog: Hot Startups on AWS – March 2016
  • All Things Distributed: 10 Lessons from 10 Years of Amazon Web Services
additionalFields.headline: Ten Years in the AWS Cloud – How Time Flies!

item.name: This company migrated to the cloud to get BETTER security

additionalFields.Description: In an interview with Network World, SCOR Velogica’s Chief Information Security Officer, Clarke Rodgers, details the company’s decision to move to AWS, highlighting security, scalability, and pace of innovation. He says, “The security benefits are fantastic, because I now effectively have an extended security team working 24/7 on my behalf.  I have AWS’ security team working for me ensuring that its core infrastructure and services are running in a secure fashion.”
additionalFields.headline: This company migrated to the cloud to get BETTER security

item.name: Why Amazon Web Services Has So Many Friends in the Startup World

additionalFields.Description: DC Inno covers how AWS has lowered the barrier for entry in cloud computing and next-gen data storage markets for startups, focusing on AWS customers Shutterstock and VideoBlocks. VideoBlocks chairman, Joel Holland, is quoted as saying that “AWS has given us the time, resources and focus to build great products and grow the company,” and that it allows the company to intelligently allocate resources for specific sets of content.
additionalFields.headline: Why Amazon Web Services Has So Many Friends in the Startup World

item.name: Carter's Innovation Push Hits Seattle With Cloud Focus

additionalFields.Description: Defense News covered US Secretary of Defense Ash Carter’s visit to Seattle where he met with Amazon, Boeing, and Microsoft to learn more about cloud technologies. . To learn more about how AWS supports the US government, visit our public sector page.
additionalFields.headline: Carter's Innovation Push Hits Seattle With Cloud Focus

item.name: AWS Offers Data Egress Discount to Researchers

additionalFields.Description: AWS has committed to making it easier for scientists to use its cloud storage, computing, and database services by waiving data egress fees for qualified researchers and academic customers. By reducing data egress fees, AWS will to help scientists launch computing machines in minutes, analyze data pipelines, and store petabytes of data in the cloud, ultimately accelerating time-to-science. Visit our Scientific Computing on AWS page to learn more about how AWS helps researchers accelerate time-to-science.
additionalFields.headline: AWS Offers Data Egress Discount to Researchers

item.name: Kiwi AWS cloud loyalty deepens as Fly Buys takes to the skies

additionalFields.Description: Resellernews covers Loyalty New Zealand’s use of the AWS cloud to create a new platform to manage their customer’s transactions and accounts. Loyalty CTO Duanne O’Brien says, “Having a multi-account, multi-member and multi-token system via AWS allows us to provide effortless everyday experiences to customers.” O’Brien also added that Loyalty’s strategy is to eventually move all core and channel applications into the AWS cloud.
additionalFields.headline: Kiwi AWS cloud loyalty deepens as Fly Buys takes to the skies

item.name: Cities Will Soon Be Able Deploy Chicago’s Geographic Information System With a Simple Click

additionalFields.Description: Tom Schenk Jr., Chicago’s chief data officer details how the city of Chicago plans to put OpenGrid on AWS Marketplace in the coming weeks, a milestone in making the city’s real-time situational awareness and geographic information system available to other governments. The City of Chicago won AWS’s City on a Cloud Innovation Challenge last November for OpenGrid, and used the award of $50,000 in AWS credits to ensure cloud scalability for the tool. To learn more about how government agencies, educational institutions, and non-profits are innovating on the AWS Cloud, visit our Public Sector page.
additionalFields.headline: Cities Will Soon Be Able Deploy Chicago’s Geographic Information System With a Simple Click

item.name: Accelerating Cloud Transformation for Telecom Providers – Ericsson and AWS

additionalFields.Description:
Check out some great coverage following AWS Consulting Partner Ericsson’s announcement at Mobile World Congress that they are partnering with AWS to help telecom service providers get up to speed on using AWS infrastructure. This is part of a broader push by Ericsson to move telecommunications service providers to adopt cloud services to run more efficient mobile services.

  • Fortune: Ericsson Cozies Up to Amazon
  • Reuters [U.K.]: Ericsson forms alliance with Amazon Web Services for telcos
  • VentureBeat: Amazon and Ericsson form telco alliance for cloud services
additionalFields.headline: Accelerating Cloud Transformation for Telecom Providers – Ericsson and AWS

item.name: Blog: VA to Reimburse Veterans for AWS Certification Exam

additionalFields.Description: Signal Magazine highlights an agreement AWS made with the Department of Veteran Affairs that allows U.S. military veterans to seek reimbursement for AWS Certification exam costs. With this agreement, AWS will open up more career possibilities for retired servicemen and servicewomen. Learn more about the benefit here.
additionalFields.headline: Blog: VA to Reimburse Veterans for AWS Certification Exam

item.name: Navman Wireless ditches co-lo for cloud

additionalFields.Description: ComputerWorld reports on AWS customer Navman Wireless’s decision to us AWS for its GPS fleet-tracking application. Ian Daniel, the company’s APAC Vice-President says of the decision to use AWS, “There’s all these really good niche players in market, but at the end of the day we are a global business, so it was very logical for us to have that relationship with someone that was a global player… If we want to get into Japan, we can get there in a heartbeat because we know Amazon Web Services is on the ground in Japan.”
additionalFields.headline: Navman Wireless ditches co-lo for cloud

item.name: Amazon Web Services to Acquire NICE

additionalFields.Description:
A few “In the News” highlights following the announcement that AWS is acquiring NICE, an Italian software and services company. NICE develops products to help customers optimize and centralize their high performance computing (HPC) and visualization workloads while also providing tools that are a great fit for distributed workforces.

  • TechCrunch: AWS Bolsters High Performance Computing Offering With NICE Acquisition
  • VentureBeat: Nice, the high-performance computing company Amazon just acquired, has a heck of a customer list
  • ZDNet: Cloud computing: Here comes the shift from price war to feature war
additionalFields.headline: Amazon Web Services to Acquire NICE

item.name: Netflix finishes its massive migration to the Amazon cloud

additionalFields.Description: Ars Technica reports on AWS customer Netflix’s complete migration of its streaming operations to the AWS Cloud. Netflix’s shift to AWS allows for improved availability of its streaming operations at a lower cost. Of the migration Netflix says, “Elasticity of the cloud allows us to add thousands of virtual servers and petabytes of storage within minutes, making such an expansion possible.”
additionalFields.headline: Netflix finishes its massive migration to the Amazon cloud

item.name: Lumberyard + Amazon GameLift + Twitch for Games on AWS

additionalFields.Description:
Check out these “In the News” highlights from the announcement of Amazon Lumberyard and Amazon GameLift. Amazon Lumberyard is a cross-platform 3D game engine that simplifies and streamlines game development and is natively integrated to the AWS Cloud. Amazon GameLift is a managed service for deploying, operating, and scaling session-based multiplayer games that allows developers to quickly scale game servers up and down to meet player demand. Read more about Amazon Lumberyard here and Amazon GameLift here.

  • PCMag: Need Help Creating a Game? Try Amazon Lumberyard
  • TechCrunch: AWS Announces New Set Of Integrated Services Aimed At Game Developers
  • ZDNet: Amazon courts game developers with launch of dev engine Lumberyard
additionalFields.headline: Lumberyard + Amazon GameLift + Twitch for Games on AWS

item.name: Congratulations to the 2016 Fed 100

additionalFields.Description: FCW has published its list of the 2016 Federal 100. Congratulations to AWS customers Department of Commerce, Department of Energy’s Brookhaven National Laboratory, and Department of the Treasury. Always great to see AWS customers and partners recognized for their innovative use of cloud technology!
additionalFields.headline: Congratulations to the 2016 Fed 100

item.name: Arkansas’ Popular Highway App Would Be Nothing Without the Cloud

additionalFields.Description: Route 50 takes a look at how the Information Network of Arkansas’ is using AWS and highlights the important role it plays in offering scalable, easy to use, and reliable services for the state’s users. To learn more about how government agencies, educational institutions, and non-profits are innovating on the AWS Cloud, visit our Public Sector page.
additionalFields.headline: Arkansas’ Popular Highway App Would Be Nothing Without the Cloud

item.name: Brookhaven Lab Finds AWS Spot Instances Hit Sweet Spot

additionalFields.Description: InformationWeek details AWS customer Brookhaven National Laboratory’s use of Amazon EC2 Spot Instances to expand its compute power for particle research without exceeding its research budget. Lead computer scientist Michael Ernst for Brookhaven’s ATLAS team, says, “AWS has superb availability…It appears to have unlimited capacity at competitive prices.” Read more about Amazon EC2 Spot Instances here.
additionalFields.headline: Brookhaven Lab Finds AWS Spot Instances Hit Sweet Spot

item.name: Buying Cloud Services: What the U.S. Can Learn from the UK

additionalFields.Description: GovExec’s Frank Konkel reports on the UK government’s G-Cloud contract that is designed to make it easier for government agencies to connect cloud providers with its Digital Marketplace of cloud service suppliers available through pre-vetted vendors working on six-month acquisition cycles. Teresa Carlson, Vice President of AWS’s Worldwide Public Sector business is quoted as saying, “The G-Cloud contract completely disrupted the way they do acquisitions in the government.”
additionalFields.headline: Buying Cloud Services: What the U.S. Can Learn from the UK

item.name: 65% Say Cloud As Secure As On-Premises

additionalFields.Description: InformationWeek’s Charlie Babcock highlights a just-released report from the Cloud Security Alliance (CSA) which says that nearly two-thirds of IT security officers and managers think the cloud is at least as secure as their on-premises software. This echoes opinions expressed by AWS customer Capital One’s Financial CIO, Robert Alexander, who said that AWS was more secure for hosting his firm’s next mobile banking application than most enterprise data centers.
additionalFields.headline: 65% Say Cloud As Secure As On-Premises

item.name: Why Los Angeles Moved Its Alternate Emergency Operations Center to the Cloud

additionalFields.Description: Ted Ross, General Manager of the city of Los Angeles’s Information Technology Agency (ITA)  details ITA’s use of AWS’s geographically decentralized crisis management system. By migrating key municipal apps and data onto AWS, the ITA has created a scalable and sustainable virtual operations center that is able to handle everything from evacuation tracking to volunteer and donation management. To learn more about how government agencies, educational institutions, and non-profits are innovating on the AWS Cloud, visit our Public Sector page.
additionalFields.headline: Why Los Angeles Moved Its Alternate Emergency Operations Center to the Cloud

item.name: AWS Lambda leads charge in event-driven computing

additionalFields.Description: TechTarget highlights AWS Lambda and how the event-based automation service eases the management of computing resources for customers. The article features AWS customers StackStorm, BetaBrand, VidRoll and Edeva, and how they are utilizing AWS Lambda to achieve infrastructure management at a massive scale. James Young, CTO for Vidroll is quoted as saying, “Having the ability to use [AWS] Lambda allowed us not to have to worry about the underpinnings of how to keep the servers up.”
additionalFields.headline: AWS Lambda leads charge in event-driven computing

item.name: Amazon Wind Farm Fowler Ridge is Live!

additionalFields.Description:
Check out these “In the News” highlights following the announcement that the Amazon Wind Farm Fowler Ridge is now live. This wind farm marks the first of AWS’s four announced renewable energy projects to go live, all crucial components of our long-term commitment to achieve 100% renewable energy for our global infrastructure footprint.

  • Clean Technica: Pattern Energy Completes 150 MW Amazon Wind Farm Fowler Ridge
  • Windpower: Pattern Energy completes 150-MW Amazon Wind Farm in Indiana
  • North American Wind Power: Amazon Wind Farm Fowler Ridge Goes Online In Indiana
additionalFields.headline: Amazon Wind Farm Fowler Ridge is Live!

item.name: Tapping the power of connected data through the cloud

additionalFields.Description: AWS’s Shane Owenby, Managing Director for AWS Asia-Pacific, details how various verticals are innovating and disrupting their own ecosystems with the cloud, specifically highlighting AWS customers in the healthcare, location and finance industries. Shane concludes, “The cloud has become the ‘new normal.’ Given the large volume of data that is generated and processed by connected devices today, it is impossible to do it anywhere else efficiently but the cloud.”
additionalFields.headline: Tapping the power of connected data through the cloud

item.name: New – Scheduled Reserved Instances

additionalFields.Description:
A few “In the News” highlights following the announcement of Scheduled Reserved Instances. Customers are now able to reserve Amazon EC2 capacity on a recurring basis with a daily, weekly, or monthly schedule over the course of a one-year term. This feature is available in the US East, US West and Europe regions, with support for the C3, C4, M4 and R3 instances.

  • TechCrunch:  AWS Launches Schedules Reserved Instances
  • ZDNet: AWS now lets customers reserve scheduled, recurring instances
  • VentureBeat: Amazon’s new AWS Scheduled Reserved Instances save you up to 10%
additionalFields.headline: New – Scheduled Reserved Instances

item.name: Interview: Building The Latest Campaign For David Guetta

additionalFields.Description: In an interview with Serverless Code, AWS customer James Hall from parall.ax, talks about how the company used AWS Lambda to build an international app for DJ David Guetta’s marketing campaign in just six weeks. James explains, “Writing a simple Lambda function and letting Amazon do all the hard work seemed like the obvious choice.” Learn more about AWS Lambda here.
additionalFields.headline: Interview: Building The Latest Campaign For David Guetta

item.name: In the Works – AWS Region in Canada

additionalFields.Description:
A few “In the News” highlights following the announcement of an AWS region in Montreal, Québec, Canada in the coming year. This region will be carbon-neutral and powered almost entirely by clean, renewable hydro power. This is the 5th region in North America, and the 12th globally. Read more about our global footprint here.

  • ZDNet: Oh, Canada: Amazon Web Services prepping new region in Québec this year
  • Bloomberg: Amazon Will Open First Cloud Data Storage Centers in Canada
additionalFields.headline: In the Works – AWS Region in Canada

item.name: Customer obsession and "partnering with partners" will drive AWS in 2016

additionalFields.Description: ARN highlights the growing Amazon Web Services Partner Network (APN) and how it enables AWS to deliver more solutions to our global customers. The article quotes AWS’s Stefan Jansen throughout regarding plans for the year ahead: “We are trying to bring our partner communities much closer together, you will see us showcasing those partners who do well and making sure they get the level of visibility to our customers.”
additionalFields.headline: Customer obsession and "partnering with partners" will drive AWS in 2016

item.name: And the cloud provider with the best uptime in 2015 is…

additionalFields.Description: Gartner-owned CloudHarmony’s 2015 analysis of downtime at IaaS public cloud providers reveals that AWS had the least downtime of all major cloud vendors. Network World’s Brandon Butler reports that “despite having the largest cloud offering on the market, Amazon Web Services had the least amount of outages among major vendors.”
additionalFields.headline: And the cloud provider with the best uptime in 2015 is…

item.name: Now Open – AWS Asia Pacific (Seoul) Region

additionalFields.Description:
Check out some great coverage announcing our newest region in Seoul, South Korea. AWS customers in the area can take advantage of the new Asia Pacific (Seoul) region for fast, low-latency access to the suite of AWS infrastructure services. Learn more about our global footprint here. 

  • Data Center Knowledge: Amazon Launches Its First Cloud Data Centers in Korea
  • TechWeek Europe: AWS Powers Up Korean Data Centres As Fifth Asia Pacific Region Goes Live
  • ZDNet: AWS launches datacentres in Korea
additionalFields.headline: Now Open – AWS Asia Pacific (Seoul) Region

item.name: Happy New Year – EC2 Price Reduction (C4, M4 and R3 Instances)

additionalFields.Description:
Check out these “In the News” highlights from the announcement of our 51st price reduction for Amazon EC2. These price cuts affect the C4, M4 and R3 instances.

  • CRN: AWS Delivers More Price Cuts To Ring In 2016
  • Fortune: Amazon Rings in the New Year With Cloud Price Cuts
  • ZDNet: AWS cuts prices for select instances
additionalFields.headline: Happy New Year – EC2 Price Reduction (C4, M4 and R3 Instances)

item.name: Amazon WorkMail — Now Generally Available

additionalFields.Description:
A few “In the News” highlights from this week’s announcement that Amazon WorkMail is now generally available in three AWS regions ((US East (Northern Virginia), US West (Oregon), and Europe (Ireland)). Amazon WorkMail is a managed calendaring and email solution that runs in the Cloud and works with existing desktop and mobile clients. Learn more about it here.

  • IDG News Service: Amazon WorkMail can now be yours for $4 per user per month
  • TechCrunch: Amazon’s Email And Calendaring Service, Amazon WorkMail, Exits Preview
  • VentureBeat: AWS launches WorkMail email and calendar service out of preview
additionalFields.headline: Amazon WorkMail — Now Generally Available

item.name: The High Costs Of Hosting Science's Big Data: The Commercial Cloud To The Rescue?

additionalFields.Description: Non-profit organizations like the National Institutes of Health (NIH) are using the cloud to tackle big data challenges, along with making genetic data more accessible and cost effective. The article concludes, “As the academic enterprise moves towards a future ever more entwined with the world of big data, it faces new challenges in supporting the contemporary needs and long term preservation of data intensive research and offers a powerful new application area for the cloud.”
additionalFields.headline: The High Costs Of Hosting Science's Big Data: The Commercial Cloud To The Rescue?

item.name: Amazon Primes Its Cloud to Fight Crime In California

additionalFields.Description: Law enforcement agencies are eager to use the cloud to help fight crime. Find out about our latest Criminal Justice Information Services Security Addendum with the California Department of Justice in this CRN article.
additionalFields.headline: Amazon Primes Its Cloud to Fight Crime In California

item.name: Nobody Knew How Big a Deal the Cloud Would Be—They Do Now

additionalFields.Description: Cade Metz takes a close look at how the perception of AWS has evolved since 2006 – from skepticism to broad adoption. Commentary from partner Chef, and Forrester analyst John Rymer drive home key points around AWS enterprise adoption trends. Rymer is quoted as saying, “The adoption of cloud among enterprises, which is really where the money is, has really picked up steam,” […] “It’s a big shift. The cloud has arrived. It’s inevitable.”
additionalFields.headline: Nobody Knew How Big a Deal the Cloud Would Be—They Do Now

item.name: AWS t2.nano instances offer dirt-cheap home for microservices

additionalFields.Description: TechTarget reporter Beth Pariseau covers the general availability launch of AWS t2.nano instances, quoting Gartner analyst Lydia Leong and 451 Research analyst Carl Brooks regarding the use cases for the new burstable instances.
additionalFields.headline: AWS t2.nano instances offer dirt-cheap home for microservices

item.name: Public cloud vs. on-premises, which is more secure?

additionalFields.Description: Members of the AWS Partner Network – Sonian, Cloud Technology Partners and Evident.io – weigh in on the security advantages the AWS Cloud offers in this Network World article. Check out our AWS Cloud Security page for insight into how AWS approaches cloud security as job zero.
additionalFields.headline: Public cloud vs. on-premises, which is more secure?

item.name: Australian Electoral Commission makes the move to the cloud

additionalFields.Description: The Australian Electoral Commission (AEC) has migrated business-critical workloads to the AWS Cloud. Working with AWS partner SMS Management and Technology, the AEC can now scale to manage more than 100 million hits to its website on Federal election night. The AEC website is vital resource for citizens and the press following the election results in real time.
additionalFields.headline: Australian Electoral Commission makes the move to the cloud

item.name: E-grocer uses real-time data to click with customers

additionalFields.Description: In this article, the Straits Times (Singapore) details how AWS customer RedMart uses Amazon Kinesis to track and process real-time customer data to offer a personalized, more intuitive shopping experience for customers.
additionalFields.headline: E-grocer uses real-time data to click with customers

item.name: How Notre Dame is going all in with Amazon’s cloud

additionalFields.Description: Network World covered Notre Dame’s cloud first strategy with a deep dive into why they decided to go all in on AWS. The article focuses on the scalability and security of the AWS Cloud as well as the technical training Norte Dame’s IT workers received as part of the deployment process.
additionalFields.headline: How Notre Dame is going all in with Amazon’s cloud

item.name: CIO Explainer: What is Hadoop?

additionalFields.Description: Check out this WSJ CIO Journal article that dives deep into Hadoop – focusing on the nuts and bolts of what it is and does.
additionalFields.headline: CIO Explainer: What is Hadoop?

item.name: Lafayette Elementary Hosts ‘Hour of Code’

additionalFields.Description: AWS sponsored a recent Hour of Code event at the Lafayette Elementary School in Washington, D.C. and provided a one-hour introduction course to computer science and coding. Learn more about ways AWS works with Code.org.
additionalFields.headline: Lafayette Elementary Hosts ‘Hour of Code’

item.name: Tackling a total traffic meltdown

additionalFields.Description: The Australian highlights how innovative Australian-based organizations like The Movember Foundation and Oztix are using the AWS to scale and manage seasonal internet traffic with the AWS Cloud.
additionalFields.headline: Tackling a total traffic meltdown

item.name: This is how you count all the trees on Earth – NASA project combines algorithms and AWS

additionalFields.Description: Fun AWS customer story from NASA’s “Head in the Clouds” contest and how AWS partner, Cycle Computing, helps NASA manage its data and cloud computing costs.
additionalFields.headline: This is how you count all the trees on Earth – NASA project combines algorithms and AWS

item.name: Amazon Cloud Gets More Business-Friendly

additionalFields.Description: Fortune covered the launch of the AWS Directory Service and its impact on enterprises looking to transition Microsoft-based applications on AWS.
additionalFields.headline: Amazon Cloud Gets More Business-Friendly

item.name: AWS Audit: MSP partners reveal how they passed

additionalFields.Description: AWS partners, Apps Associates and Datapipe, shed light on the rigorous auditing process they completed to achieve status in the AWS Managed Service Program. The program is designed for AWS Partner Network Consulting Partners who are skilled at cloud infrastructure and application migration, and deliver value to customers by offering proactive monitoring, automation, and management of their customer’s environment. Visit our site to learn more about the AWS Managed Service Program.
additionalFields.headline: AWS Audit: MSP partners reveal how they passed

item.name: Robinhood Gives Zero-Fee Stock Trading To Other Apps

additionalFields.Description: AWS startup customer is redefining the business of stock trading – and doing it all for free for their customers!
additionalFields.headline: Robinhood Gives Zero-Fee Stock Trading To Other Apps

item.name: AWS Lambda Makes Serverless Applications A Reality

additionalFields.Description: This TechCrunch article highlights AWS Lambda’s ability to simplify server deployments, storage, and database management for application developers. The article quotes AWS’s Matt Wood, “Lambda lets [developers] focus on developing applications without worrying about the heavy lifting of all the behind the scenes stuff of building the application.”
additionalFields.headline: AWS Lambda Makes Serverless Applications A Reality

item.name: Amazon Dedicated Hosts: Bye-bye to noisy cloud neighbors

additionalFields.Description: InfoWorld covered this week’s launch of AWS’s EC2 Dedicated Hosts writing, “Amazon claims Dedicated Hosts eases governance, compliance, and software licensing, but as a side benefit, it allows enterprise cloud customers to ensure their workloads aren’t shared with other workloads they can’t control.”
additionalFields.headline: Amazon Dedicated Hosts: Bye-bye to noisy cloud neighbors

item.name: Amazon shares landmark cancer genome data sets on cloud platform

additionalFields.Description: FierceBiotechIT reports on AWS’s role in making two of the world’s largest cancer genome datasets – The Cancer Genome Atlas (TCGA) and The International Cancer Genome Consortium (ICGC) PanCancer – freely available. Learn more about the AWS Public Data Sets program – our program for hosting large collections of public data that anyone can access for free!
additionalFields.headline: Amazon shares landmark cancer genome data sets on cloud platform

item.name: The guy who pushed Netflix into the future says we're still underestimating Amazon

additionalFields.Description: Adrian Cockroft, the driving force at Netflix who made the decision to move the company onto AWS, outlines a few trends he is seeing in IT including the rise of “’Serverless architecture,’ like the kind presented by Amazon Web Services' Lambda, will really take off since it makes it much easier for developers to build big apps that scale.”
additionalFields.headline: The guy who pushed Netflix into the future says we're still underestimating Amazon

item.name: 5 cities win AWS City on a Cloud challenge

additionalFields.Description: Congratulations to the five winners of the City on a Cloud Innovation Challenge, who demonstrate innovation on the cloud at state and local agencies across the world! This year’s winning cities are: Louisville, Ky., King County, Wash., Louisiana’s South Central Development and Planning Commission, Chicago, Il., and Marquette, Mich.
additionalFields.headline: 5 cities win AWS City on a Cloud challenge

item.name: The Guardian: ‘Our sources are safer in the cloud’

additionalFields.Description: During the AWS Enterprise Summit in London, AWS customer, The Guardian newspaper, shed light on its decision to migrate to AWS and the resulting business benefits – especially when it comes to security. In the article, Graham Tackley, director of data technology at The Guardian, is quoted as saying, “That's one thing about security, moving to AWS has been a really positive thing because it's forced us to think about it in a way we didn't think about it before.”
additionalFields.headline: The Guardian: ‘Our sources are safer in the cloud’

item.name: Beware of software companies cloud-washing their existing solutions

additionalFields.Description: The Economic Times takes a close look at AWS’s presence in India and our competitive differentiators following a discussion with AWS’s Adam Selipsky.
additionalFields.headline: Beware of software companies cloud-washing their existing solutions

item.name: Security’s future is the cloud, as enterprise trust in Amazon grows

additionalFields.Description: Matt Asay takes a close look at the future of security in the cloud – pointing to the GE and Capital One AWs use cases as proof that, “as more enterprises move workloads to the cloud, and secure those workloads in the cloud, there's a good chance that security will get better, as the public cloud providers provide superior security to internal security teams.”
additionalFields.headline: Security’s future is the cloud, as enterprise trust in Amazon grows

item.name: Amazon explains its secret weapon in the cloud wars

additionalFields.Description: In celebration of the one-year anniversary of the preview announcement for AWS Lambda, Business Insider takes a close look at what makes the offering so popular with the developer community. Matt W’s Business Insider writes of AWS Lambda, “It's just another way that Amazon is extending [AWS’s] lead in the hot cloud-computing market, where it's already a $7 billion player and growing fast.”
additionalFields.headline: Amazon explains its secret weapon in the cloud wars

item.name: London Calling! An AWS Region is coming to the UK!

additionalFields.Description: A few “In the News” highlights from this week’s announcement of the planned opening of our U.K. region by the end of 2016. item.name: The Amazon boss who conquered the cloud

additionalFields.Description: Check out this Financial Times article that chronicles the inception and early days of AWS, including its initial batch of target end users, “’We were targeting developers and start-ups who were not very well served at the time,’” Andy Jassy recalls. And Amazon decided to make itself one of the first customers, in a key step that meant its own retail operations would be completely reliant on AWS.”
additionalFields.headline: The Amazon boss who conquered the cloud

item.name: In the Works – AWS Region in South Korea!

additionalFields.Description: Today, we announced our plan to open an AWS region in Korea in early 2016, the fifth AWS region in the Asia Pacific area. item.name: 10 Signs The AWS Cloud Juggernaut Is Unstoppable

additionalFields.Description: Check out this CRN slideshow highlighting AWS’s recent milestones and key takeaways from re:Invent as well as the Q3 earnings announcements. CRN’s Joseph Tsidulko writes, “Amazon's fourth annual re:Invent conference and its more-recent third-quarter earnings call leave the impression that AWS is simply unready and unwilling to even slightly relinquish its massive lead in the market.”
additionalFields.headline: 10 Signs The AWS Cloud Juggernaut Is Unstoppable

item.name: AWS Emerges As Goliath As Cloud Competition Fades

additionalFields.Description: As stated in Q3 earnings, revenue for the AWS segment increased 78% y/y to $2.09 billion with 25% operating margin, making AWS an $8 billion run rate business. In this article, InformationWeek provides a detailed recap on AWS’s Q3 earnings announcements and their broader industry implications. Charles Babcock writes, “Amazon is where it is mostly because it keeps using cloud technologies to hand off more power to the customer. Its goal now is to hand off increasingly sophisticated services that end-users can self-provision and self-manage. Its call for database migrations to the cloud is just the start. Many more enterprise IT functions are likely to follow.”
additionalFields.headline: AWS Emerges As Goliath As Cloud Competition Fades

item.name: Amazon's Cloud Business Is Worth At Least $70 Billion

additionalFields.Description: Following the Q3 earnings announcements, Mat Asay and financial analysts estimate that AWS – as a standalone company – might be worth as much as $70 billion.
additionalFields.headline: Amazon's Cloud Business Is Worth At Least $70 Billion

item.name: Amazon’s case for running containers in its cloud
